He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:James was cooking s stew in his apartment kitchen.  Where might he look for a potato. Choices:  A: restaurants B: casserole C: root cellar D: pockets E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>D)<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the following table of conversions.<n><n>### Input<n>### Response<n><n>### Instuctions<n>Input:  A: 26.7 liters B: $15.7 C: 15.7 kg D: 27.208 liters E: 4.124 gallons F: 124 fluid ounces G: 208 ounces H1: $20.17 H2: $0<n><n>####A<n>Answer: $10.17<n>####B<n>Answer: $15.36<n>####C<n>Answer: 15.3 kg<n>####$10.17+$15.36+$15.66+$15.31=$76.44<n><n>### Instructons<n>Input: The amount of pizzas ordered by students at the school cafeteria doubled since last year.  It is important that they have at least 163 pizzas in the cafeteria for lunch. There was one day when students were gone, leaving leftover pizza in the refrigerators. If there were 6 pizzas left total in the refrigerator, then how many pizzas did they sell? How many extra pizzas do they need?<n>####Input:<n>$163$<n>$6$<n>6x163= $1018$<n>1018/6= $169.732$<n>Answer: $$6p-6m=163$$<n>For more, see [the next lesson](lesson3/solutions_4_lesson3.html)<n><n>### Lesson:Lesson 3<n>Input:  A group of six friends ran to raise money for a charity.  A carnival hosted a fundraiser to donate all of the proceeds to the charity.  The charity raised $7,468.  The carnival gave each friend $337. 413. 650. 583. 358. 050. What percent of the proceeds did the carnival give to the charity?<n><n>####
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n><n>### Response:		Choice A: drop to zero<n>Rationales: At the start of the day, the sun was out and the heat was increasing. The temperature would not change. At some point in the day, the sun went out, and the heat began to go down. The day then cooled down to zero.<n><n>### Input<n>The problem says, `if the square root of a number, n, is 9, what is n? Choices: A: 3 B: 47 C: 238 D: 24 C: 2 E: 48`<n><n>The solution is that the answer is `C`, n=238.<n><n>### Rationales<n>In the first line, we'll square root `238`. (We can do that because the second line tells us that to get n=238, we'll solve for n=9.) Then we'll cross multiply, `x = 9`<n><n>### Input `Fifteen percent of what number is five? Choices: A B C E F E<n><n>### Solution<n>The answer is `F`, 50.<n><n>In the first line we need to get 50 divided by 15. Since the second line in the problem tells us that the remainder after dividing 50 by 15 is 5, we know that 50/15=<50/15!=4><n><n>### Instructions:Which is the median of the following data set: 7, 15, 8, 4, 12, 17<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>The median of this data set is the 8th. There are an uneven number of numbers, so we don't have to go to the 7th number in the set. The 8th number in this set is 8.<n><n>## # Exercise 3.4<n>### Instruxion: What is the sum of the following digits in the following number: 5?<n><n>### Solution: <n>5005<n><n>## Instruxion<n>### Instrucions: What is the sum (addition) of the following digits in 2 6 4 7?<n><n>### Instructure: Write a program that asks the user
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where did his wife ask him to look first when he complained of missing deodorant? Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		I will choose D: get more.<n><n>### Explain your answer:<n><n>#### The response chosen is correct because when someone gets something and they are thankful, they probably want more. Also, if someone doesn't get something, when they get more of it, they have been thankful, so getting more would not be necessarily a right response.<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>#### Inference: When someone has not chosen anything, they probably have not thought of the answer. Also, when people do not have any idea, they usually pick something that has a meaning, and they also try to choose the options that have less choices to pick from, by elimination method.<n><n>A: B: C: D: E: <n><n>#### Demonstration: Inspire Math<n><n>Input: Harvey is a chef. If the original number increased by 18, the sum had a value of 73. If the original number first decreased by 11, and then increased by 18. Which operation should come before division?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### (A) Division<n><n>### Reasons:Original number = 35<n><n>sum = 73<n>#### 73 – 11 = 62<n><n>#### 42<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input : In his first year of college, Juan earned 196 dollars through part-time working during the summer. He made 118 dollars more working the summer after his freshman year. In total, he earned 414 dollars during his four years of college. How much money did he earn working each summer?<n><n>### Reaction<n><n>#### 56 dollars<n><n>#### (A)-37<n><n>#### Answer:C<n><n>### Input   :  If Juan earned 193 through part time during his first year of college and 118 during the summer after his freshmen year, then how much money did he ear in total during his four years at college?<n><n>### Ration :<n><n>#### The given are: $193 + $118 = $311<n><n>#### $311 = $414<n><n><n>```<n> $414 = $193 x 2<n> <n> $414 / 193 = $193<n> <n> $56<n> <n> => $56<n>```<n><n>#### D<n><n>###Input:The ratio of the ages of Lilly and Amelia was 5 to 3. Lilly was a hundred years older than Amelia. If the sum of their ages was 92, which of the following expressions shows Lilly's age?<n><n>###Ration:<n><n>```<n> 5/3 = 50/30 = 50 years/30years = 20<n><n> (H)<n><n> Lilly's age = 20 + 92 = 112
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If you're afraid of spiders what should you avoid owning? Choices:  A: meadow B: cupboard C: shed D: mail box E: cellar<n><n>### Response:		A, meadow.<n><n>### Rationale:This is the only choice that includes the word "wardrobe," the opposite of which is not provided in the question. Thus, E and C are likely also incorrect. While I do not know the exact meaning of D (mailbox in US), I am familiar with B and A from my previous knowledge of English (dictionary), and therefore the answer is A.<n>

If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:We do not have rest, so how are we feeling? Choices:  A: exhausted B: lonely C: worked all day D: were very tired E: feel better<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>  A. exhausted = <<>><n>  B. lonely = <<>><n>  C. worked all day = <<>><n>  D. were very tired = <<>> <n>  E. feel better = <<>><n>### Choices: D, E<n><n>### Response Rationales:<n>I felt like my answers made sense so I said what I felt even though it was wrong<n><n>[#][exercise]: exercise: 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. If the ostrich is 12.50 feet tall, what is the angle between its eye and the tree?<n>Rationales:- We have 265 feet x Sin (Anglem) = <<265*Sin(Anglem)=12.5>>12.5<n>12.5 feet is the eye point of the ostrich.<n>Angle is the triangle theta which connects from the point at the tree to the point where the bird stands.<n>So angle = 12.5/265 = 0.0475 = <<0.0477=47.5>>47.5 degrees.<n>Thus the answer is 47.5 degree.<n><n>Input: In the diagram below, the radius of a shining circle is equal to the radius of a smaller black circle. Choices:  A: board ship B: shout at C: smile at D: cross street E: feel happy<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A: board ship<n>* It is an idiom to say “board a ship” which means getting on it but it is more likely something is on a ship like an airplane.<n>* The sentence is incorrect.<n><n>#### B: shout at<n>* “Shout at” is a common phrase to mean speaking to someone loudly or excitedly.<n>* The sentence does not make sense, so the correct response would be either E or D.<n><n>#### E: feel happy<n>* To feel happy is to be satisfied or pleased. So, the sentence works.<n><n>#### D: cross street<n>* A “cross” street is a crossing place made where two or more streets meet.<n>* This is also the only verb tense that works with “cross.”<n>* Therefore, the only correct response is D.<n><n>### Input<n>Richard and Hurley are trying to finish their tax returns, but they don’t know if they should write down their total income or total taxes.<n><n>### Response<n>If they work backwards from the end, there is no confusion because the tax return is going to say, which is total income.<n><n>###Input<n>Molly needs 5 ounces of milk, a 0.8 oz bag of raisins, a 1.2 oz bag of cherries, and a 1.8 oz bag. Choices:  A: sea world B: court room C: shallow waters D: poker game E: card shark<n><n>### Response:		The answer to the instructions above is C (shallow waters)<n><n>### Rational:If you are a shark swimming deep enough in the ocean, you may mistakenly think the card players are emotionless. Therefore, since this is a card game, it is most likely that a poker game or shallow waters (card shark) are being played.<n><n>### Input::Jennifer has $50 in her piggy bank and earns $3 per week working her job at Starbucks. If she works every week of the year she plans to have $200 by the time she is 15. How many weeks does she have until that age? Choices:  a: 20 b: 10 c: 15 d: 22 e: 17<n>### Response: The answer to the above instructions is D (22)<n><n>### Answer Rational: By the time that Jennifer turns 15, she has to have saved at least $200. But if her weekly income is $3, if she saves $50, it would take $3 * 3 weeks * 50 + 50 * 10 + 50 = $1450. So with the amount that she has currently saved, she has 22 weeks until she turns 15, therefore her birthday is in 22 weeks.<n><n>### <n>### Input:The amount you save every week can be written as a formula. What number represents the amount that is saved every week if Amelia is saving for a trip to Disneyland? Choices: 100 200 300 400 500<n>### Response:<n>### Answer Rationale:<n>The formula for Amelia's saving is: 50 + 10 * $3. The answer must be less than 400, so the minimum answer is 4 because 400 is a maximum, and 5 is an integer. Therefore the answer is 4.<n><n>###<n>### Input: <n>### Response<n><n>###<n>

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where did the compassionate farmer allow the heifer to reside during her last days? Choices:  A: cattle ranch B: countryside C: grocery store D: slaughterhouse E: dairy farm<n><n>### Response:		I didn't understand the question.<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Choose what you think is the best answer from the choices provided and write it down below.<n><n>Then write your rationale to defend your answer.<n><n>Use text to explain your thinking. Use the RAD method and write out an explanation of your rationale for your selection.<n><n>### 1. Write your rationale<n><n>### 2. Write your answer choice
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Lilly owns the only kosher deli in the area.  She isn't in a heavily populated area.  Where might she live? Choices:  A: food court B: jerusalem C: new york city D: jewish community E: town<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n>####E<n>Answer:<n><n>###Instructions:Answer the questions.<n><n>####4:What is the best strategy to get all of your chores done? It’s Friday at 3:52 pm.<n><n>####5:How many students are enrolled in the middle school this fall?<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Choices:  A: tennessee B: band practice C: orchestra D: violin case E: music store<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationales:Because fiddle is the name of a musical instrument, and is plural in form.<n><n>### Source: The official SAT question website<n><n>### Input #2:What will be 10% of $600? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to thank someone for saying I have done a good job, what would I do? Choices:  A: smile B: shake hands C: express gratitude D: say you're welcome E: appreciate compliment<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is D: say you' re welcome.<n><n>Here is why: Saying you’re welcome is responding to good feedback by the other party.<n><n>#### D: say you' a welcome<n>#### Smile<n>#### Shake hands<n>#### Express gratitude<n>#### Say you're welcome<n><n>### Input<n>Five friends are on a trip to the zoo, and they all buy a ticket to the zoo. Two of the friends had a combined ticket in addition to their individual tickets, and three of the friends had individual tickets only. How many tickets did each person get?<n><n>### Response<n><n>I found the following information from the problem.<n><n>A total of 3 people have individual tickets only: $35 + 35 = <<35+35=70>>70<n><n>There were a total of 4 people, 2 of whom had combined tickets, the other 2 had individual tickets only: 25 + 25 + 70 = <<25+25+70=120>>120<n><n>So I got the total tickets sold: $120 = $$120 \over 4 =$<<120/2=30>>30<n><n>I can answer the question now.<n><n>Three people had individual tickets only, which we know is $35+35 = <<345>>35.<n><n>So we know the total number of tickets is 30 which means that tickets are $35 each.<n><n>####$35<n>Answer:$35<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. In the wilderess, they lit up night sky.<n>C: (3) James loved the stars, in the wilderness,  they lit up universe.<n>D: (4) James loved the stars; in the wilderness they  lit up the orbit.<n>E:(5) James loved the stars in the wilderness but they did not light the ground.<n>#### 4 points are deducted<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If she is the only one in the game, she gets to have twice as many cards as Bob. Alice decides to switch hands with Bob. Bob declares the game, and they decide to play another game. How many more cards does Alice have after the second game?<n><n>### Rationales<n>Bob wins the first game because Bob's hand of cards beats Alice's. Alice decides to make a new rule, and switches hands and plays against herself.<n>So it is Alice's turn again, and Bob wins the second game because Bob's and Alice's hand of cards tied each other. So, after the second game, there are no cards left over, and Alice and Bob have an equal number of cards<n><n>### Answer <n>49

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Sam left his muddy shoes in the entryway.  Where might he be? Choices:  A: department store B: school C: garden D: office building E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Sam is in house.<n>Rationales: Sam will not be in the school, department store, or the office.<n>Sam's shoes aren't muddy because he's in a house, so he can't be in school, department store, office building, or garden.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input:(Sam has a pet dog that likes to watch TV news reports.  What other news sources does his dog watch?) Choices:  A. newspaper. B. radio station. C. local television station D. family newsletter. E. family friend's social media posts.<n><n>### Response:(Sam likes to watch TV in his house.)<n>Input:  Sam watches the news report on TV at home.<n>Rationales:(Sam has a pet that watches news reports with him, so he must have a house)<n>Sam is in a house and the dog watches TV in the house, not at any other place.<n>#### 1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Why might a person take a vacation? Choices:  A: relaxation B: good things in life C: admiration D: own house E: needs money<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: Relaxation<n><n>### Instructions: Input: A box contains all five of the following items. Choices:  A box  B  C  D  E<n><n><n>### Instructoin: Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Input Choice: A box<n><n>### Response Answer: A box<n><n>Instruction:Write a code that will verify the correct answer in which you check whether an item is from the list.<n><n>### Answer: Write a C++ code that checks the given input and prints the list of options and if it finds the item it will print true.<n><n>### Code:<n><n>```C++<n>#include <iostream><n>using namespace std;<n>int main(){<n>    char choice;<n>    char item[4];<n>    int item_length;<n>    cout<<"Enter item from the list"<<endl;<n>    for (item_length = 0; item_length < 4; item_length++)<n>    cout<<"Item number "<<item_length<<": ";<n>    getline(cin,item{4});<n>    cout<<"Was  it one of the following choices?";<n>    switch (item_length){<n>    case 0:<n>        cout<<"A. box"<<endl;<n>        break;<n>    case 1:<n>        cout<< "B.  box"<<endl;  <n>        break;<n>     case 2:<n>        cout<<  "C.  box"<< endl;<n>        break; <n>         case 3:<n>             cout<<"D.  box"<<  endl;<n><n>        break;<n> case 4:<n>        cout<<“E.  box”<<  endl;<n>    default:<n>        cout<<item[0]<<endl;<n>}        <n>}<n>```<n><n><n>### Output:<n>Enter item from the list<n>Item number 0: A. box<n>Item number 1: B. box<n>Item number,D.box<n><n>Was  it one.of the following choices?<n>A. box<n><n># <n>

Choices:  A: determination B: upper hand C: superior D: higher position E: skill<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Option A:<n><n>```<n>Determination<n>```<n><n>### OptionB:<n><n>```<n>1st position.<n>```<n><n>## <n>### Option C:<n><n>```<n>Upper hand<n>```<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>### Reaching advantage position in a competition puts you in what position as compared with others. Choices: <n>- determination<n>- upper hand<n>- superior <n>- higher position<n>- skill.<n><n>### OptionA: <n><n>### 1st position if competition have multiple option. <n><n>## <n><n>Reach an advantage position puts me in what position 1).determination 2) upper hand 3) superior 4)higher position 5)skill.<n>The correct answer is :<n><n>```<n>Reach an advantage puts me in what position:<n><n>```<n>\(<n>\begin{array}{cccccc}<n>D & Determination & Upper Hand & Superior & \text{Higher} & \text{Skill} \\<n>\color{blue}{$\left\{ \begin{array}{l}<n>I \left( A \right) \Rightarrow A \cup \varnothing \cup \color{blue}{I} \cap \left( I \cup \color{Blue}{I} \right) \\<n>I \left( B \right) \Rightarrow \color{blue}{A} \cup \left\{ \text{D}\right\} \\<n>I \left(\text {C }\right) \Rightarrow A \\<n>I \left[\text {E} \right] \Rightarrow \color{Blue}{A}<n>\end{array}\right.}<n>\end{array}<n><n> \)<n><n>### <n><n>The correct answer is <n>[<A-2>]The correct answer is <4>.<n>The correct answer is    <D>. <n><n>### <A-3><n><n>```<n>\left(\begin{array}{lcl}<n>R = 0 & \neg \exists q\leq r & P = R<n>\end{array},<n>\begin{array}[t]{lcl}<n>P,Q\vdash (A\to\neg\exists xS(x,P,Q)) & P\cup Q\to \exists xS(x+1,P,

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. If he bought 3 more blue hats, 2 more white hats, and 1 blue hat, how many of each type of hat does he now have?<n><n>Rationales：He bought 10 hts in total, which means after he bought 3 more of anything, and he bought 2 more white hts, the hts he bought were 15 instead of only 10, plus his new 3 white hats and 1 blue hat.<n>```<n><n>### Input : A rectangular table has a base that measures 15 feet long and 12 feet wide. If the table is 2 feet high, what is the height of its top? Choices: A: 12 feet B: 4 feet C: 10 feet D: 8 feet E: 5 feet<n><n>### Response : A<n><n>Rationals : The height of the table must be 12 ft, because the length and width of the table are 15*12,  while adding a height of 2ft makes its area the square area of the top 15*15, so the height has to be 12 to make the height the square of the base 15, and the square of the width, and 15 being a square makes the height A.<n><n>### Response：The total cost of 50 items bought at a store was $962,60. What was the cost of each individual item?<n><n>### Rationals<n>Rationals: Since he bought 50 items to cost a total of 962,6$ and we know a total price to cost 962, 6$ 41,60, we can calculate a cost per item and the results is: $ 41,6/50 = <<4160/50=8 32>> 832$<n>#### 832<n>Answer: 832<n><n>### Response 3<n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Why would a person be approached by a lot of people? Choices:  A: care about B: compliments C: know all D: popularity E: understand themselves<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input 3: The number of people in the group is a ____ of 12.<n><n>### Answer 3: Divisible by (12)<n><n>### Inputs:The number of people in a household can be a multiple of ____ without any people being left out.<n><n>### Choices<n><n>- 1<n>- 3<n>- 6<n>- 9<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>The number of people in the household can be a multiple without any people being left in the list. As per the question, Household has 28 people in the List, and since 28 is divisible by 16 it meets the criteria.<n><n>### Anatomy:Write two statements that describe a condition in numbers. In statement __, use the term condition (with no spaces) and fill in the blank.<n><n>### Ex. Statement 1: The number of apples in the jug is more than 3 apples. Statement 2: The number of appositive phrases in the sentence is more than three.<n><n>### Rule:When the number of apples in an apple pie is more than 3, the pie is full.<n><n>### Statement 1:  When the number of appositive words in a sentence is more than three, the sentence is full.<n><n>#### 2016<n>Answer: 2016 <n><n>### Answers 1&2:<n><n>Statement 1: The number on the dice is less than (divisible by) 10. <n><n>Statement 2: The number given is more than 10.  <n><n>Answer 1:  The number of the dice is greater than 10.  (The dice can roll 1-6, and it is above 10 when it rolls the 7th or 8th.)<n>Answer 2: The number on the list was divisible by 10.<n><n>### Input #1: If John has 925 apples and Bill has 630 apples, how many apples are there altogether?  <n><n>### Rule #1: Whenever there is a number or a quantity, there are apples.<n><n>### Example 1: There are more apples under the apple tree than in my

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What might a satisfied person do? Choices:  A: board ship B: grocery shop C: cross street D: feel happy E: shout at<n><n>### Response:		The answer is B/C.<n><n>### Rationales: A-4000 B-99995 C-25 D-265<n><n>#### 265<n>Answer: 265<n><n>### Input/Output: You will be given information in the form of a table or a series of values. From the information provided, write a response that evaluates the statement.<n><n>### Example/Instructions: If the table is read from left to right, how many more red marbles are in the jar than green marbles?<n><n>### Example: Blue, Blue, Green, Green, Green, Red, Red, Red, Blue, Blue, Red, Green, Green, Blue, Blue<n><n>### Rationale: Red = 4 Green = 4 Blue = 3<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Inputs:You will be given information in table format.<n><n>### Input format: The tables provided are in the form of the following example: 12, 6, 3, 2, 4, 2, 1, 5<n><n>### Reworked Table: 12,  6,   3,   2,  4,  2,  1,  5<n><n>### Question: If the numbers in the table are read from left to right and numbers in the column are read from top to bottom, what is the next number in the table?<n><n>### Method: Count the number of times a particular color has appeared, that in this case is a color named "4". Count each one so that a total of 4 for 4 is counted, that is, it is counted 4 times.<n><n>### Formula: \fbox{$[\#\text{4-times 4]\] =$ 4}<n><n>#### 16<n>Answer: 16<n><n>### Input(s): You will be given two numbers. Students often ask, “Are grades just numbers?”<n>The following sentence could be written using this information: “A student’s first grade is assigned to correspond to the sum of the letters in the student’s first name, likewise a student’s second grade is assigned to correspond with the sum of the letters from the student’s last name.”<n>Rationales: This sentence is true because you can assign a value to the letters in a name.<n>A student’s first year of school could be his or her age.<n>A student’ first grade could equal the number of letters in his or her first name.<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input Is the following sentence true or false?<n><n>### Instructions An equation has _______<n><n>### Demstration<n>Input: A teacher divided a number of students into teams of two, four and six. Each team was given the same sum of money. The teams will take turns spending the money according to the rules of a game they make up. Which equation can model how the money is divided among the teams? <br> $4=2a+6a^2<br> $6a+2a^2=6<br> $4+2a=4a+2<br> $10=5a+6<n>Rationales: The first equation shows that since $4=2a$ then 2 * $2a$ = 4. (2 a x 2) = 4. 2 (a x 2) = _A_ (b x 2). A x D = A x 4. So A = 4. Then, $($4+2a) = 4a + 2$.<n>The second equation is equal to 6, so $6a + 2a^2 = 6 $, $6 + 2a^1 = 6 $, $4a + 2 = 6 $.<n>The third equation is equal to 4, so $4+2a = 4a+2$.<n>The fourth equation is equal to 10,

The others don’t make sense at all<n><n>### Input The average height of a herd of grazing kudu is approximately 130 cm. If a single kudu is 120 cm tall, 25% of the herd is taller than the tallest kudu, and 50% of the herd has an average height of 150 cm, what is the total number of kudu in the herd?<n><n>### Demostration: The options that are correct are A and B<n><n>### Input How much should 75 rolls of the following toothpaste cost?<n><n>**60 rolls are 1.25,** <n><n>**25 rolls of that are.35.**<n><n>**Total cost should be 75*(1.25+.35) = <<75*1.25=.9>>.9<n><n>Answers should be 0.75<n><n>### Input A person buys 5 bananas and 3 pears, but she buys 3 extra bananas and 2 fewer pears. Then explain how to solve the problem using that equation.<n><n>**The problem involves an equation such as 7x+9=6**<n><n>**If an equation starts with a letter X then do a x b**<n><n>**If you multiply, you multiply each value by the same amount and then add them. For example: 7 x 8 = 56**<n><n>**The answer will be on the other side of the equals sign**<n><n>### Input a = 4.3 x 5 = 21.5<n><n>### Choice should be the 5th letter of the alphabet and
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:When you experience boredom, what can you do on television? Choices:  A: watch film B: play cards C: play chess D: read news papers E: surf net<n><n>### Response:		<n>A)watch film B)play cards C)play chess D)read news papers E)surf net

It is not very effective to get to people to get out of paying the bills they don't want to pay, or paying the ones they can't pay.<n><n>2: The bills that people want to avoid paying or forget about and the bills they can't pay will just keep piling up over the time. Then, people get frustrated, they get into so much debt.  So instead of getting them to understand one another through paying bills, it will cause much more confusion and misunderstanding<n>####2<n>Answer:2<n><n>### Response(B:swap bodies):  The swap body might be quite scary for the young generation to consider.<n><n>When it comes to learning from each other, it is so important to understand each other's perspective<n>####<n>Answer:<n><n>### Response (C:learn from each other):  In my opinion, learning from each other is about accepting each other's point of view and seeing things from each other's perspectives.   The word people usually use at the end of the sentence "learn from each other", the most important thing is how you can understand each other's perspecive.<n>####<n><n>### Input (D:believe in god):  In the real world, many people may have a hard time understanding God. Choices:  A: planet B: basin C: submarines D: earth E: pacific<n><n>### Response:		Planet<n><n>### Instructions:Abby is preparing for the math olympiad. Her goal is to get at least some points on all the math problems she does.  She practices on a problem set that is two sections long.  However, she's having trouble keeping track.  She writes down all the problems she gets right on her first practice test (a).  However, on her second practice test (b), she missed four problems.  However, on her third practice test (c), she only missed one problem. She's decided that on her fourth practice test (d) she won't keep track of the ones she gets right and she won't keep doing that after that.  She would like to get perfect scores on each of the other four sections and she only plans to do four more practice tests before the olympiad. What math problems will make it to each of Abby's last four tests?<n><n>### Rationales:This problem involves an arithmetic sequence which is a set of numbers where each number in the sequence is simply obtained by adding a constant to the previous number.<n>Here we are going to start with 15 and we get 15, 16, 17, and so forth until we get to 18, 19 because there are 20 items in an arithmetic sequence which is why you do (18,19) with this.<n>Starting with 15 we want to know what number are there in sequence. Well once we know what the sequence the end, we can subtract the previous number from the current number. So 15-14 equals 1, and then 14 – 13 equals 56 and 14-15 equals 16. Well if it starts with 15, it means it needs to start with -15 until it gets as large as possible, and then it keeps repeating the sequence.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 16, 21, 26<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: 31, 36, 41, 46<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 51, 56, 61, 66, 71, 76, 81, 86, 91<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 156,

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John couldn't find a place to stay, and he didn't want to waste money.  He picked a place that was inexpensive and offered few luxuries.  Where might he be staying? Choices:  A: farm B: town C: city D: hotel E: motel<n><n>### Response:		E: motel<n><n>#### 20<n>Answer: A<n><n>### InputA: A family of 5 went on a budget vacation.  They spent money on lodging and meals but they limited the amount spent on souvenirs.  How much did they spend overall? Choices:  $140A: $60B: $80C: $90D: $100E: $120<n><n>### ResponseE: $12<n><n>#### 33<n>Answer: $100<n><n>### OutputThe sum of the first 10 terms of a geometric sequence is greater than the sum of the first 5 terms by a factor of 120.  What is the sum of the first five terms and the sum of the first ten terms? Choices: 120A: 60B: 102C: 105D: 130E: 140<n><n>### AnswerC: 102<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: $16<n><n>### InputThere are 4 boys in a group.  In how many ways can they be seated so that they are not all next to each other? Choices: 4A: 1B: 3C: 4D: 6E: 8<n><n>### ResponseA: 3<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: E<n><n>### InstructionsFind the value shown as a fraction to the nearest tenth.<n><n>### ResponseThe value is 37/4<n>#### 0.925<n>Answer: .97<n><n>### Instrument<n><n>### Response<n>Input:<n>There is a 3-leg table. One leg is 6 inches long, another leg is 2 inches longer than the first leg, and the final leg is 8 inches long. What is the length of the longest leg?<n><n>### Rational<n>#### 12.5<n>Answer: 15<n><n># Exercise<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Traders work on the floor of the stock what? Choices:  A: building B: hallway C: table D: exchange E: office<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question correctly to earn credit for this assignment.<n><n>Input: How many people were in the picture you submitted?<n>Rationales : People can see the background but can not see the people<n>#### 16<n>Answer: 8<n><n>Input: What is half of 20?<n><n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: I own six puppies, each of whom will share one meal each day. In all, 48 meals are required.  The dogs are eating approximately an average of 9 meals each day. What is the average number of meals eaten by my dogs in a day?<n><n>### Response<n>C<n><n>48/6 =<n><n>48/48 =<n><n>#### 8<n>Answer: 8 Meals A Day<n><n>### Input<n>The number in the top left corner would be called :B<n><n>### Response B<n><n>### Input and Response<n>7<n><n>### Input a multiple choice question. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What will happen to your knowledge with more learning? Choices:  A: headaches B: bigger brain C: education D: growth E: knowing more<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1. What will happen to your knowledge is you have more learning?<n><n>2. Choices:  A> headaches B> bigger brain C> education D> growth E> knowing more.<n><n>3. If you have more learning, Choice B will happened because, with more learning, headache will increase because, headache come from studying and education (you will be educated) or headache comes from studying, but if you do education, headache can reduce so Choice B will help you,<n><n>4. Conclusion:<n><n>   - Choice A, because for headache you choose D, so Choice B is better than C<n>

How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: insane B: annoy people around C: enjoy D: inhale E: had good voice<n><n>### Response:		The last reason is "had a good voice".<n><n>#### D<n>Answer:  D,<n><n>### Input<n><n>The number of years when the earth was created. Choices:  in the 21st, the 22nd, the 17th, the 18th, the 23rd.<n><n>### Response<n><n>The last choice is 'the 18th'.<n><n>#### 18<n>Answer:  The 18th.<n><n>### Input <n>You can write a program to print the numbers from 1 to 100.<n>You can print a line of 5 spaces to separate the different sets of numbers, and the new set will start on the next set of 5 spaces.<n><n>### Request<n>Input: How much output would be printed using this program? How much does each set of numbers printed cost?<n><n>### Rationale:First set of numbers costs 1 and the other sets of numbers cost 5 each because 5 x 20 = <<5 x 20=100>>100<n><n>#### 100<n>Answer:  The first set of numbers printed costs 1, the rest cost 5 each.<n><n>### Note:<n>You can only use 2 variables. Here are the variables you have access to:<n><n>**number_of_sets**<n><n>**cost_per_set**<n><n>### Input/Request<n>Input: What is x times 2. Choices:  A:-3 B: 3 C: -8 D: 5.5 E: 5<n><n>### Rationales:<n>If x is -3, 5/2 is still -3.<n><n>If x is 3, 5/3 is still 3.<n><n>If  x is -8, 5/8 is still -8.<n><n>So choices (A) and (C) are the same and choices (B) and (E) are the same, and the only other remaining choice is (D).<n>#### D<n>Answer:(D), which is 5.5<n><n>### Input and Request:<n>Input: What is the area of a square if the length is 23. Choices:  Area: A:-30.47 B: 193.375 C: -
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The mother was worried about all the spills, so she bought a rug for under the what? Choices:  A: persia B: table C: living room D: house E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n>(Input) rug for house AUG 23 C.jpg <n>#### E - Desk<n>Answer: E - Desk<n><n>### Input<n>Sarah is planning on making a birthday cake for a friend. Choices:  A: sum B: likeness C: alike D: sameness E: similarity<n><n>### Response:		A)sum<n><n>### Justification:<n>The differences are the result of either subtracting or adding different numbers. The sum of these two operations will always be 0.<n><n>### Response 2: B)likeness<n><n>### Justifications: The likeness is equal to 0 because subtracting or adding the same number will produce 0. The sameness is the same as likeness, as well. Therefore, B and E are the same answer.<n><n>### Difficulty<n><n>If you do not know, don’t cheat. Ask your teacher.
