If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The man tried to run, but he could not. He could that he could only move by doing what? Choices:  A: stand B: go quickly C: walking D: stand still E: walk slowly<n><n>### Response:		The man could that he could only go by doing "walking"<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostrations : The following Demostration will not help you. You are on your own<n><n>### Instuctions: Write a response that appropriatley completes the request. Write your answer on answer page<n><n>### Input Answer : The difference in ages between 16, 25 & 38 is 15.  If 25 years old is twice as old, how old is 16?<n><n>### Rationales: The difference in ages 16, 48 is 32.  This is 24 because 48 – 24, so 25 years old and 25 has to be 4.2 times older.<n><n>### Input answer 2: The difference in ages of Doreen and Kyle is 11. If Doreen’s age is more than 5 times Kyle’s age, how old is Kyle?<n><n>The difference is 11 and Kyle is less. So Doreen has to be more than 5 times 5 = 25, because Kyle is only 11.<n><n>### Input 3: Annie’s age is one-third the sum of the ages of her daughter and her son. If her daughter is 16, and her son is 21, what is Annie’s age?<n><n>Annie’s age has to be, 15, because the difference is 16 + 21 = 37, and 16 is the lowest. So Annie has to be 52.<n><n>### 4th input : After 3 hours, Ben subtracts 6 from 2 times his current age. After another 3 hours, Ben wants to subtract 4 from 8 times his current age. How old is Ben at this point?<n><n>Ben subtracts 6 + 8 = 14 from 2.  So at 5 hours, it subtract 14, which is equal to 7, and at 8 hours he can start counting. So he can start counting at 14.<n><n>He can start counting at 9 because he subtracts 4 from 2.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is an way for people to meet with each other? Choices:  A: believe in god B: pay bills C: group together D: enjoy themselves E: face each other<n><n>### Response:		C: group together.<n>

How much money will each student have?<n><n>**Solution:**<n><n>Total amount given by teacher to each student $9.00/4 students = $<<9/4= $2>>2  For first $3.00 each, For second $2.4 = $<<2.4<<2.4= $4.8 each, For third $1.2 = $<< 1.2<<1.2= $2.4 each, For fourth $0.4 = $<<0.4<<0.4= $0.8.<n><n>**Solution**<n><n>Solution= $2+2.4+2.4+0.8,<n><n>=5. <n><n>$5.<n>

Choices:  A: grandma B: clothing C: jewelry store D: clothes E: fabric store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In order to buy the velvet material, she would have to look in a Clothing store of a Jewelry stores.<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>Cause C and E is a fabric, a clothing is not a fabric. Fabric stores are clothing for children and babies with low price. Clothing stores are a fashion store with more price.<n><n>### Input<n><n>The problem is a question that says “Jerrod has 2 times as many cookies as his brother, and Caitlin has twice as many cookies as Jerrod. What is the sum of their cookies.”<n><n>Finding the cookies that Jerrod has and his brother also have the same amount of cookies. That answer is 40. Jerrod and his brother each have 20 cookies, now we also can find that Caitlin has 20 cookies. Jerrod and Caitlin have the same amount. <n><n>Adding them up together and seeing the answer is 80.<n><n>### Answer<n>Caitlin and Jerrod each have 20. Jerrod has 20 + 20= 40. He wants to know how many cookies Caitlin has, Caitlin has 40. (20+20)=80<n><n>### Instructions<n>Input: The sum of two consecutive integers is ­16. What are those integers? Choices: 1) 4 and 3; 2) 5 and 3; 3) 6 and 2; 4) 1 and 14; 5) 12 and 13<n><n>A: 5 and 3<n><n>B: 12 and 4<n><n>C: 6 and 2<n><n>D: 1 and 13<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:After bringing eggs home from the store in what are they held? Choices:  A: chicken coop B: supermarket C: box D: egg carton E: henhouse<n><n>### Response:		<n>Eggs are stored in the supermarket in their own special room away from the actual store. There are several reasons for this, first the eggs may become contaminated if they were stored in a different room. The store can also charge more for egg because they have a safe location. The egg carton is another reason why eggs are sold a special price. <n>The only reason eggs are stored in a carton is for practicality and for easy dispersion. A carton is made for people who only have a few eggs and wants to carry it a convenient distance instead of lugging a whole package home.<n>#### 4<n>Answer: Eggs are stored in their own special room in the supermarket<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The wood became fossilized, what did the paleontologists call it when they found ti? Choices:  A: sanded B: composted C: warp D: hardened E: petrify<n><n>### Response:		E <n>##### <n><n>### Input : The population of a certain town went from 314,567 in 2005 to 344,763 in 2010. What is the total population growth in this town in these five years?<n>##### <n>##### 330180<n>Answer : 3301<n>

Choices:  A: detroit B: australia C: michigan park D: cafe E: retail store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>We should only buy retail if we choose Detroit, Australia,  or Retail Store since if we do not choose those choices we will always buy at the Cafe if we do not choose any of the other 3 locations.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>If we take away the locations of barbecue sauce that we do not want we must take away from retail store. So from Choice A we take away 3 locations, from Choice B we take a way 1 location. From Choice C we take away 0 locations.<n><n>## Contribute<n><n>For any bug reports, suggestions, or feedback you may have, please report them in the issues section:<n><n>- [Issues page](https://github.com/CodeSignal/coding-challenge-test-bank/issues)<n>

Choices:  A: lake B: aquariums C: swimming pool D: pond E: childrens pools<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is C.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>If the body of water is shallow, it is because the depth of the water is not very deep in that place. So if you're in an aquarium (like a childrens' pool) you won't be able to see the floor of the aquarium.<n><n>### Input<n>What is the volume of a sphere? Choices:  C: the volume of a sphere is 4 pi r cubed + pi r 2 h 2. D: h = r is the height of the sphere above the equator. B: r is the radius. A: the area of a sphere is 2(4 pi) where pi is 3.14. E: None of the choices are correct.<n><n>### Response<n>The correct answer is B.<n><n>### Solution<n>If you knew the radius of a sphere, you could determine the volume of the sphere. Then, using Pythagorean theorem, you could determine the height of the sphere.<n><n>### Example with two dice:<n>If you have a dice, the volume of the dice is 5.4 x 5.4 x (1/6) as there is 1/6 chance of rolling the die.<n><n>### If you have two dice, the volume of each die is 5.4 cubed, times 5.4, which is 5.4^6.<n><n>### To determine the volume, we add 4.4^6 + 4.5^6 which is 4.4 + 4.5 = 9 cm^3<n><n>### To compare the difference between the height and the radius, use Pythagorean Theory: √(4.4^6)(√4.5^6) = (5)2 which is ≈ 25.6<n><n>### This is less than 7/2, since 4.4^3 is less than four times it's radius, so it is true.<n><n>### This follows because 5.5^6 ≈ 4 and 4.4^4 = 4.20001, which is less than 5.<n><n>### Note the use of a fraction. This is how to simplify the calculation. If you plugged in 56, it would

Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The banjo finds it's history in the Caribbean, but it's probably most famous where? Choices:  A: music shop B: music store C: jug band D: united states E: among nice people<n><n>### Response:		Banjos have an interesting history in the Caribbeabn. They origionated in the Caribbean and spread to areas throughout the Americas and eventually to the United States. Because of the popularity among country folk (jug bands) the banjo became more popular and began being seen in music stores.<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>### Inputs:<n>1.  The sum between and is<n>2.  The sum between 3 is and is<n>3.  The sum between n is and is<n>4.  The sum between l and is is<n><n>### Response<n>1. 8 and 4<n><n>2. 13 and 4<n><n>3. 17 and 3<n><n>4. 20 and 1<n><n><n><n>#### 8 and 4:<n><n>-Sum of 8 and 4 is 12<n><n>#### 13 and 8:<n><n>-Sum 13 and 3 is 16<n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does someone need to do to begin creating art? Choices:  A: relax B: controversy C: pleasure D: frustration E: needs theater<n><n>### Response:		The only choice that begins creating art is the one that states that someone needs theater. People need theater because theater is where someone can find frustration, controversy, and pleasure. In theater, there might also be things that can be used to help someone relax.<n><n>---<n><n>### Input and Description:<n>Write a sentence that adds a phrase/word to the sentence below.<n><n>### **The newest model of my phone came with a great camera and a**<n><n>Write a response that appropriately adds a word to the sentence below. <n><n><n>The newest model of the iPad came with a great camera, but<n><n>#### Apple<n><n>Input: How many hours does it take an average person to drive 250 miles from New York to Boston?<n><n>Rationales:  Assuming the person drove straight and without stopping, it will take the average person x = <<250/20> = <<3150>>3150 hours to get from New York to Boston.<n><n>#### 3150<n>Answer: 3150 <n><n>#### Input: 8.8 <n><n>#### Answer:2391.4 <n><n>#### Input & Rationale:<n>You have an opportunity to invest in a particular stock. The stock is guaranteed to appreciate by 6%, and you can hold on to it for 5 years. However, the stock will produce a dividend payment of $10 next year. <n><n>**What is the payoff you will receive in a dollar after 5 years?**<n><n>#### Answer:<n>It is not possible to determine the payoff (unless you have more than 6 years of information).<n><n>---<n><n><n><n><n>---<n><n>

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. In this case, the student answered lake, but they didn't write their reasoning. It didn't matter.   He didn't heave anything to put it on, and he lacked the what to balance it? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n>Correct response is B, hands.<n><n>### Justification:<n>If the man didn’t have any thing to place the cup on like a table, he wouldn’t put it on the table and it wouldn’t matter. And it doesn’t say any kind of the lacking the ability to do the what the man doesn’t have hands or anything else to put the table to balance the cup?<n><n>The correct response is A, A 13 B,B 27 C,C 37 D,D 42 E,E 54<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the questions for the following passage.<n><n>### Paragraph 1:<n>We're getting to know each other is the first thing my daughter said when we entered their dorm room on move in day. Ava was one of those girls who was always smiling, but she knew how to express her unhappiness when she had some too. Ava was from a poor family and her parents were divorced. To make it worse, her dad ended up in jail while she was in high school. However, she refused to let any of that prevent her from excelling in school while she was still in school and working part time to make sure that she could have the things she needed. Ava was a member of my church, and when it came time to apply to college, my wife and I worked with her to find the best college for her to attend while also making sure that she'd have the resources she needed for each of our programs. We were blessed to find the perfect spot in the beautiful mountain location of Asphodel Falls with the best price that could accept Ava's scholarship that she earned thanks to her hard work.<n><n>### Question 1:<n>This reading is about a young woman named Ava who decides to go to ***college***. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:You might head to the locker room after getting a green drink here. Choices:  A: health club B: jocks C: fitness centre D: stadium E: gymnasium<n><n>### Response:		Health Club is the answer to the question.<n><n>## Input:Brian has 7 friends, Jake, Kevin, Sam, Mike, Sora, Lucy, and Evan. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The only baggage the woman checked was a drawstring bag, where was she heading with it? Choices:  A: garbage can B: military C: jewelry store D: safe E: airport<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>Baggage is most likely to be headed to the airport.<n><n>### Note: If you’re not sure about multiple choice answer choice, pick a choice that is most logical.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>A man has $20. He wants to save $3 per day. He also wants to save 50 cents for each time the temperature rises over 100 degrees Fahrenheit. He earns $20 per week.  If the temperature reached 100 degrees, how much money would he get after his first payday?<n><n>### Note the following hints:<n>1. Temperature rises > 100 degrees --> Increase daily savings by 50 cents<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>This problem would be easier if we first had to look at the temperatures. For example, if it rises to > 100 we save $.50 each time it reaches that temperature. Let's make that a bit clearer.<n><n>So far we have, $$ 20 + (.50*3) + (2*50) + (20 + 3) = $$<n>$$ 20 + 15 + 100 = $$<n>$$ 135 $$<n><n>### Inputs:<n>A man has 20.  He wants to save 3 per day, and 50 cents per every time the temperature is over 100.  He earns $25 per week.  If it were to reach the temperature of 100, how much money would the man get from his first payday?  A: $.7 B: $375 C: $50 D: $20 E: $-5 C<n><n>### Solution A<n><n>In order to find the difference and the value of the pay day we'd have to find how much money we started with each day.  Since we earn $25/week this seems like it could be a problem.  Instead we can use  a different method.<n><n>So far our answer is:  $7*6 = $42  We have $42 left in our account at the start of the day but remember our savings that we receive each day is not the same amount of $2.50

Write a response that correctly completes the instruction.<n>Input: John paid 25% of the tax on a new boat. He also paid 1.50% interest on a loan to buy the boat. He put down $2200 of his own money and got the rest for a down-payment in the form of a loan. How much money did he have to put down?<n><n>### Instructions<n>1. Multiply the 25% of tax by the price of the boat: (0.25)(13,500)=3875<n>2. Multiply the interest payment by 365 for one year: 90(365)= 32,450<n>3. Add the tax payment and the interest payment to the money saved, and subtract the cash price and down payment:<n>```3875(minus)90(minus)2200=25875-3450-2200=17605```<n><n>### Question:What does $17605 represent?<n>####Answer:The amount of cash John had to put down<n>###Instructions:Tally tally tally! The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:You can share files with someone if you have a connection to a what? Choices:  A: freeway B: radio C: wires D: computer network E: electrical circuit<n><n>### Response:		Input:A: freeway and B: radio are not correct<n>C and D are correct<n><n>### Rationales: Freeway and radio do not answer that what must be shared is files, so not an option.<n>Freeway refers to streets and can not be shared.<n>Radio needs other people's frequencies to work so cannot be shared.<n>Wires and computers can be shared, so correct<n><n>### Electrical circuit is not correct.<n>Electricity is different than electronics, so not an option (Wires and computer are option options)<n><n>### Input:"The city’s 2012 budget deficit was 14.9 percent of its revenue. Which number must be increased by 1.4?”<n><n>### Response:"E"<n><n>### Rationale:The deficit is 14.9% of 2012 revenue.<n>1.4 is about 7%. To cover the 1.4 and keep the percentage relationship correct, it will have to be added to the deficit.<n><n>### Input:[![Damon wants to know how much it costs to rent a car if he rents for 5 days. He rents a car that costs $25 per day and then another car that costs $45 per day. He also has a 50% discount on the 4th and 5th days. Write and solve an equation to find the total cost of the rental.<n><n>### Response:[![Renting the first car is $25 and then renting the second car is $45. If he has a discount of 50%, this means that it costs half price to rent the second car for a 4th and 2nd time.  However, his discount does not apply to the first car. If $90 of the total cost is for the second car, then $90-(1/2*$90)= <<$90-(1/8*$90)=$29>>$29 goes for the second car and $25 goes to first car. If the answer is $25 + $29 = <<25+29=54>>55 days, then $55+25= <<55+25=$76>>$76+$75+$
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Though he could've kept going his body appreciated the rest, it had been constantly what during the day? Choices:  A: walk B: lay down C: working D: moving E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question states that he could've kept walking, but he preferred laying down after a long day of work.<n>**A: Walk** Choice: **A: walk** <n>**B: Lie down** Choice: **B: lie down** <n>**C: Work** Choice: **C: work** <n>**D: Move around** Choice: **D: move around** <n>**E: Exercise** Choice: **E: exercise** <n>**The question is asking for what he did during the day, but the choices do not fit the description of what he did during the whole day.**<n>#### <n>Answer:<n><n>### Input The difference in ages between Rich and Hurley is 18 years. If Hurley is eight years older than Richard, how old are they at that age? <n><n>### Response<n>To find out how old they are, we take their present age and deduct the difference between their ages. <n>Richard is 11(8), Hurley is 4(8)<n>Hurley must be 5 years younger/older than Richard<n><n>The question doesn't tell us when their ages are at. We don't know if they are still 11 and 4 or if they are at a different age. <n><n>We can also use the answer the question gave in Richard's answer.<n><n>Richard is 4 years older/younger than Hurley right now. They will probably be 5 years older/young than Hurley in 20 years<n>#### <n>Answer<n>None of the answers do.<n><n>###Input: A pizza costs $5.50. A side salad costs 1.50.  If a customer orders a large pop that costs $0.25 cents, how much does the total bill come to?<n>Output: One dollar ninety-five cents<n>Rationales:<n>Bill will be $5.50 + 1.50 + 0.25 = $<<5.50+1.50+0.25=7>>7.25<n><n>**A pizza costs $5 then the side salad costs $1.50**<n><n>**Bill will be $7.25 if they bought a Large pop for 25

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:I have something in my head I want to share, what ways can I do that? On the same day C as the 2nd choice<n><n>## Output<n>Output: The answer of this question is 'D' because if it is always cloudy and it is sunny in afternoon it means, the man start his job in morning 3:30 at same time it will remain sunny in afternoon because sun rises again so it will be same the next day<n>### Instruions<n>Write a response that answer the question<n><n>### Demasation<n>Input: Find 5!<n>#### 120<n>Output: 5! = 5*4*3*2*1<n><n>## Input<n><n>Input: Mr. Scales has 20 cows. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The president is the leader of what institution? Choices:  A: walmart B: white house C: country D: corporation E: government<n><n>### Response:		If the word was walmart, I would say it's a corporation<n>If the word was white house, I would say it is a government<n>If the word was country, I would say it was a country<n>If the word was corporation, I would say it was government<n>If the word country, I would say country was government<n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n>

Choices:  A: stressful B: dangerous C: fun D: illegal E: deadly<n><n>### Response:		<n>Deadly<n>Rationale:<n>Deadly -<n>"Deadly driving," "deadly driving" or "deadly" are used to describe a driving style that leads to accidents:<n><n>- In his blog 'deadly driving', Mr. X said that driving a car too fast is dangerous. (from the English Dictionary)<n>- <n><n>### Input : Which of the following is true of the following?<n><n>1. The price of a dozen donuts goes from $3 to $4 and the price of a bottle of soda goes from $2 to $3.  Which is the bigger savings?  A. It is the same for both items.  B. It is the same, but only for the donuts.  C. It is bigger for the soda, D. It is bigger for both items<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>Even if the change from 1 to 2 is twice the change from 3 to 4, but the total savings will be more in the first situation because both commodities will be more (three times 2 =9.  one and two both are increasing but the first one is much greater than the second)<n><n>#### C<n><n>Answer: C

Choices:  A: advisory B: mandate C: soap opera D: elective E: optional<n><n>### Response:		E: optional <n><n>### Instuctions:Answer the following question.<n><n>## Rationale:The evacuation become mandatory <n><n>### Choices:  A<n><n>### Rationale:Mandatory means necessary or required, especially because of a rule or law. Advisory means for giving information, or an order or suggestion that an official does not require. Mandatory is NOT an option if the evacuation had become mandatory.<n><n>### Choice: B<n><n>### Rationales:Mandate means authority that has been given by a central organization, especially by a government, to rule a particular area. Mandate means to give control or order to somebody or a group of people. Elective means chosen by popular vote; not compulsory. <n><n>### Rental: C<n><n>### Rationale:  Elective soap opera means an optional or chosen television program in the form of a play or film that is broadcast in installments. Elective means chosen.  So the rental of a soap opera means <n><n>### Option D: MANDATORY, because the evacuation was forced by the government.<n><n>### Option E: OPTIONAL, because you can still not go in the evacuation.<n><n>### Answer: E: OPTIONARY<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input: You will be assigned to a group of 4 or 5 students for a project.  Group leaders are still needed.  How many different ways can you divide the job?<n><n>### Answering multiple choice questions: Always read completely all choices. Try to always identify the answer that makes NO sense or <n><n>### Does not fit in a particular case, try to identify that answer choice.<n><n>### Rating systems on exams:  It is important to choose the first answer choice, always read the answer completely.<n><n>### If you are in doubt, identify that answer choice. This will help you eliminate a potential answer because of their answer rationale. <n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Learning languages is difficult.  Even in a full immersion environment you're likely to make mistakes, mistakes will cause misinterpretation, which will be uncomfortable, which will cause what?, Choices:  A: better communication B: overthinking C: frustration D: misunderstandings E: headaches<n><n>### Response:		E Headaches<n><n>#### <n>Answer: E Headaches<n>

Choices:  A: owner B: foot C: subordinate D: base E: point<n><n>### Response:		The owner, the head, or in this case, the branch is a subset of the entire organization, which would be called the branches' leader. In a branch office or similar set up, there is usually a higher-up branch supervisor who is head of everyone working in that office. This person, in turn, is directed by some higher-up and is responsible for the workers in the head-yeller's branch. The head-yeller is responsible for these, and therefore they work with them, are their superior, and tell them what to do. To tell someone to do something is to direct someone to do that thing. Therefore, this person is directing those under their command. This person could be considered the leader of the branch.<n><n>#### Response Rationale:<n>The head-yeller is directing this person's subordinates/employees.<n>The head-yellers boss/employees leader is then responsible for the head-yeller and all other employees/subordinates<n>The responsibility can then go up the chain of command until the head of the organization is reached (the CEO)<n>#### CEO<n>Answer: C<n><n>Answer: The correct answer is D, points. A point can direct a person to turn left or right.<n><n><n>To do so, they would stand at one intersection (the point) and yell directions at the driver, pointing (directing) with their arm.<n>If the driver is not sure which direction to go, they may ask the person for directions.<n>The driver may inquire as to which way to go, by asking what direction to turn.<n>To do this, the driver would point to where they are going to turn which is known as a point.<n>The point is directly in front of the car and directs the driver to go in a certain direction.<n>In the diagram, the direction that the person is pointing is towards the point where the road forks, which tells the driver to make a left turn.<n>So, a point would be the name for that specific location where it is used to direct a person to decide which way to go.<n><n>#### Point<n>Answer: D<n><n>Answer: The point is directly in front to the car, so they need to point the driver in that direction to decide which way to turn.<n><n>#### Point: Answer A: No<n>Answer B: Yes<n>Answer C: No<n>Answer D:Yes<n>Answer E:

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:When you play around with your dog they will have? Choices:  A: alive B: health C: fun D: playing dead E: black<n><n>### Response:		A is the best choice because "alive" is when the dog is playing but "playing dead" is when your dog is still, but it's not always when your dog is playing<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Write a response that appropriately complete the request.<n><n>Below is an instruction that describes in a sentence the task before you.<n><n>#### Input:Find the distance between the given pair on the coordinate grid.<n><n>#### Demonstration: <n>Input: Find the distance between (9, -7) and (-5, 3)<n>Rationales: Subtract their coordinates<n>9 - (-5) = <<9-(-5)=4>>4<n>-7 - 3 = <<-7-3=-10>>-10<n>10 + -10 = <<10+-10=0>>0<n>Therefore, there's no distance between the given pair.<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>Input:Find the total distance between the given pair of vertices.<n><n>Input: The distance between (2, 8) and (1, -3) is <n><n><n>### Instuctions: <n>Write a response that can be evaluated by the student to determine that it is correct.<n><n>Input: Find the total distance between the pair of vertices (4, 1) and (3, 5)<n><n>### Response<n>4 - 3 < <4-3=-1>> -1<n>Add 1<n>3 + 1 = <<3+1=4>> 4<n><n>#### 4<n><n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Instuctino<n>Write a response that shows that the student understood the question.<n><n>## Demonstration<n>Input: The question is:<n><n>The picture below shows the distance between points P and Q. Find the distance between the midpoints of the two lines and between P and Q. Enter your answers as a comma-separated list.<n><n>Rationale: The midpoint between the two lines shown is (2,3)<n>Between (2,3) and  (2,-2) we have<n>2 - 2 = <<2-2=-2>>-2<n><n>So we subtract them and our answer is < <<2-2=-4>>>>-4<n><n>Now we subtract Q, (1,-4)

Choices:  A: depressed B: downcast C: angry D: unhappy E: sorrowful<n><n>### Response:		I am not glad, upset or pessimistic, which may be that I am miserable<n><n>### Explanation: I am not glad. If I am not glad, then one of the ways that I can be is if I am depressed. Another way to be upset without being glad is if I am downcast. Being upset or downcast means I am angry, upset. If I am upset, downcast or angry, then I am most likely also unhappy or pessimistic. Finally, if I am upset, pessimistic, downcast, or angry, I will most likely be unhappy or sorrowful.<n><n>### Input 2:What happens to the second word when you add two words that contain the same letters to the end? Choices:  a: They change place. b: Both remain. c: One remains. d: Both change places. e: Neither remain<n><n>### Response 2:Both remain.<n><n>### Exprination:The second word is a two letter word, so when we add words that contain the same letter, nothing will change.<n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input : If a plane takes off heading northwest and lands heading north with the same speed, how many degrees did it travel? If it was not heading east or west, then it traveled half of a circle and went a 1/4 of the distance around.<n>#### 25<n>Answer: 25<n><n>

If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John was punching and punching at the wall but succeeded only in bloodying his knuckles. This was bad.  He would be unable to hold his tools if he injured what? Choices:  A: hostility B: anger C: nose D: fists E: hands<n><n>### Response:		John was punching the wall but succeeded in only bloodying his fists. His anger, hostility, and nose were all not harmed.<n><n>### A: Hostility<n><n>### Input<n>The number of days it takes to get to the moon is 384,000 km. What is the closest number to it without using the decimal point?<n><n>### Response<n>If the number of days = 384, then the number without using the decimal point is 384<n><n>### **20 minutes** (5 minutes each)<n><n>\### **21 minutes** (11 minutes each)<n>Input: I love you.<n>Output: I love you. What more can I say?<n>I love you. What more is there to say?<n>What else can I say?<n><n>Input: This is a simple operation.<n>Output: This is a simple problem. This is a simple operation for a problem.<n><n>Input: My mother is 42.<n>Output: I'm just a little older than you.<n>Is your mother 152, 172?<n><n>Input: The distance to earth travels through 4 months of travel.<n>Output: The distance to earth is a 4-month journey.<n>The distance to earth is a four-month journey.<n><n>Input: Who wrote the following question? I will buy all 5 apples for $8.00<n>Output: Why did you ask this question?<n><n>### **(20 minutes)**<n><n>\#### Instruction: Answer the following in an organized manner.<n><n>1. Find and save the input.<n>2. Write and save the output, one output at a time.<n>3. The outputs will need to be evaluated by checking for errors.<n><n>\#### Demonstration: Sample output is provided to walk you through the process, or watch the tutorial: [Link](https://www.loom.com/share/569de1d7c60f4065952a359474e6c36b)<n><n>#### 384,713 = 384713<n><n>### **5:00-6:45**<n>### **Answers (5 points each)<n>1. Instruction
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would a lizard surprise a person? Choices:  A: new mexico B: forrest C: dessert D: garden E: creek<n><n>### Response:		<n>Surprise is used in a negative context in B.<n><n>### Input<n>How many years ago was William born?<n>A: 1.923 years B: 1.427 years<n><n>### Response<n><n>Years ago is used in the same sense. I do not think years ago is the correct answer<n><n>### Input <n>What is 30 minutes from now?<n>A: 3 years ago B: 3 days ago C: 3 weeks ago D: 3 months ago<n><n>### Response <n>Both 30 minutes and 3 years ago are used in the same way, so B is the correct answer.<n><n>### Answer<n>Because we know William went to 4 different schools before sixth grade, there are four schools in the answer.<n><n>## Input: There are a few shops on our street and a few shops on the corner that I want to visit today.<n><n>### Response - Write a sentence that describes 3 of the options below.<n><n>## Input <n>A: Sheryl is looking for a house and she is not sure if she wants to live in town or in the country.<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>It means Sheryl does not know if she is going to move into the city or live in the country. She will go somewhere.<n><n>### Output <n>Sheryl is looking for her first house and does not know if she wants to live on the country or in town.<n><n>### A. Sheryl is looking to find her first house.<n><n>### B. She does not know if she prefers a country house or a town house.<n><n>## Input<n><n>A: Sheryal is looking for her first job.<n><n>### Choices<n><n>### A: Working for a small or a big company.<n><n>### C: Getting an office job or an outside job.<n><n>## Input Rationales<n><n>If someone wants to find their first job, they are applying for their first job.<n><n>This job search covers all the job options. They can also search for any kind of job in the company, it is not limited to outside work or in an office.<n><n>### Sheryal is considering a

First, install the `git` command using `pip`.<n><n>    pip install git<n><n>Next, create a Git repository for these challenges. You will need a Repository Hosting Service like GitHub, GitLobby, or Bitbucket. Create an account at one of the three hosts and create a repository using the Python folder as the directory.<n><n>    git init.(initializes the Git repo in your current directory)<n>	git add. <n>	git commit -m "initial commit"<n><n>## Next Challenge<n>The next challenge can be found at [challenge 01](https://jellyfish.ai/challenge/python/01/README.md).<n><n>## Questions<n>You can ask questions about any part of Jellyfish on [our forum](https://discuss.jellyfish.ai/) or on the [Discussion Channel in Slack](https://jellyfox.slack.com/archives/C348MNV75)<n><n>---<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy tickets at a ticket booth for games/ Choices:  A: train station B: cathedral C: metro station D: fairgrounds E: amusement park<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>input:  How many students were in Ms. Ramirez’s class on the first day of school?<n><n>### Response : 120<n><n>Input The number needed to get a majority on a jury is ten<n><n>### <n><n>###<n>### Input: A carpet installer was paid the first 50% of the job, and then was paid the last 40% of the job. She was paid $350 more than the total. How was the carpet installer paid for the job?<n><n>Input: 1103+p+518=1621  1090+225+465=1780<n><n>###<n><n>###<n>

The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: home B: hardware store C: home D: hot room E: office<n><n>### Response:		The most appropriate answer is A because there can't be a fan anywhere else that satisfies both the given criteria of cool climate and the required location.<n>```<n>Choice:A<n>```<n><n>### Input If somebody likes temperatures hot, they might have more<n>            than one electric fan where Choices:A: homeB:<n>            hardware storeC: homeD: hot roomE: office<n><n>## RESPONSE<n>The most appropriate answer is D because there can't have a fan in a home or office, and the temperature in a hardware store can't be either hot or cool.<n><n>```<n>Choice:D<n>```<n>

The words <<horrible>> and <<horribly>> are not what? words or what? words?<n><n># Conclusion<n>- The correct word that is used to indicate that something is small or little is <<little>><n>- The correct word for something that is large is <<big>><n>- The correct words for a lot of something are <<many>> and <<much>><n>- The correct spelling is <<I>> and <<you>><n>- the correct spelling is <<there>> not <<their>><n>- The correct answer to the question <<what can be thrown away is garbage>>, because there is something called a garbage can, that is where you throw away your trash (aka garbage)<n>- We can say <<What are they doing? >><n>- The correct response to the prompt was <<What can be thrown away is their garbage?>><n>- The correct response was <<What time of day is it at night time.>><n>- The correct sentence structure is <<I like my dog>><n><n>### Final output<n>

A bay is the name given to each small section of the shed dedicated to keeping certain machinery. Carpentry shops have different areas that are used for the same thing. They have a garage that is used for storing equipment. Carpentry sheds are like a garage for carpenters.<n>

Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n><n>### Response:		OverPriced<n><n><n>### Input :<n>```Java<n><n>for(int x=1; x<10; x++){//for loop<n>if(isPrime(x)){<n>    System.out.print(" " + x + " ");<n>    }<n>}<n><n>System.out.println();<n>```<n><n>### Response :<n>```Java<n>for(int x = 1; x <10; x++){<n>    if(isPrime(1)){///first if statement of inside loop<n>        System.out.print(1);//print out value of 1<n>        System.out.println("is a prime number");<n>        }<n>        <n>    if(isprime(2)){//second if of inside loop <n>         System.out.print 2;<n>         System.out.println();//print out value of prime number<n>         }<n>    }<n>}//Close for loop<n><n><n><n>System.out.print(" ");<n><n><n>```<n><n>## Instructions: Input the Java statements below.<n><n>### Response<n>```Java<n>class Bookstore <br/> <n>{<br/><n>    char bookType; <br/><n>    int numberOfCoys;<br/><n> <br/><n> int totalCost(char,int);<br/><n> <BR/> <br/><n> public static void main() <br/> <n> {<br/><n>    System.out.println(new Bookstore().totalCost('N',5));<br/> <n>    System.out<<System.out.println(new Bookstore.totalCost('F',2);<br/><n>}<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Output:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Find out the input and print out the output.<n><n>### Input for Output:<n><n><n>### Result:<n>```Java<n><n>class Solution_01<n>{<n>    int sum=0;<n><n>    static int findClosest(int[] arr, int current, int x) {<n>        if(x-current<0) return x;<n>        if(x>current) return current;<n>        int i=current;<n><n>        while(i<arr.length&&arr[i]+1-x>=0){<n>            System.out.println("int i=
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is the hope of playing sports without competition? Choices:  A: running B: have fun C: balls touch D: winning E: get tired<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n>##### 1. Choose an answer above.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>##### 2. Provide a rationale for your answer in the first-person narrative below.<n><n>Due to pandemic many sports events are canceled. I don’t know what is the hope if people wants to play sport but there are no competition. I can’t run with my favorite ball because I don’t know where it go. I can’t play volleyball with my cousin because she doesn’t live in the same town.
