Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:James chose to not to print the cards, because he wanted to be more personal. What type of cards did he choose, instead? Choices:  A: cursive writing B: hand writing C: store bought D: online media E: hand written<n><n>### Response:		<n>The type of cards James will choose is B: hand written cards<n>The reason is because he wanted to be personal.  And hand written cards is one of the options for expressing personality.<n><n>###Input:Between what two integer values, x and y, does the 6th digit in the number 23262392326326232626326 differ from the 7th digit?<n><n>###Response:<n>Between what two values, x and y the difference between 6th and 7th digit in 2326 2326<n><n>### x: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12<n><n>### y: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9<n><n>### x > y<n><n>### The 6th digit is 2. The 7th digit is 1.<n><n>### Hence, answer: 6<n><n>### input:If Jody has 160 items of clothing, then how many items do she need to have the exact same number as her grand total?<n><n>### Response<n><n>If Jody has 60 items, then she needs to have the exact same amount of items.<n><n>### <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What can go on a football field? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: university C: college campus D: players E: yard<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input<n>> What are the first two letters of the alphabet?<n>><n>> Choices: A: b B: c C: d D: e<n><n>> B: c<n><n>### Summary:<n>### Input:Give a letter.<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instructions:<n>#### 1. Find a list of 5 letters<n><n>#### 2. Choose the first letter in the list.<n><n>#### 3. Choose the second letter in the list. It is not the first letter.<n><n>## Questions<n>- Which letter is the third letter?<n>- I want to give answers for this task.<n>- Write instruction for this task.<n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What will telling many people about an embarrassing situation lead to? Choices:  A: notoriety B: emotional distress C: riot D: bad dreams E: annoyance<n><n>### Response:		Option B<n><n>### Comment:<n>- If many people got told about an embarrassing moment(a,b), there's a big chance some of that people will feel bad, emotional distress<n><n>[Reference image](https://photos.app.goo.gl/8a5UeXkjEUhXLmY86)<n><n>### Instructions: Select the response with the most specific evidence.<n><n>Input: When Pablo was a boy, his mother bought lots of candy. Pablo ate a piece of candy every day.<n>The candy she bought didn't get eaten fast enough and it ended up becoming stale.<n>The candy came in bags of 24 pieces of candy. If Pablo ate one piece of candy each day, how many bags of candy did he eat?<n><n>Rationales: Pablo ate 24 pieces of candies on each bag, since 24 means he eat on bag each day, and he had 24 bags eaten on<n># 24 x 24<n># 24²<n># 576<n>#### 576<n>Answer: 576<n><n>### Instructoins:Choose the verb form that best completes this sentence.<n><n>Input: The bus arrived at the train station at 11:30 and a few minutes later a  train arrived.  The bus and the train departed at the same time.<n><n>Rationales : A few minutes later means at<n><n># 11.30 + a few minutes later = 11.36<n># 11:36<n># hour<n># the<n>#### hour<n>Answer: hour<n><n>### Input :Read and answer. How old are many of the children?<n><n>### Choices : A: 14 years old. B: 20 years old<n><n>### Rationales:<n>A)<n>3.5 divided by 3.5 = 1<n>There are 3.5 children on average, and each child is 1.<n><n>### B)<n><n>### Response 2:<n>3.5 divided  by 3.5=1/2<n>There are 3 children per family; each of them is older than 18 years old, which goes into the second half, or 10.5, meaning 3.5.<n><n>Rational:<n>Numb: B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Instrusions:<n>For each of the following questions, choose the most reasonable explanation according to the given information.<n><n>###  Input 1.<n><n>```<n>A father tells his son to clean out the garage to help the girlfriend clean it. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What could a balalaika be needed for? Choices:  A: artist junkyard B: music store C: singing D: symphony E: orchestra<n><n>### Response:		The balalaika is an instrument often used in Russian folk music.<n><n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple answer choice question.<n><n><n>### Demnstration<n>Input: The difference between Jack’s age and the product of 7 and his age is 21.  If Jack is 3 times as old as his father, find Jack’s age.<n>Rationales: Jack is 3 times older than his father, so Jack is 3\times100 = <<3*100=300>>300 years old.<n>His age minus the age of his father is 300 - 21 = <<300-21=289>>289<n>His age is 289<n>#### 289<n>Answer: 289<n><n>Input: The answer to the equation 2/5 * (5 + x) = 11 is:<n>Rationales: We are trying to solve 2/5 * 5 + x = 11<n>2/5 * 10 = <<2/5*10=20>>20<n>5 + x = <<5+x=15>>15 and that equals 16.<n>So 2/5 * x = <<2/5x=4>>4<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>#### Instructions:Answer each question for the following sequence:  [1,3,6,9,30,...]<n><n>**How many integers are there in this sequence?**<n><n>**What is the sum of the integers?**<n><n>**Is the sum of the sequence odd or even?**<n><n>**If the sequence was reversed, would the sum of the sequence still be the same?**<n><n>Answer: The sequence is: [1,3,5,8,17,...]<n><n>There are 9 integers in the sequence. <n><n>The sum of the sequence is 24.<n><n>The sum is even.<n><n>Reversing it would change the answer to: [17,8,5,3,1] and change the sum to 38 which is still even.<n>#### 9<n><n>#### 24<n><n>#### 2<n><n>#### Instruactions:Answer the
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is the worst outcome of an injury? Choices:  A: cause death B: cause bleeding C: falling down D: become infected E: claim insurance<n><n>### Response:		I think the worst part of an injury has to be bleeding. If an accident or injury is serious, the victim may bleed so much that it can lead to death. Even if the victim does not bleed to death, it is dangerous for a person to bleed a lot because the loss of blood can cause the person to pass out, get dizzy, go into shock, or other serious health complications.<n><n>#### Correct<n>Answer: "Bleeding"<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The following passage describes some changes that take placed in the life spam of a family. Choices:  A: interesting B: fun C: joyful or painful D: very important E: free<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I would change the learning process to being more painful when someone doesn't like learning. The main reason why I said that is, that when someone learns painful things then they will do all what it takes to avoid that pain. Therefore they will never learn. For example, if the learning process is fun then the students will probably not learn. On the contrary, if they learn something that brings them pain, then they will always think about learning that to keep themselves out of the pain. Thus, when someone does not like learning, they need to have more pain when learned.

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What could contain no more than around 100 people? Choices:  A: apartment B: classroom C: buildings D: car E: audience<n><n>### Response:		A<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:In what place could you find air that has been breathed by only a few people recently? Choices:  A: train station B: house C: cupboard D: cricket stadium E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In places like a car, trains, a bus, an airplane, or a building, you may find air has been breathed by all the passengers or the people who lived or worked there.<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>Input: Which two people are in your group?<n><n>#### Input:<n>```input<n>Which two people are in your<n>group?<n>Answer:<n>```<n><n>### Response 1:<n><n>```<n>Which two people<n><n>are in your group?<n>```<n><n>Output:<n><n>```<n>Jill, Peter<n>```<n><n>Input: There are 56548 customers at the store. Choices:  A: bus stop B: street corner C: roadblock D: fast food drive thru E: city<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n>```<n>This solution gives all possible letters of the alphabet, not necessary in order A-Z.<n>```<n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n>```<n>This solution returns nothing, as it is in the wrong letter format.<n>```<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n>```<n>This solution is correct, as it returns a string with the word STOP on it as the correct answer.<n>```<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n>```<n>This solution only returns the words FASTFOOD DRIVE THRU, not necessarily in order.<n>```<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n>```<n>This solution correctly returns the words CITY and STREET CORNER, in that order.<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Below is a task description. Write a response that is suitable to the task description.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>```<n>Which of these best describes how you feel during summer?<n><n>    A: The summers are hot, dry, and long with a short winter.<n>    B: The summers are short, and colder with a long winter.<n>    C: The summers are long, and hot with cold, wet winters.<n>    D: The summers are warm and short but the winters can last quite long.<n>```<n><n>#### A<n>Answer : A<n>The summers are hot, long, and dry with a short winter. D can't be the answer because it's a 9, not a 7, and C because the winters would be cold but not short.<n>#### B<n>Answer : B<n>The summers are short, cool and damp with a long winter. You could have a short summer and a short winter and have a cool, damp climate. You can't have a summer that lasts too long and also too long a winter. You could have "short, cool and damp summers" but "short and cool with no winter" can't be right.<n>#### C<n>Answer : C<n>The summers are long, hot and wet with a short winter. B and D can't be answered because their temperatures would need to be colder and D's winters would need to be longer. A's summer heat would need to be hotter and its summer would need to be longer too, but the winter would need a hotter, longer
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What appliance uses water and soap? Choices:  A: washing machine B: space shuttle C: blender D: disneyland E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		A: washing machine<n><n>### Instructions: The appliance that uses water and soap must be a washing machine. If water and soap are not used in other appliances, then B and D are wrong. If wash detergent and a washing machine are in the room and you have not seen a washing machine and you have not seen wash detergent, then A is the answer.<n><n>### Input and Processing:<n><n>### Instuctions: Choose one of the following ways to answer the question.<n><n>## ✔︎ **Choices:** -If an appliance uses water and other appliances do not use water, then it is a washing machine.-If an appliance does not use water and soap and other appliances use water and soap, then it is a space shuttle.-If an appliance uses soap, then it is the blender.-If an appliance is a space shuttles and it does not use water, then you will find it outside.-If an appliance needs money, then it is the disneyland.<n><n><n>## ✔✔✔ **If an appliance uses appliances that use water and soap, and the appliance does not, it is C.**<n>## ✔✔ If an appliance does not need money, it is E. If an appliance needs money then it is C. If it needs water and soap, it is B. If it needs water, it is E. -If water does not need soap and appliances need water, it is A. If appliances need water and water needs soap, it is D. -If appliances need water but it is not in washing machines, it is B.-While a space shuttle does not use water and it does not need water, but a washing machine uses water and soap, the washing machine is A. If appliance needs water, then it is C. -If an appliance needs water and it does not use appliances that use soap and water, the appliance is C.<n><n>### Rationales: If an appliance is the disneyland and the disneyland needs money, the appliance is disneyland.<n>

Choices:  A: sadness B: happiness C: amusement D: losing money E: anger<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>15+50+20+4=<<15+50=65>>65<n>```<n><n>### In the question above, answer the question without calculation.<n><n>### Input and Processing the Input:<n><n>```<n>If Richard is 32 years old now and the difference in ages to him and Hurley is 18 years, what were their combined ages 15 years from now? Hurley is 15 years old now.<n>```<n><n>##### Solution1:<n><n>```<n>Richard=32(Richard is 32 years now).<n>Hurley=15(now he is 15 years).<n>Hurley-Richard=18(difference in ages is 18)<n>S+O+Y=55(solution), so:<n>S + S+Y=55+15+18<n>(S+S+Y)=55<n>55=63<n>S=18<n>S-Y=18-55<n>18-55=20+18<n>18=43<n>O+T=25<n>25=48<n>T-O=48-25<n>23=43(T-O)=Ratio of 43:23=Ratio=1<n>T=23<n>```<n>23=Y+S<n>Y=16<n><n>##### The Solution2:<n>Since Richard is 32, so Hurley is 16(16-18=Richard-Hurley=3-18=3).<n>Richard is now 32 so it means Hurley is 11(18-16=Richard-Hurtley=3).<n>Richards is now 32 and Hurley is 30(Richard -Hurley-1=Richard-3=30).<n>20+10=Thirty two years combined from now,  So  it equals to 20+10+1=31<n>So since 31=Richard+Hurley it means  that Richard and Hurley are 31 years combined now.<n>Their ages from now combine to 31<n>Richard = 32<n><n>So 32

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Riding bike through rough terrain can be dangerous, one could find themselves what? Choices:  A: pleasure B: accident C: get somewhere D: hurt E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		Pleasure is not dangerous. Since riding a bike is not always dangerous.<n><n>### Input : A father needs to buy a shirt for his son. He knows they have 12 shirts of $15, 12 shirves of $20, and 1 shirt of $25.<n><n>### Question: How much does each shirt cost?<n><n>### 12 shirtes of 15<n>### 1 shirte of 25<n>### 20 shirtes of $20<n><n>### Answer : 15 + $20 + $25 = $50<n><n>### Rationale : Since he doesnt have 25 to buy a shirt at the total of 25 the price of a shirt with not be 25 but would be less because he still has all the other items left like the $15 and the $20 each shirt would equal the $15<n><n>### Input 3 teachers, students, and 30 hours<n><n>Rationale: She wants to spend $60 and there are 3 each that is $20, the teacher spent $60<n><n>### Output 10<n><n>* Question:The bus travels at 60 miles per hour for 1 hour. How far did she travel?<n><n>### Input Question<n><n>### Rationales 60 miles/60 miles/1hour.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Question <n>Harper needs to buy teacher apreciation gifts. Her son has 3, daughter has 4. If she spent $78 on 7 gifts how much did each gift?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Rationle Answer<n><n>### 78 / 7 = 11 each<n><n>### Instructions:<n>- A man earns $8 per hour<n>- he works 8 hours<n>- he makes $16 per day<n><n>- how much does he earn per week?<n><n>- Answer: $64
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where does a spoon go on one side of a plate? Choices:  A: bowl of soup B: serving dish C: table setting D: placemat E: glass of iced tea<n><n>### Response:		A: bowl of soup  <n><n>#### 5<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input : What does a snake and a fish have in common? Choices: <n><n>### Response : They both have teeth <n><n>#### 50<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input - What is the relationship between 1956 + 1979 and 1925 +2020? Choices:<n>G: they end with the same number<n>H: they are divisible by the sum of their digits <n>I: they are divisible into the sum of their digits<n>J: they are divisible to the sum of their digits plus 20<n><n>#### 100<n>Answer: G<n><n>### Input.A class is selling their baked goods on Saturday. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: infect B: reproduce C: mutate D: eat food E: make computer malfunction<n><n>### Response:		I'll give the right answer with the explanations. My answer is D. A virus invades a persons computer system by first infecting and then reproducing itself. When a virus infects a persons computer system, it enters the computer and then changes the computer system to start reproducing more of itself. Once a computer system is infected, the computer system will start to run slowly and other problems may start to occur. Another thing that a virus does is eat up the computers memory or computer hard drive memory. A virus can do all of this by eating the memory of the computer hard drive. A virus first infects by entering the computer, second, it reproduces, third, it multiplies or eats up the computer hard drives memory to replicate or to eat up the hard drive memory to grow, and last, it makes the computer slow or cause computer errors.<n><n>### Input : What are three things that can cause a computer to slow down?1. One thing that causes a computer to slow down or have problems is a virus or virus software. I think that a virus causes a computer to slow or have a problem because once a virus gets in a computer it will start eating up the computer memeory or hard drive memory to grow and if many viruses are in one computer then the computer might slow down a little bit but not so much because it has to slow down a little to where its not too slow. Another thing that could cause a computer to slow is having too many applications installed on one computer, and the last thing could be that if the computer hard drive or memory does not have enough space and has too much data such as many pictures and not enough hard drive it will slow a computer system in many different ways such as make it slow as much as it could be slow.<n><n>### [Instruction Answer]: A computer can slow down or cause errors for many different reasons such as the operating system gets slow, and it can happen if there is a hardware issue or the software is not good then it could slow

What time does school end if school started at [5 o'clock]? Choices:9 o'clock5 o'clock3 o'clock10 o'clock<n><n>### Response<n>If school started at [5:00][5:00], then school ends at [5:05] [5:05], and if school started at [8:00][8:00], then it ends [8:05] [8:05].<n><n>### Demomstation:<n>If school started at 5:00, then the time it ends is 5:05.<n><n>### Explanation<n>If school started at five o'clock then it ends five minutes later at [5:06] [5:06].<n><n>### Expplanation:<n>If [8].00 started school, then [14:05][14:05] would be the end time<n><n>### Instutution:<n>Answer the following muliple choice Question<n><n>---<n><n>

How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What are ai machines known for doing? Choices:  A: fly B: milk cows C: eat D: answering questions E: fail to work<n><n>### Response:		<n>If Milking Cows was the answer:<n><n>If Eating was the answer:<n>```python<n>import random<n><n>milks = '3960001'<n>machines = '2070001' and '2069001'<n>cows = '3955991'<n><n>"""<n>Because the question had an A, you should answer the remaining A, C, E, B, D.<n>If machine A is A, the remaining choices become B, D, E, C, A (in any order, except B then D and E)<n>If machine B is answer for C, D, E, B, choose C until you reach machine A. Then choose D.<n>If machine C is A, D, E, continue by answering each for rest until you reach E.<n>Once you reach E, continue by answering B, D, E for rest.<n>After that, continue by answering A, C, E for rest. Ends the process because the last machine A is already answer.<n>If machine E is E, end the program as it is the end of the program.<n>If machine D is C, E, D, B in any order, choose C until you get D.<n>If machine D was D, end the program.<n><n>"""<n>```<n><n>### Process (Input/Expected Output) with Python<n><n>### What machines are known for doing?<n>Answer: Milking Cows<n><n>### Choose the answer that accurately conforms to the given rules:<n>```python<n>if milks == '396039603' and machines == '207030703' and cows == '201030103':<n>    print('Milking Cows')<n>else:<n>    print('Milk Cows')<n><n>if milks =='396038900' and machines =='197020' and cows =='21002840':<n>    print('Eating')<n>else:<n>   print('Milking Cats')<n><n>if milKS == '1990312000' and machines is '20102990' and cows is '2108141
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:People are purposefully harming others, what trait are they exhibiting? Choices:  A: deceptive B: altruistic C: stupid D: cruel E: agressive<n><n>### Response:		<n>A)<n><n>Input:<n>There's a new place that has recently opened for lunch that I've been wanting to check out. It's called, 'Flying Pig' and they have an unlimited fries and coleslaw bar. It's $10.00 so, if you order just a sandwich it's $7.00 + tax.<n><n>1. I would suggest ordering with your friend and then ordering your own meal. That way, you can still split that meal after you pay for it. If you want to order lunch for yourself, order your own meal and add the 'extra side of flies' because that's only $3.00 and the regular meal price + tax is $10.0<n><n>Answer: Order two sandwiches with your friend, add a'side of fries' and add the 'extra fries' to save $4.00.<n>2. I would suggest getting the fries for free because the total is only $10.0 + tax.<n>```python<n>sandwich = 'Sandwich with fries'<n>Flybar = 'Extra Fries for $4'<n>Flytray = 'Side fries' + 'Extra fries'<n><n>if Flytray in 'Flybar' or Flybar in 'Flytray':<n>print('Free Flys')<n><n>else:<n>print('$14.0 total')<n>```<n><n>### Answer:<n>Order two sandwiches with a friend and add a 'Extra Side fries' and add 'Extra Flies' to save $4<n><n>Answer: Order one sandwich with a friend and add'side of fries & 'Side of Extra-Flies'.<n>### Answer:  Order two sandwiches and one fries with a friend and add the 'Extra flies' which will save you $4.<n><n>### Answer<n>Order one sandwish and one fries with friend and add the 'Side of Extra flies' which has the fries free and save $5 from the total bill<n>### Instruction<n>A 100 lb barrel of apple juice costs $40.00 and can be filled 10% of the volume with water without affecting the price. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The person is laying on the beach, why would he do that? But for the calculation it should be 2 + 3 <n>### Instruc:<n>- Fill in the correct pronoun for the sentence.<n><n>- I like these shoes.<n><n>- ______ likes these shoes.<n>		<n>		<n>- It is fun.<n><n>- It looks like fun.<n>		<n>### Answers<n>I<n>The correct answer is 'I'. The pronoun for sentence 2 should be 'I' and not 'it'.<n><n>### Instrac:<n><n>1. The car is covered with snow. 2. The car was covered with snow.<n><n>3. We are going to eat together tonight. 4. We ate together last night.<n><n>5. The teacher has a blackboard. 6. The teacher had a blackboard.<n>	<n>### Answer: <n><n>1. The correct answer for sentence #1 is S + H (Present Perfect Continuous). <n>While for sentence #2 the correct answer is SH +ing (Past Participle+ing)<n><n>2. The correct answer for Sentence #3 is SH+ have. (present perfect + have)<n><n>3. The correct answer for #4 is SH + had. (Present Perfect + had)<n><n>4. The correct answer for#5 is SH

D is actually the opposite<n><n>### Input 2:If your grandfather is 4 times your age, how old is your grandfather? Choices: A: 4 B:16C:103  D: 62E:11<n><n>### Response 2: A<n><n>### Rationales: The age of the grandfather is 4 * <<4*=4>>4 times the age of the kid or 4 times 4 = <<4*4=16>>16<n><n>### Input : If a person with a 45-minute commute saves every penny of the 71% of their cost of living that is not paid for by the employer,  and invests all of this money (ignoring earnings) at 6%,  when will total assets equal total salary? Choices: B: 6 years C: 8 years D: 9 years E: 13 years<n><n>### Response : D<n><n>### Rationle: If the person is saving every penny, then the person has to cut off some of the cost, say $5, leaving a remaining salary of $6.50. Then the person can invest that 71% and the remaining $5 at 19.5% at 6%. So the math is $6.25*19.5% +$5*6%.<n><n>### Then use the formulas 6.25(19.5%/2)+5*(19.5%)=0.455/2+5*6.5% = <<19.5/2+19.5%=9.8>>9.83<n><n>Then use the formula 9.83%*6= <<9.8*6=60>>60 times by 71% to get the total assets, and we get 0.6*60=<<60*6=360>>360 times.<n><n>### So, the person needs to earn $360 to cover the remaining 30.5% cost of living.<n>### So, at 6

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would a ficus plant brighten up a room? Choices:  A: middle east B: palace C: dictionary D: pots E: apartment<n><n>### Response:		<n>You should select the letter marked [C]<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Because of the following words in the options, "Middle East", "Palace" "Dictionary", "Pots", "Apartment"<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>c<n><n><n>#### c <n><n>### Input : Which of these pictures shows the best example of shading?<n><n>### Response : Choose D<n><n>### Rationales: <n><n>### Answer :<n><n>### Input - Find, as indicated by the letter, the term in the figure that matches the term in the sentence.<n><n>### Response - Choose option a.<n><n>### Ratiionale -<n><n>### Answer -<n><n>#### a <n><n>### Question 1:<n><n>### Input – ___ in the figure is missing the middle triangle<n><n>### Response – Choose B, because it is a parallelogram.<n><n>### Answer –<n><n>#### b <n><n>### Which of these drawings represents a right triangle?<n><n>### Input<n>If it's a right triangle, then it should be the one that's right next to it. So answer to be A<n><n>### Ration:<n><n><n>### Question -<n><n>### Input Answer -<n><n>### Rules:<n>Because it is a triangle, it should be in the top most box. So answer to be <n><n>#### d <n><n>### Choose the correct term for the picture shown<n>C, because the picture should look the way the figure in the box is drawn.<n><n><n>### Rule -<n><n>When you draw in the middle of the triangle. It has only two triangles, hence no middle.<n><n>### Question and Ration -<n><n>### Choice -<n><n><n>#### c<n><n>### Which shape in the diagram is a parallelopgm?<n><n>### Rate -<n><n><n><n>### Answer and Question -<n><n><n>#### d 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The other passengers on the bus were quite loud, so he put on his headphones to relax and what? Choices:  A: go to bed B: sleep C: listen to music D: stretch out E: stop worrying<n><n>### Response:		D: stop worrying<n> <n>### Instruction::Answer the following multiple choice problem.<n>### Demontration:<<The driver was too fatigued to drive.>>The driver was too fatigue to drive. <<The car stalled unexpectedly.>>The car stalled unexpected. <<She was too busy to listen to the bus driver.>>She was too busy to lest to a bus driver. <<The lights did not work.>>They did not work. <<The brakes did not work.>><n>The brakes did not worked.<n>Forty years is forty years ago. >>Forty years ago is forty years ago. <<He arrived forty years early.>>He arrived forty years early.<<She did not get her passport yet.>>She did not go her passport yet.<n> <n>### Answers<n>11536<n>> 2 7<n>8512<n><n># Day 8<n> <n>### Go to https://math.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/12626/mathjax-in-comments<n> <n>### [comment] 10 - (10x + 2)/(-x2 + x + 5)<n><n><n>### [comment -] 10 - ((10x + 12)/((-x2 + x + -5)))

Write a program that determines if the string is a palindrome or not. A palindrome is a string that reads the same forwards as it reads backwards. Input is expected to be valid C++ strings.<n>The code you write should take the input string, traverse the characters, and print whether it is a palindrome. Output format is either true or false after it is completed.<n>String myString = "racecar";<n>```for (int i = 0; i < myString.size(); i++){<n>      if (myString[0] == myString[i] && i < 3){<n><n>        cout << "true";<n>      } else{<n>        cout << "false";<n>      }<n>```<n>#### true<n>Answer: true<n><n>### Instructuion:Determine if the supplied string is a vowel.<n>Input: string = "raceca"<n><n>### Response:'e' is a vowel but 'raceca' isn't<n><n>### Input(String): The string has not been specified<n><n>### Rationales:'e' is a part of the string and it is a vowel<n><n>### Input (String): str = "raceca" or even str = "racecaac" str = "race" are not valid inputs<n><n>### Answer: vowel is 'e'<n><n>### Instractions:Write a program that takes as an input two integers, a and b. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would a ticket help you to get to a different country? Choices:  A: train station B: baseball stadium C: lottery D: movie E: bus<n><n>### Response:		Choice B: baseball stadium or D: movie<n><n>### Instructions: In the chart, we have given you the dimensions in inches of three different rectangles. E: Leaves fall less often than birds fall.<n><n>### Response; C<n><n>###Rationales:In the process, any number of leaves fall and every branches has the same chance of falling. Choices:  A: to be heard B: receive gifts C: understand themselves D: good things in life E: acknowledgment<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- A: to be heard<n>- B: receive gifts<n>- C: understand themselves<n>- D: good things in counseling<n>- E: acknowledgment<n>Answer: (Choose all the answers that apply.)<n><n>### Input:"The sun rises in the East."<n><n>### Rationale:<n>From the text:<n><n>"The sun rises in East.  It must be true."<n><n>"The Earth goes around the sun."<n><n>"I am sure the Earth goes around the sun.  Therefore, the sun rises in the east."<n><n>- The Sun goes around the Earth. <n><n>- Since 'The Earth goes around the Sun', it must be true.<n><n>- The earth goes around the Sun, the sun goes around the earth, and then the earth goes around the Sun again, in the east.<n><n>- The sun rises in the Eastern direction.<n><n>- It seems it must be true that the sun rises in East, thus must be true that the Earth goes around the Sun.<n>- Because the earth goes around the sun, the sun must go around the earth thus the earth going around the sun would mean that the sun had to go around the earth which means that the earth must go around the sun, the earth goes around the son. <n><n>- Because it is true that the sun rised from the east in the morning, then it must be true that Earth goes around the Sun..<n><n>- The sun goes around the Earth.<n>- Since the Earth goes around the Son, the Son must go around the Earth.<n><n>- Since the Earth is revolves around the Son and the Son revolves around the Earth, the Son is the Earth.<n><n>The earth revolves around the sun, the son revolves around the earth, the earth revolves around the son, thus the sun goes around the Earth<n><n>Answer:<n>It is not logical that the Earth goes around Sun simply for the Sun rises in the East. <n>- The Earth goes around the Sun because Sun is bigger than the Earth that is why the Sun moves faster than the Earth.<n>- When the Earth rotates, it is considered as the rotation of the Earth.<n>- However, it is not called rotation of Sun when the Earth orbits the Sun.<n>- An object that revolves around another object is called a moon if the object is less than half the size of

The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What might someone do who is having fun? Choices:  A: being happy B: glee C: smoke D: stress relief E: may laugh<n><n>### Response:		The answer to this question is: may laugh<n><n>Output:The difference in ages between Richard an Hurley is 2. If Hurley is two years old, what are the combined ages 40years from now.<n><n>### Input Choices: C: smoke D:stress relief E: may laug<n><n>### Output Choices: A: being happy B. glee C: smoke E: may laugh<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The old barn was beyond repair, they had to destroy it before they could what a new one? Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n><n>### Response:		I selected 'A' because this is the only one that made sense to me. I think 'Raise' and 'Entice' should be used in a different circumstance. I selected 'D' for the same reason.<n><n>### Input2:The old barn wasn't beyond repair, just some repairs were needed to fix it so they could use it as they what? Choices:  I didn't like any of these except option E 'they used'.<n><n>### Response2:I just picked 'use' because to me it's the least objectionable of all the other answers. I hate 'use' as a verb, but I was not going to pick the wrong answer option.<n><n><n><n>### Input3:The old barn had been beyond repair and they needed to have a new one built. What was the problem? Choices:  None that I liked.<n><n>### Response3:I didn't like any and I wasn't going to not answer. That would not impress me as a positive action. I picked 'None' and wrote it as a justification.<n><n>### Question: Which of the following answers is most likely to appear for a given question?<n><n>### Dem: I believe the answer is 'D', because I think they are all good answers but for very different reasons.<n><n>### A: A is probably not correct because I think 'Entice' should always follow 'Raise'.<n><n>### B: B sounds good, but it makes no sense to entice an animal or a person to jump up.<n><n>### C: C is ok, but it sounds a little wordy and doesn't offer up much information.<n><n>### D: D is ok, but this sounds a little more complicated compared to 'use'.<n><n>### E: E is the least objectionable, as suggested by you. But I still think 'use' and 'raised' could be used together as both are actions. And 'entice' could be used to raise an animal.<n><n><n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:They wanted to eat at home but the cupboards were barren, so they had to go what? What is the lowest age each player can be?<n><n>### Response The lowest age of each player cannot be less than 20 years old, because the average age is not the sum of every age, the sum is 50. The lowest age must be at least 25 years old.

The first period from three to twelve, the second period from twelve to eight. She has to go to bed at three which is an hour before her first possibility of morning shift. She will have to wake up at twelve and have her lunch after the work. Her work ends at eight. Which is nine to twelve. So, her entire shift will consist of nine hours of work.<n><n>### Insructions: Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### I: A boss tells her interns that if their work is less than 90%, they need to do more<n><n>### II: You are allotted three hours for a test. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Her average mileage isn’t affected because her car uses less gas going to work than coming home. If her car gets 17 miles per gallon, how much gas does she use each day?<n><n>### Response<n>Answer: 58.8<n><n>### Rationales<n>From our answer, if she only drives one way one day, then the average miles per gallon is the total multiplied by the total miles divided by 2<n>17 times 33 = <<17*33=583>>583 miles one way, so if she does that 1 time, that is 583 total miles<n>583 / 2 = <<583/2=291>>291 miles per day, twice to work and twice back<n><n>### The answer choices are E: read book, D: wash dish, C: ask questions, B: drop out of school, A: enter school,  so our answer would be C<n><n>### Rationale for the choice of C:<n>C: the other choices are all before going to school<n>A: She enters school in the morning<n>B: She drops out of school in the morning<n>D:She washes a dish at school everyday<n>E: She reads a book at school everyday<n><n>### Input and Rationales for Answer:What is 1 divided by 1/12?<n><n>### 2<n><n>### Explanation<n>2/3 = <<25/3=16>>16<n><n>### A woman earns $516 teaching one year and $504 teaching the next year. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:HOw do you carry potatos home? Choices:  A: grocery store B: grocery bag C: restaurants D: farmer's market E: bushel basket<n><n>### Response:		The answer is A<n>#### A:Grocery store<n><n>### Input What did the little red hen buy at the store?
