Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### D: truck<n><n>### Instructions: The table below lists various costs of building and shipping items. One customer has the choice of purchasing item A, item B, item C, item D, or item E. Their choice depends on the costs. For example, if they pick up item D, they spend $5 more than if they picked item A. What items are available, given their budget of $40 and the items that cost more to choose?<n><n>### Instructed Response:<n><n>#### E: train<n><n>Answer: Item D<n><n>### Inputs for response:<n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>#### D<n><n>### Instinctive Response:<n><n>### Input for response:<n><n>#### E<n><n>### Instudction:<n><n>#### E.<n><n>### Response to Instructed Response: The shipping cost on item A, item B and item C is $80, $100 and $120 respectively(Item A costs less to ship)<n>So in order to spend maximum on items A and C; item B must be the purchased item because item A's shipping cost of $80 is less than its total cost.<n>The sum of shipping costs for items A and B is; $80 + 40 = $(80 + 4) = $<<80+4=84>>84; <n>So the sum of cost (price+shipping) for these items is; $84+150 = $(84+15) = $<<84+15=100>>100; <n><n>The customer is only interested in the higher value of $120 so the items available based on the maximum budget of 100 are; E ($<<120>=120)>>120 and B (${84+15}=100)>>100.<n><n>The choices are:<n>E, A (120)<n>E (120) (40)<n>B (100) (40)(84 + 15),<n><n>### Instuitive Response:<n><n>#### A<n><n>### Instuidtive Response:<n><n><n>#### D<n>```<n>I think the correct one is, B.<n><n>###

(2) Choices:  B: 28 C: 48 D: 16 E: 5<n><n>### Response (A then B):<n>#### A<n>#### B<n><n>### Input (1) The distance between the closest coast of the United States and the second closest coast of the United State is A: 1500 miles B: 2100 miles Rationales (A) Choose 7: 67 Choices: Choose 7: A: 56 B: 11 C: 28 D: 32 E: 43 F: 75 G: 170 <n><n>#### A<n><n>```<n>1500-11=480 <n>```<n><n>### Input One question will ask you to perform operations using rational numbers. Rational numbers are numbers that can be written as a ratio (or fraction). Choose the answer that can be reduced to rational numbers, including fractions.<n><n>Answer: <n>#### A<n><n>#### B<n><n>#### C<n><n>```<n>17 > 5<n>```<n><n>#### D<n><n>```<n>-6 < 3<n>```<n><n>#### E<n><n>```<n>16 < -5<n>```<n><n>```<n>4<16<n>```<n><n>## Labs:<n>|lab 1|lab 2|lab 3|<n><n>### Name:<n>#### lab 1<n><n># lab 2 answers<n><n>#### lab 3 answers<n><n>### Name<n><n>### Score
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where might someone find old clothing? Choices:  A: trunk B: drawer C: suitcase D: book shelf E: washing machine<n><n>### Response:		<n>A) B) C) D) E)<n>

The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. They:  A: added<n>B: subtracted<n>C: reduced<n>D: multiplied<n>E: divided<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### D.Divided<n><n>### Rrationales:If they took the simple fraction first and got a fraction, then they would know the reduced answer before taking the mixed_number, so they would not need to add it (or subtract it). If they knew what the reduced fraction was, then they could easily divide to get the answer.<n><n>### Input<n>In math class, you found that you could cut 456 pencils into equal parts, using 11 pencils to equal 1 gram. Choices:  A: switzerland B: pennsylvania C: picture D: asia E: austria<n><n>### Response:		Choosing D, Picture<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the sentence below.<n><n>You may choose an answer from among the choices.<n><n>If $A$ is your selection for the first word in the sentence, then your choice for the second word must be ______.<n><n>#### A<n>This choice is $A$.<n><n>#### Picture<n>This choise is Picture<n><n>#### switzerland<n>This choice is switzerland<n><n>#### pennsylvania<n>This choice is pennsylvania<n><n>#### Austria<n>This choice is Austria<n><n>### Conclusion:Based on the above choices, which is the most logically correct answer.<n><n><n>### Answer:Based on the first word and second word, we can see that the sentence makes sense. We therefore must choose Answer C.<n><n>### In conclusion, which choice is the correct one?<n><n>Answer E<n><n>### Why?<n><n>Because Penandasia is the correct answer to the given question, even though choice D is Picture.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>Input: What eastern state is home to the mountain?<n><n>Choices: A: switzerland B : Penandasia C: picture D: Asia E: Austria<n><n>Example: Choosing E for picture, because the answer to the question 'What eastern state home to mountain' is Penandasia, and Penandasia has 8 letters, if you are selecting for E, choosing the word Picture, when is really is Picture, is very easy, so it has 8 letters.<n><n>### The last sentence of the example should read:<n><n>Choose Penandasia in this example for the letter Picture<n><n>### Example of sentence with missing piece:<n><n>Input: Find the missing piece of my name.<n>Choices: A : P_________ C: A_______________ E: J______________<n><n>Example for P: The correct choice would be Picture of J, and Picture has 8 letters<n><n>### Example 2:<n><n>Input: The letter is the third letter of my name.<n><n>Choices: {1/2/3/4/5}<n><n>{1} The correct choice would be Cause C is three<n><n><n>### Example Summary:<n><n>Choose Picture in this example for the piece A missing from the letter<n><n>### Example Conclusion<n><n>Based on the answer, you are

Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: medicine chest C: armpits D: grocery store E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		Choices: A, D<n><n>### Input and Request<n>The owner of a gas station said to a customer, “At each location on my driveway, my average cost of fuel was $2.24, my average cost of service was $2.50, and the total revenue (revenue from fuel + revenue from service) was $42,000.” Which of the following must be true?<n><n>### A.The average of the cost of fuel and the average of the cost of service is more than the average revenue.<n><n>### B.The total revenue is less than $16,800.<n><n>### C.The total revenue must be between $14,000 and $17,000<n><n>### D.The total revenue does not have to be between $14000 and $30000<n><n><n>### The owner of a gas station had the following numbers for each location on his driveway:<n><n>### 1. Average fuel cost = $2.80.<n><n>## # 2. Total revenue = $58,410<n><n>## 3. Average cost of service = $11.<n><n>## #	4. Average revenue per gallon = $2.29<n><n>## #	5. Total revenue in gallons =$25,927.<n><n>## #6. Average service fee per customer = $2.85<n><n>## #7. Total service cost = $50,376<n><n>### Which of the following must hold true?<n><n>## A. The average cost of fuel and service must be less than $21,689.<n><n>###B. The average cost of service per location must be $2.85 or more<n><n>C. The total profit is less than $50,360<n><n>###D. The average revenue per gallon must be greater than $2.80<n><n>## E. The total revenue must be less than $9,000<n>F. The average revenue must equal the average cost<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>##	Answer: The average cost of service must be equal to $2.30<n><n>### Justification:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Who sits at the center table at a receeption? Choices:  A: restorand B: wedding party C: church basement D: corridor E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		F: wedding party<n><n>### Input : The boss's assistant is a woman who likes to eat candy for lunch. She's 30 years old and only eats 1/3 of a pound for lunch. She does this every day of the week. On Saturday she eats the same amount of candy for lunch but she adds on an hour of television time. How many pounds of candy does she eat in one week?<n><n>### Response : A: One pound<n><n>### Inputs:Melinda is 2 years older than Lena. If Lena is 14, what are their combined age forty years later?<n><n>### Rationales : Melinda is 2 years more than Lena so the total between the two is 14+2 = <<14+2=16>>16<n>So 16+40 = <<40+16=56>>56<n>Their combined age forty years later is 56<n>#### 56<n>Answer : 56<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response that appropriately answers the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostrations:<n>#### Input:What did Harper buy for teacher's appreciation day?<n>Rationales : Teacher appreciation day is May 1st. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What prevents someone from getting sleep at night? Choices:  A: conference B: theater C: building D: floor E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Answer:   <n>C: building<n><n>### Rationales:   <n>C: Building is the answer because conference is used for business, thear is used for entertainment, building is used for business as well as entertainment, floor is used only for enterteinment, so building is a place that is for business and entertainment.<n><n>### Input : What is the smallest number possible for all the three addends in the subtraction sentence 0 - 1 + 3?<n><n>### Response : 0<n><n>### Rationale : Since 0 is the smallest, then 0 can be  the answer.<n><n>### Answer : 0<n>Rationales: 0 is the smallest number because if you are going from the least to the most, 0 is the least, therefore 0 would be the answer. <n><n>### Input  :<n>### Demonstoration : If someone wants to find their age by adding their age when they were born 5 years ago, they will take whatever their age has been in the last 5 years, add that amount to the number for their age before they were born and get their current age. If it is now current, subtract 5 to account for the 5 years it is older.<n><n>### Ratingnales : Add your age to what it would be before you were born if you are older than 3. <n><n>## Input : <n>## Demonstration : How many people is one person who is trying to learn a foreign language from a recording tape alone.<n><n>## Rationales : From one, you take 1 in 1000 and plug that value into the equation. <n>Therefore, 1/1000 = <<1/100=0.0001>>0.000(one tenth)<n><n>## Answer : 0.00006, or about 1/1,750,000. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The keys were black and white, what were they attached to? Choices:  A: front pocket B: cabinet C: purse D: chain E: piano<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input:[The keys were black and black]<n>[black: A black car]<n><n>### Input:(The keys were black and [black]: A black car]<n>[black: black car]<n><n>Answer:<n><n>### Instructions: What is the value of x?<n>![img](./src/assets/images/image4.png)<n>*Rationales*<n>x = 81<n>```<n>Answer:<n><n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Choices:  A: get tired B: have legs C: skip D: not fat E: look first<n><n>### Response:		Choice E<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: What do you need to run fast?<n>Choice A: Get Tired<n>Choice B: Have Legs<n>Choice C: Skip<n>Choice D: Not fat<n>Choice E: Look first<n><n>If you have strong, healthy, young legs, and you want to be a sprinter, you have to practice running as much as possible. There's a saying about all you have to do to run fast: L.I.T. (Leave It on the Track). In other words, if it hurts, don't stop. Practice makes perfect, even if you feel tired.<n><n>#### Choice A<n><n>Answer: E<n><n>#### Choice B<n>Answer: E<n>#### Choice C<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n>Input: Why does the lion lose the race when he is not even running?<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Question:<n>Input: Which set of numbers from 100 to 125 are prime number? Choices: A: All<n>B: None<n>C: 107<n>D: 111<n>E: 113<n><n>### Demstration:<n><n>#### Choice C:<n><n>Answer: The prime numbers in the range 100 to one hundred twenty-five (inclusive) are one hundred twenty-five, and one hundred thirty-three. (The next even prime is not 100.)<n><n>#### Choice E:<n><n>Answer: 111 is the only number with 11 digits that is a prime number: 23 31 51 01 11 23 39 47 113<n>There are no prime numbers that are 12-digit or higher. (Any odd number that is greater than 100 has at least three factors, so it cannot be a prime number.)<n><n>#### Choices A and B:<n><n>All numbers are prime, so there are no other prime numbers.<n><n>#### Choices D:<n><n>Answer: There are no prime numbers in the range from 111 to 125, excluding 111. (A prime number is greater than 1 if and only if it is odd.)<n><n>####

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Choices:  A: conduct trial B: arrest C: bring in verdict D: pass sentence E: serve justice<n><n>### Response:		<n>The judge would A conduct trial if the person would plead not guilty and would B arrest the person if he pleads guilty. Once the conviction arrives, judge will either C bring in verdict or D pass sentence, after which the person will serve justice.<n><n>### Input Choices A, B, and C would all be good responses. Choice D does not answer the question. Choice E is a good response if asked as part of a larger question.<n><n>## Scoring a CAT score:<n>- **Different**: CAT tests should measure your basic skills rather than your ability to perform a given task or process<n>    - Expect to see lots of data and a complex story <n>    - Example: you were given a spreadsheet describing various information, such as population and death rate of cities in another country, your job is to find out what percent of the population died <n>    - What you would be looking at: is the data valid?, are there things that should be done to improve the data, if so describe them, do the data indicate what we think?, if so describe reasons, if not explain your reasoning. <n>    <n>- You are looking for data and logical arguments. Make sure to describe these ideas with your comments.<n>    - Doing this will allow you to provide your answer and use your own knowledge to form a conclusion. <n>- **Informal**: don’t worry if your explanation does not end up being formal English. CAT uses the context of the question, if you are using the right vocabulary and describing concepts accurately, you will get credit for it. <n><n>

Find the speed of the point in the 6 o'clock position.<n><n>## Rationales:<n><n>### (12 + 3 + 18) ÷ 3 = 27 ÷ 3 = <<27/3=9>>9<n><n>### (9 + 6 - 27) ÷ 2 = 15 ÷ 2 = <<15/2=7>>7<n><n>### The point at 6 o'clock has speed of 7 miles per hour.<n><n><n>### (6 * 7) + 18 = <<6*7=42>>42<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Instructor:What is the difference between this example and the first example?<n><n>### Student:<n><n>#### 18 - 27 = 9 miles per hour at the 12-o clock position and 9 + 7 - 42 = <<9+7-42=(-3)=>>(-3) miles per hour at the six-o clock position.<n><n>#### 1. If you go to rug, you might be spreading disease, but it doesn'a matter because you cannot cure what you spread. Rug, ghost town, and human body are all places for animals, but not for humans, so A is wrong. B is also wrong, because third world countries are places where some people are rich and others are the opposite, and this is not where you should be spreading disease. D is wrong because even if you don't die, it will still get onto the rug where it cannot be taken.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A person notices popcorn, cotton candy on the grass, where is he likely? Choices:  A: feel pleasure B: look attractive C: compliments D: interesting experiences E: joy<n><n>### Response:		In this case, the person's likely goal is: A: feel pleasure<n><n>### Reason:  People may think that the beauty industry, makeup, and others of the same field is something that women just use for self-pleasure. It may be true that women would like to look their most beautiful or like a celebrity, but those things may just be the bonus of using makeup and not the main goal, at least not all the time, because women who only want to use makeup to feel pleasure could also be men, who also use makeup even though its beauty is secondary.<n><n>If it is men only, women are in a disadvantage since they have to do more to look beautiful.<n><n>If it's women only, they are in a disadvange because it will be harder to make makeup and the amount of beauty products might be in excess.<n><n>### Note: The person's likely goal above is written as one choice while below is written as two choices<n><n>### Instructions: Choose one of the possible words and fill in the blank.<n><n>### Example: Dad, can I pick up some ice cream? Choices:  A: shelf B: place of work C: desk D: office supply store E: school<n><n>### Response:		Place of work<n><n>### Input 2:What is 48% of 125?<n><n>### Rationales:The % tells us that this is a percentage problem.48% of 48 is 48*48 = <<48*48=2304>>2304<n>We know that we need to find 125% so we add it to itself 2304=125% so 2304/100 = <<2304/3=768>>768<n>#### 768<n>Answer: 768<n><n>### Input3:Selena had $0.76 to spend on a snack at the concession stand. Given that her snack must be over $0.25, how much can she spend?<n><n>### Answer: over $0.26<n><n>### Rationale:She needs to spend at least $0.25 because if she spends $0.25 then she'll have $0.51 left and she can spend that too.0.76>0.25<n><n>### Input4:After a weekend of watching movies, Jack and Jill had $11.10 in movie money collect. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Why shouldn't you walk barefooted after the rain? Choices:  A: shoes B: wet ground C: wet clothes D: start to fall E: water garden<n><n>### Response:		D:<n>####D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Why:Shoes B:  wet ground and wet clothes Choices: wet clothes will cause skin damage and wet ground is not comfortable for walking.<n><n><n>### Input The length of a rectangle is double its width. If its width is 6 cm and its length is 24 cm, what is its area?

The numbers 2, 6, 10, 14, 18, and 22 are multiples of what number? Choices: <n>A : 3. B: 4. C : 6. D : 5.<n><n>## Explanation : <n>\# D. 5. The multiples of 5 will be 5, 10,15,20,25,30,... and all these numbers have common factor of 5. Hence 5 is a multiple of 5.<n># E : \# D : The numbers 2,6,10,14,18,22 are multiples or 5

Choices:  A: house B: den C: family room D: wood E: floor<n><n>### Response:		<n>What should the bean bag couch sit on? A<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The choices are A (house), B (den), C (family room) D (wood) and E (floor).<n><n>Since the choices do not include a house, and the couch is a bean bag, we can eliminate the options.<n><n>Then, we can determine that since the couch is a couch, it can only sit on a floor or a wood.<n><n>Since the house and den are not floors or woods, we can discard them.<n><n>Then, family room and floor can also be eliminated because we have the floor chosen beforehand.<n><n>So the final options are A (den), and B (family room)<n><n>### The final question for today is:Why am I good at math?<n><n>### Rationale:<n>I'm good at math because I like math!<n><n>### Input/Response:<n>I'm a math teacher so I am good at math!

Choices: A: (x+5)/((2x+18)/2)=x B:x C:2 D:x+6 E:1<n><n>### Demstration:<n>Start with the first step: x = (x+5)/2<n>Add 5 to both sides: 2x+10 = x+10<n>Divide both sides by 2: 2x + 5 = x-5<n>Raise both sides to the power of 1/2: (2x+5) ½ = (x- 5) ½<n>Multiply by x to get: (2x+4) ½ = x-2 ½<n>Multiplying both by x gives (2x+4)(x-2 ½) = x-x = x<n>2x+4=x, 2x-4=x, 4=0 and now x+4=x+4 and x-4=x-4, so 6=0, and x+4 = x-4: x= -(4) or x= -4.<n><n>#### x = -(4) or x = -4<n>Answer: -(4) or x=-4<n><n>### Input:-22.5 divided equally into ten people gives $<<-22.5/10=2.25>> and $2.25 for one person.<n>How many people does it take to receive $0? (corresponds to c)  The koala is not an Australian animal, but actually from Africa, therefore the panda is the closest.<n><n>### Input The math test went downhill from there. (10/6) <sub><sup>10</sup></sub> B. (10/3) <sub><sup>(10)</sup></sub> C. ( 5/6) <sub>5</sub> <sub><sup>6</sup></sub> D. <sub><sup>5</sup></sub>(3 / 6) >sub>5(3/6)<n>### Response: <n>B. <sub>5</sup>(<sub>3/6</sub>) <n><n>---<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where was the apple tree said to contain something forbidden? Choices:  A: north carolina B: washington state C: nil D: great outdoors E: garden of eden<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales: The forbidden fruit was the apple in the Garden of Eden.<n><n>### Input Choice:A<n><n>### Input Answer: A<n><n>## <n>###### [ 19 questions left]<n>### Instruction - Multiple choice or short answer<n><n>```<n>Instruction:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions on how you would perform a task. For each task, choose from the options below.<n>```<n><n><n>### Input-Short Answer<n><n>Input: What was the name of Mr. Smith’s dog? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Billy's mother tripped over a stuffed animal.  She yelled at him not to leave his things where? Choices:  A: toy store B: hall C: bathroom D: amusement park E: fairgrounds<n><n>### Response:		Which choice is correct?<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Input<n>Billy’s grandfather has $x money. Billy’s grandmother has $x-8 money. Billy has $x-5 money. His brother has $x-7 money. His sister has $x-2 money. How much does each person have left when the amounts added together equal 31?<n><n>### Answer<n>The solution is X - (5 + 7 + 2) = 31 -- 5x7 = 5x3 - 4x7 = 1x3 - 4<n><n>### Input and Response:<n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>### Example:<n><n>### 65 / 0 =<n><n>65 ÷ 0 = ∞<n>

The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Who does the government help with schools? Choices:  A: school children B: parents C: get money D: require to pay taxes E: take money<n><n>### Response:		A<n>### Rationale:If the government helps schools, who do they help? A student would be the biggest beneficiary and since students are in school, they would not pay taxes. So the answer choice that requires you to consider who the schools help rather than who the government helps, is A because of its benefits for students.<n>```<n>Answer: School Childrens<n>```<n>### Input:Find the mean of the input. Choices:  A. 69.24969 B. 129.23883 C. 180.0 D. 231.19214 E. 338.12148<n>### Response:B<n>### Rationale:-69.24+231.18+129.24+180+180.23+68.19=<<-69.24-231.12-129.22-180-180.22-68.18=1320>>1320<n>The mean is 1320 / 6 = 220 or in scientific notation it is 132 ×10²+1.2 ×1.9 = <<132*10^{2}+1.2*1.9>>220.<n>The option that matches this number is B because the other options all have the same mean.<n>#### 220<n>Answer: 220<n>### Input:Which of the input data has the greatest mean? Choose: A. Daisies B. Roses C. Tulips D. Irises E. Lilies<n>### Response:D<n>### RationaleDaisies have a mean of 136.19, 550 roses have a mean of 53.08 per rose and 46 lilies have a mean of $46.27. Since 550 ros and 46 liles has the highest mean of 53 - 46.27 = <?550-46.27=83.73>>83.73, and we need the greatest, it is D.<n>#### 83
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Who designs a building? Choices:  A: builders B: driver C: architect D: fall down E: tradesmen<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is "A".<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question correctly.<n><n>### Rationals: The question is asking who is in charge of building a building, so the answer is "B" (builder).<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Input<n>|  Input |  Answer | <n>| :--- | :---: |<n>|A: builders B: driving | Correct Answer - "C" (Architect) |<n>|A: building B: drivers | Correct Answer - "A" (Builders) |<n>|A driving B: Building | Correct Answer - "D" (Fallen down) |<n>|A building B drivers | Correct - "E" (Tradesmen) | <n><n><n>### Input 2: The teacher asked if anyone had seen a car that was red and green, and nobody had.<n>I know it sounds impossible but I had one once.<n><n>### Correct Answer: "F" (no)<n><n># The question is asking if someone has seen a car that was both red and green, so the answer is False or "F"<n><n># Answer: Yes, I've had one!<n><n>### Input Input 3: Write a statement that is equivalent to: 2/4 < 6/10<n>1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The man on the street corner was showing off a wristwatch, he was trying to what it for drug money? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		Which word has the initials “S” and “H”?<n>*A: “Sammy wanted to go…”<n>*B: “Where might he go…”<n>*C: “Populated areas…”<n>*D: “Apartment…”<n>*E: “Sammy wanted t…”<n><n>```<n><n>### Input:(n)^2+8(n)+5<n>```<n>### Demonstaration:<n>n = 4<n>5 = 4 + 1<n>8 = 4 + 4<n>2 = 4 + 2<n>7 = 4 + 3<n><n>The sum of the three steps = (n^2) + 8n + 5<n>#### 24<n>Answer: 24<n>   <n>### Input: Which number should replace the question mark? (18 x 15) ___ 90<n><n><n>### Demostaration:<n>**Rationales**:<n>If (18 x 2) = 36<n>and 18 = 10 + 8<n>90 = 10 + ___ + 80<n>So, the replaceable number is 90<n>####80<n>Answer:80<n>       <n>### Input: Sam’s dog ate his homework! What two operations will help fix the problem? Choices:  E: multiply and divide H: add and divide I: add and subtract J: minus and divide<n><n>### Demstration:<n><n>Rationales: E: <<E= Multiply and Divide>>Multiply and divide<n>H: <<H= Add and subtract>> Add and subtract<n>I: <<I= Add and divide>>Add and divide<n>J: <<J= Subtract and divide>>Subtract and divide<n><n>#### Directional Question<n>### Input: What’s his next step if he wants to double his value?<n>### Demonstraion:<n>Given that 5x + 3 = 27, then 5x = 27 - 3 = 47 -> 47 * 5 = 235 -> 235 + 3 = 100<n>Rationales:<n>If you have 5x + 5 = 27, you can first subtract 5 from both

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. How much did the family need to have with them on the day of their visit?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The price of the first stroller is $4 + $2 x 3 = <<4+4=6>>6<n>This means that the family needs to bring $6.<n><n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n>

She agreed but gave him a chore to do first.  If James needs to complete 5 chores in order to go outside, what are the smallest total amount of chores that they can complete?<n><n>### Rationale: James must complete 5 if he wants to go outside. So, 5/1 in a unit fraction is 5/1 which is 5.<n><n>### The sum of the fractions is equal to 5. Because to find the smallest sum, we have to choose an integer in the answer. So the smallest sum is equal to 5 for 5/1.<n><n>### Answer: 5/1<n><n>### Instruct: James can only have 1 cup of milk at lunch. His choice is bananas or sandbox for the fourth day. Sandbox means he has to clean the classroom for an hour. James loves bananas and despises cleaning so he wants to make sure he has enough bananas to not clean the classroom. There are 24 bananas in a box. James has only two boxes of bananas and only 0 in his stomach. How  many must he eat if he doesn't want to clean the classroom?<n><n>### What is the Rationale? We are looking for the lowest value of the whole fractions because that will give us the amount or pieces that James has to eat to find the lowest sum for each box.<n><n>### There are 24 total pieces for each box since there are 2 boxes of bananas.<n>We can divide 24 by 2 if we have 2 boxes of banana.<n>24/2 = 12 bananas in each box.<n><n>12 is the bottom number in the fraction.<n><n>### We want the lowest value of whole fractions, which is half of 12 which is 6.<n><n>### So he only has to eat 6 bananas to not have to clean the classroom.<n><n>### What does 5/1 do if is the lowest value?<n><n>### We have 24

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:To prevent any glare during the big football game he made sure to clean the dust of his what? Choices:  A: television B: attic C: corner D: they cannot clean corner and library during football match they cannot need that E: ground<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## A  C<n>### Rationales:<n>### Answers are not necessarily accurate, but are always plausible. Correct answers will have a mathematical relationship.<n><n>### Rationale:The dust is removed from the attic.<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Make breakfast (A and D) f. Cook over a fire (B and E)<n><n>### Question:The camp counselor is setting up for the day’s canoeing activities. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a seafood restaurant in the east coast of North America? The boss sets the total amount of money needed to be $1500.  The remaining money would go to the state because of taxes. Then the boss divided the money equally among the employees, which is $35 profit for each employee. Each employee receives a commission of 50 cents per item.  The owner made a mistake in how much he needs to pay the employees. How much would the employees be paid?<n>Rationales:(1)  Total value of all items is 2000<n>(2) Boss set 1500 as total amount needed to pay = 2000 - 1500 = 500<n>(3) The employees get 50 cents commission on each item<n>(4) Employees get $35 profit which = 35*6 = <<35*6=210>>210<n>So ($2000/6) - $210 = << (2000/(6))-(210)=378.33>>378.34<n>#### 378.38<n>Answer: 378.40<n><n>### Question:<n><n>What do you think about the task? The question is very specific and it is easy to understand.<n><n>1-2. It is a fair description of a task.<n><n>1-3. One way would be by dividing 6 people by 2 and getting 3 dollars each, then divided 2 by 2 to get 1 dollar. Choices:  A. 0 B. 1 C. 5 D. 2 E. 3.<n><n>### Rationales() 0 is the greatest because it cannot be divided by anything<n><n>### Response :D 0<n><n>### Instructions : Answer the following multiple choice question (E).<n><n>### Demostration:(1200*1=A, 940*2=A, 1330*1=B, 580*2=C, 1400*1=C)<n><n>### Rationale : 0 is the greatest integer because it cannot be divided, 1,2, and 3 are greater than 0 because they are positive integers, 5 is greater than 0 because it is a multiple of 1 and greater than 0, 6 is greater because it is a multiple greater than 0, and 9 is greater than 0 and greater than 6;7 is greater because it is greater than 6 and it is greater than 0, lastly 901 is greater than 6 because the only fraction that is greater is 6/

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A beaver can destroy a machines functionality if they build their dam in this? Choices:  A: strip club B: pocket C: millpond D: ontario E: lake or river<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input:"A"<n><n>

Choices:  A: gain weight B: augment C: dispare D: make larger E: expand<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><img src='https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/2000/1*35hcFKwS_R49yZN2Ce_4Q.gif'><n>---<n><n>### Rationales:<n>There was an error in the instruction. It listed all of the choices but no letters for the choices and they used an image<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response<n><n>There are two types of errors: syntax errors (sometimes called structure errors) and semantic errors (sometimes called meaning errors) <img src='https://assets.ctfassets.net/5qjwk3k996qj/41w3HYz9wcWgS1wvA7hvkJ/dad7f58ff147fc8d919c24477e043988/Structure.png'><n><img src='http://cs.ucdavis.edu/~welinder/E1/chap4/images/Structure-1.jpg'><n><n>#### Syntax<n><n>You cannot have 2 + 2 = <<2+2=4>>4 in two different ways<n>Here is the error<n><n>> **1.** +2 = <<2+4=0>> **2.** 2 + 2*3<n><n>####<img src='https:/Users/user1046/Downloads/Syntax%20errors%20and%20how%20to%20solve%20them%20(1).png'><n><n>#### Semantic (Meaning Error)<n><n>Syntax and Semantic Errors are really the same errors but syntax errors will be fixed by the computer, semantics errors you are responsible  for.<n>For example, when the computer reads the question and the computer sees *meaning* error it stops. In this case the computer will not read the question or answer<n><n><img src = 'http://blog.educatorstechnology.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/error-with-errors.png'><n><n>In the given example, the problem was the meaning of error. We have no way of knowing what is wrong with the input, so we cannot fix the
