If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a lover likely to want to do with their partner? Choices:  A: build family together B: fall in love C: make love D: complete E: distance themselves<n><n>### Response:		What is a lover likely  to want to do with each other? Choices: A: build family together  B: fall in love  C: make love  D: complete E:  distance themselves<n><n>## What did you learn from your peers?<n>Things I learned from my peers: <n>1. That there are some people that are just more advanced than others, whether it be in math or english.  It's not always possible to do work the whole class can't do. <n>2. You may need to step back and explain yourself more to people.  A lot of times kids like to make fun of the way I talk and ask me how I speak.  Once I let them know that I am just from another place, I can understand their jokes better.  They can make fun of the way things are said in our class.  They think it is interesting to hear things explained a lot.<n><n>### What did you NOT learn from your peers as a result of their feedback?<n><n><n>### What suggestions do you have regarding the quality of feedback provided here?<n>I think the quality of the feedback was ok.  I do think that there were a lot of people trying to have me feel better about my math even though that is the main reason I'm here.  I know I can do this math, and I know that I will do it.  I am a very hard worker and will stay here until I get the help.<n><n>### How do you think the quality of feedback varies by the learning need?<n>Sometimes feedback from the people I have tried to work with doesn't help much.  If I am asking them for help about a topic they are not great at, then they have nothing to help me with.<n><n>### Please rate the feedback you received on a scale of 1-10 (one being the lowest and ten being the highest).<n>Rating: 5 <n><n>### Please comment on the ratings.<n>I am trying not to rate them low because I really think people just don't want a stupid kid to do poorly in math.  They are just trying to help in the best way they know.<n><n>### Reflection<n>What do you see as the next step in the process?<n>I think working with a teacher is the best way to go.  I already know the people that help me are
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does a person looking for new things in life do? Take the lowest billing period and multiply it by $5500 to get a mean.<n>C. Take the highest bills and average them to calculate a mean.<n>D. Take the highest billing period and multiply by $550 to get a mean of the two highest bills.<n>E. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Choices:  A: industrial area B: museum C: barn D: school E: office<n><n>### Response:		D (School)<n><n>### Demotivation:The original question asked:If there are 3 men and 3 women in the same room and every one of them knows everyone else, then how can someone always tell which man in the room has the last name of Brown?<n><n>### Answer:<n>When someone gives you the name of a person, that person must be at least in the room.<n><n>### Rationales:The names need to match at least some people in a group of three men and three women in the same room.<n>The three men have three names, so there is a chance the last one will last the same name of someone else.<n>The three women have three names, so again, there is a chance the one woman who has the last name of brown is the same name as on the group of three women.<n><n>### Explanation:The question is:If there are 5 people in one room, and each person only shares the same name as one of the others, then how can you always tell one of the women has the last name Brown? The answer is in the word "only"<n><n>### Rationale:The women have different names than each other, including Brown, Green, and Smith, so when all of a sudden you have a man name Brown and none of the other names in the group, that person must be Brown.<n>When one of the names is shared, we eliminate that from all of the women, making it easier for us to guess who Brown could be.<n><n>### Sample Question:<n>How many even numbers less than 10 can not be made with any digit that is even?<n>Input: There are 8 even numbers less than 9: 2, 4, 6, 8, and 0 (the last four can not be used since the ones are odd).<n>How to find the total:<n>To find the total amount of not even numbers, add 8 to 9 and find the one digit between 0 and 9 that is not even, 1.<n><n>Since there 8 possibilities between 2 and 8 and there is only 9 options possible in the first place, the only possible numbers are 1, 3, 5 and 7.<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would you find performers on a platform in public? Choices:  A: arena B: building C: dock D: concert hall E: museum<n><n>### Response:		<n>In the above question, the choices of E, D, C, A, and B represent:<n>```<n>	E= Museum<n>	D= Dock<n>	C= Concert Hall<n>	A= Arena<n>	B= Building<n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A balloon or two is a staple at a what? Choices:  A: birthday party B: child's hand C: grocery store D: sky E: up in the<n><n>### Response:		A balloon at a birthday party<n><n>

Choices:  A: hoof B: kentucky derby C: race track D: painting E: triple crown<n><n>### Response:		<n>Artist can commemorate a horse in many ways:<n>```<n>A) a) If the horse is famous, the artist can get some photographs and turn them into art.  b) If the horse is just a regular horse, the artist would probably use some paint and make the horse into a work of art, like Van Gogh.<n>```<n>####  A)<n>Answer:  A<n><n>### Input : You have $115 to buy lunch each day for 6 days, $133.89 to buy lunch each week for 12 weeks, $251.88 to buy lunch each month for 6 months, $115.37 to buy lunch each year for 5 years, and $230.75 to buy lunch out of college. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The color yellow is associated with the opposite of the characteristic, what is it? Choices:  A: fearless B: english carrier C: courageous D: brave E: achromatic<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The color yellow is associated to the _____ of the characteristic, what it is?<n>- The color yellow is _____ to the characteristic, what it has, which is _____.<n><n>The above are the instruction for which student will find the answer or response.<n>

Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can you eat fruit on a red bridge? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: engineering school C: san francisco D: tree E: market<n><n>### Response:		C) Where can you eat fruit on the red bridge?<n><n>#### <n>Answer: C<n><n>#### <n><n>### Input:{number of animals: 3} x {number of bale} of hay: {number of bales: 9}<n><n>### Response:{number of animals: <<3x9>>?<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 9<n><n>### Input::{number of birds: 12} + {number of cats: 2}<n><n>###	Response: {number of birds: <<+2>>14<n>#### 33<n>Answer: 33<n><n>### Input:"I love you. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The billionaire donated a large sum to his former college, this allowed them to construct a new science what? Choices:  A: fraternity house B: bank C: big town D: big city E: building<n><n>### Response:		<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If an actor is said to be on the “silver screen" where would you see them perform? Choices:  A: play B: movies C: theater D: screen E: television<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question, A movie theater, because the actor is performing on the silver screen.<n><n>### Input-Choice:<n>- Choice A is a play, not a movie.<n>- Choice B should be the theater, not a movie. <n>- Choice E is the television, the actor is performing on a screen, not a movie. (Silver screen may sound like television screen, but it is not the TV.)<n>- Choice D doesn't include 4 choices of performing, the only 4 places the actor can be is  A or B or E or the screen.<n>- Choice C is a theatre, not a movie. Theater is a place, and a movie performance would not happen in a theater, it would happen on a movie screen, so there is no need to include choice C.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>```<n>- An actor who is on the silver screen is performing on a screen.<n>- The silver screen refers to the movie screen.  A moviestar is said to be on silver screen.<n>- On the silver screen, means movies, so movies=silver screen.<n>- Performance on the screen would be on a television or movie screen, so on the screen means the actors is performing with a movie or tv program, or  on a movie screen.<n>```<n><n>```<n>Choice D:  Silver Screen = the movie screen, not a movie theater.<n>```<n><n>### Input/Response:<n>Input: Which of the choices below gives the definition of congruent triangles the quickest?<n><n>Choice A:<n><n>In mathematics, two triangles are congruent if their sides and angles are equal in size<n><n>Choice B:<n><n>If two triangles have corresponding, or corresponding sides equal to each other and the angles connecting them also equal, then the triangles are congruen<n><n>Choice C:<n><n>In geometry, two triangles are said to be congruent if each has exactly one pair of congruent sides and each has exactly one pair<n><n>#### Choice A:<n>Answer: choice B<n><n>#### Choice B:<n>Answer: choice A<n><n>#### Choice C:<n>Answer: Choice A because that matches the definition, if the corresponding sides and the angles are equal, then the triagles are congruent.<n><n>### Response/Answer:<n>In a

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What's the nickname of the monster the beauty loved? He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. What is the total number of fouls that were committed?<n>Rationales.<n>First you find out how many times a player on each team committed a foul by multiplying the total number of foulls by 2.<n>1. So the first total number of foull is 5+7 = <<5+7=12>>1<n>2. So the second total number of foull by multiplying by 2 is 8-5 = <<8-5=3>>3<n>3. So to find the total number of foulies commited you simply do 1+3. <<1+3=4>>4<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: There are 5 men: A, B, C, D and E. There are 3 times as many men as women. Let me show you what I mean with a table<n><n>name |gender<n>---- |----:<n>A |M<n>B |M<n>C |M<n>D |M<n>E |M<n><n>This tells me that there are 5 times M.<n><n>M = 5<n><n>Also since there is 3 times as many M we get 3XM<n><n>3XM = 15M<n><n>We know the total group of men has 5 times M in it, so we can say that<n><n>5 = 15M+2<n><n>Solving for M we get M = 7<n><n>We can find the number of men

With these limitations and restrictions we came up with another way to celebrate my favorite holiday. Since we were stuck inside we decided to do a “Bingo” type of game with cards full of candy and snacks from the kitchen as prizes. It was a fun time spent with my best friends and I still would have done it any other year in lockdown.<n><n>### Solution:Solution to #20<n><n>Let x be the month that your friend wishes to know. Your birthday falls on day d of day.<n><n>The following formula can be used to get d: d = (x - 1) months + 2 months. d - 1 = (x - 2) months. d - 2 = (x - 3) months.<n><n>You can rewrite these equations so that you get just the day of the month.<n><n>d -

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:No matter the background of the person, they should all be given what in applying for the job? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What happens to the next appointment when a grooming takes longer than expected? Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>##### Choice A<n><n>##### Choices A and B<n><n>##### Choieces A and C<n><n>**Response:**<n><n>- A: injury: <Injury can’t make the next appointment go a little longer than usual because they have already been there for more than the usual period. If there is any injury, it should take precedence.<n><n>- B: beauty:< Beauty cannot be able to postpone an appointment. Beauty has time constraints because there's not much time for styling hair, and the clients have to do their activities earlier than expected, so, it's not allowed to postpone an activity just because of time.<n><n>- C:late:< In the event of a delay, it's important to make sure it doesn't cause other patients to be late.<n><n>- D: mistakes:< All the mistakes will be taken care of. That is one of the things that the beauty parlor will be responsible for.<n><n>- E: annoyed:< In the event that a mistake happens, the person will be very worried and he becomes very annoyed, but when it is too late, it can not be reversed, so that when a beautiful error happens, it is important to make it right again.<n><n><n>### Instructions:What is a benefit of the parking garage in the picture?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Parking garage parks more than 50% of the vehicles.<n><n>#### 50%<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Instuctions:What happened if two vehicles were already in the garage at the time of the crash?<n><n>### Demo:<n>The vehicles will be damaged.<n><n>#### 4 + 4 = 8<n><n><n>#### 8<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### Choice A:<n>> "I've seen a lot of cars get crushed like trash cans on top of them."<n><n>#### Choice B<n><n>> "They'll be gone and then we'll be left with the trash cans or the cans behind."<n><n>#### Choices C and D<n><n>> "If they crash, they will destroy them."<n><n><n><n>### Choices C and D: The trash cans will get damaged if they crash.

If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to sore a wind instrument in you home? Choices:  A: under bed B: symphony C: music room D: band practice E: music store<n><n>### Response:		 D<n><n>### Input A good friend should be loyal. Which of these words means the same thing as loyal: B: trustworthy, C: unfaithful, D: not trustworthy, E: constant<n><n>### Response E<n><n>### Input 1. When I was a child I wanted to be a teacher because I liked school. 2. I really respect my teachers because they make learning so fun. B: False C: True<n><n>### Response C<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:She curled up under a blanket to get warm, this made her what on the couch as they started movie? Choices:  A: sleep B: feel more comfortable C: sweating D: blush E: cuddle<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Sleep is more comfortable so that is what the people did on the couch.<n><n>### Inputs:11. That is the idea it is making, so "but" is the best answer for the definition of the word.<n><n>#### Input<n><n>Choose one:<n>1. Although, but<n>#### Input and Rationale #1:<n>Although the word does not mean that a statement is made, it means to contrast the following statement.<n>You are correct.<n><n>#### Input #2<n><n>Although the word is used in the place of "but" it means to contrast the sentence instead of the two statements.<n>Correct.<n><n>#### Input, Rationale, and Answer<n>1.  Although the word means that the two statements contrast each other.<n>2.  However is used to contrast the two statements, so but must be the answer<n><n>#### Rationales<n>E-<n>The answer is correct because the word means to contrast the two statements.<n>F-<n>The answer is incorrect because the word does not mean the same as "but," so that word is incorrect.<n><n>#### Instruction<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:There weren't enough chairs for everyone.  What might have to be delayed? Choices:  A: bookstore B: building C: meeting D: office E: coffeehouse<n><n>### Response:		The D: office can be delayed.<n><n>### Input 1:There weren' think the event was a waste of time.  Choices: A: bookstore B building C: meeting D E: coffeehouse  <n>### Response 1: D<n><n>### Input2: It was great to have everyone.  What might be done to improve the next event? Choices: A: bring back books B: build more desks C: give people more chairs D: have the event twice as long E: get a bigger office<n><n>### Response 2: D<n><n>## 7 & 8<n><n>### Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demaration : A.If you work in a cereal factory, how many pounds of cereal do you get for $100?<n>B.How many pounds can you get for $1,000<n><n>### How can 75% be more than 90% of? Choices: A.20% B.30% C.60% D.None of these answers<n><n>### How many times a day do Aaron and Sara go to the movies? Choices: A..never B.once C.twice D.four times<n><n>### Demarch :  How many times more does Sara shop than Aaron? Choices: A B C D <n><n>### Demark :  How many times does Aaron go to the movies on Friday as opposed to Sara? Choices: A C B D <n><n>## 9<n><n>###  Find the fraction represented by the number line below.<n><n>### A. 12/45<n><n>### B 13/45<n><n><n>###  You have $1.00 and $5.00 bills in your wallet.  How many 25 cent candies can you buy?<n><n>###  A. 4 B. 11 C. 31 D. 59<n><n>### How much change would you get from $2.25 for one dollar?<n><n>### Choices: A..25¢ B...50¢ C..70¢ D..20¢<n><n>###  What is one-half of 10% of $3
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What preposition do you use if you want to combine two words? Choices:  A: article B: adjective C: interjection D: conjunction E: pronoun<n><n>### Response:		D: conjunction<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>### Rationalizes:Each item in a group will be completed with the same operation as long as the last item is also in the group.<n><n>### Input 1:Each item in a series will be completed with the operation of the last item plus 2.<n>1. The first three numbers in a series total to 15, so the second, third, and fourth numbers in the sequence are 5, 8, and 11. The sum of the first three numbers is 5 + 8 + 11 = <<5+8+11=24>>24<n>In the order of operations, 5 + 8 = <<5+8=13>>13<n>In the order of Operations 13 + 11 =<<13+11=26>>26<n>In the order of Operation 15 + 2 = <<15+2=17>>17<n>#### 17<n>Rationales: In the order of Operation<n>17 = <<15+1+3>>15+1+2<n>17 = <<2+3>>2+3<n><n>### Input2:Each item in a sequence will be completed with the formula 2 + (value of the previous item).<n><n>### Rationals:The formula is the same for each item in a series.<n><n>### Response 2: 2+18.<n><n>### Output 2: 2 + (2+18)<n><n>### Rationale for Output:For Input 2, the formula for each individual in a sequence is 2+previous value (which is 2 + 18).<n><n>The previous value of 2 is going to be (20).<n>The new value for 2 is 21<n>2 + 21 = <<2+21=23>>23<n>Since 23 is the new value, the next sequence becomes 23 + (23 + 19).<n>The formula is 23+23=<<46>>46<n>The previous value is 23 + 18 = <<23+18=41>>41<n>23 + 41+18 = <<2

Choices:  A: dissipate B: flown C: disintegrate D: fall apart E: penultimate<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Option A: Dissipate<n><n>Option B:Flowed<n><n>Option C: Disintegrated<n><n>Option D: Fallen Apart<n><n>Option E: Penultimate<n><n>## Instructions<n>Follow the prompts and directions given to you throughout the page. Use proper coding ettiquette and don't copy this code from any other website. This assignment will be graded and reviewed by multiple teachers so be sure to answer all of the points in order to receive full credit.<n>## Demonstration<n>What has happened to a persons money after he or she used the last of it?(1 point)<n>Option A: DISSIPATE<n>Option B: FLOW<n>Option C: DISINTEGRATE<n>Option D: FALLEN APART<n>Option E: PENULTIMATE<n>## Response<n>Penultimate means second last. In math, "Penultimate" is the answer to the math problem "pen-1-LAME-timate". What has happened to a person’s money after he or her used it is, Dissipate.<n>## Demonstiation<n>Penultimate: What is the second-to-last term?(1 point)<n><n>## Response<n>Second-to-last term does refer to as penultimate because the penultimate can be interpreted as "second last" or "next to last"; when you add an "m" to penultimate, you get "permanent" and when you add an "lt" to penultimate you get "petulant" which both mean the definition of "permanent" is "being always the same" and the definition of "petulant" is "fever."<n><n>## Demostration<n>Penultimate refers to: (1 point)<n><n>Penultimate is a word that refers to "second-to-last term" or "second last."<n>"Pen" means "the smallest amount" and "ultimate" means "the best or last result."<n>Pen meaning "smallest" can refer to the smallest amount or the smallest amount of time and ultimate means "the end result" or the last outcome.<n>When the pen is held up it looks like "pen" = tiny and ultimate = large because small pencil = tiny and big pencil = large. In order
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a place to eat and places to buy items of many different kinds? Choices:  A: city B: downtown C: own house D: bar E: shopping center<n><n>### Response:		City<n>### Demonstraion:The city often has places to eat where you can also buy many other types of items.<n>#### City<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Instructions:If a number is divisible by 8, the remainder must be 8. Write a statement that uses the remainder operator and describes the correct response.<n><n>### Response:(remainder 8) 48 / 8 = 6 = remainder 2<n><n>### Instructuon:If a number is greater than 0 and divisible by 8 an additional test should be done. Write a function that determines if 48 is divisible by 16.<n><n>### Code:function test(num){<n>  if(num % 8){}else{<n>   return "not right"<n>  }<n>}<n><n>### Tests:test(12);  <n>### Output:not right<n><n>### Instuctions:Write an expression that, when executed by the calculator, will display 6489.<n>- 6 / ( 4 x (89 - 16) )<n><n>### Test:60 / 91<n><n>### Output:59%<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If I recieve a letter from a friend over seas, why might I read it? Choices:  A: pudding B: get news C: strain D: answer E: though<n><n>### Response:		<n>In order to get news<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: A - pudding<n><n>### Input : <n>Taylor made pancakes for breakfast every Saturday morning. She only had enough pancake mix to make 16 pancakes. How many pancakes could Taylor make if she used 2 pounds of flour to make those same pancakes?<n><n>### Response : <n>I can use the same mix to make these pancakes if I can use two pounds of flour to the equal 20 pounds of mix.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer : 2<n><n>### Input :-<n>Linda went to an art installation to celebrate her birthday party. She brought her son along. She asked her son's teacher for his permission and the teacher gave it to Linda. On their next day, before going out Linda asked her son to take a bath and the son said, no! Finally Linda forced her son to have a bath. Now Linda was very angry with her son. When she asked him the reason to that, he said, I asked you to bring me that art installation only and not for that birthday party. So what?<n><n>### Rationales -<n>I need to change the birthday party to art installation<n><n>#### 00<n>Answer :-<n>Linda was very angry with son<n><n>### Input:-<n>There is a circle. All circles are congruent. Which is not? Choices: 1: O 2: A 3: C 4: B 5: D<n><n>### Response :-<n><n>All but C<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer :-<n>(C)<n><n>### Input-<n>A new business has been opened near your house.The owner of the business said, My business is very popular.Which of the following does the owner mean? How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Choices:  A: cinema B: opera C: party D: stage E: dance<n><n>### Response:		<n>We need to find the definition of each and see which one would most commonly involve performing:<n><n>####A: cinema: <n>1. A cinema, also known as a movie theater or theater, are venues, buildings, or former buildings where cinematic motion pictures are shown for public viewing.<n><n>####B: opera: <n>1. Opera is one of the earliest examples of western arts.<n><n>####C: party: <n>1. An ordinary party, in which the term "ordinary party" often refers simply to a birthday party or some other such festivity, generally has little in common with a festival or other important, organized ceremony.<n><n>####D: stage: <n>1. The stage (or more formally the performance area) is the part of the theater building in which most of the action of the drama occurs, where the audience sits and where the actors and technicians engage in their work.<n><n>####E: dance: <n>1. Dance is a type of art that generally involves movement of the human body, often rhythmic and to music.<n><n>Since we are comparing to theatrical performances, I will say the answer would be the most common place you would see a performer at such a gathering is on stage.<n><n>### Input<n>Choose the verb in the statement that best completes the sentence.<n><n>### Sentence: It took a lot of work to complete the assignment.<n><n>### Options:<n><n>1. Where did he drive? Choices:  A: great granddad's house B: family picture book C: brother's house D: family tree E: family reunion<n><n>### Response:		<n>My niece’s father is my family tree, and we always meet at family reunion, which is in my family picture book. Marlowe is 4 years old, what is their combined age next year? They have birthdays on the same day.<n>### Response: Last year, their combined age was 27.  To find their age in 2 years, subtract their combined age last year by 2 then add 1.  We know their age combined last year is 27, and today Marlowe is 3 less years than Richard is.  So their age combined is    (x + y) = ____ or   27= (x + y),  where "x" is Richard and "y" is Marlowe's combined age, and  27= (x+y), where x= Richard's age and y= Marlowe's age, and we find 27 = (x+y) = 27 = (___  +_ _)  =   ___ and 27= (x-1) + ____, so 27= (___ +27, then ___=27. We know that next year will be 1 year later, so  27 + 27 = 54 = (___+___), so our combined age next year is x+y= 54. We know that last year's age was 27, so <n>last year's age =____-, and this was calculated in the first part of our equation. Therefore, we can rewrite the equation to read x+y= 27 + 25 or 54<n><n>54= 27 +25 <n><n>#### 54<n>Answer: 54<n><n>### Input The difference in ages between Timothy and Owen is 12. Owens is 8 years old, what is the combined age of Timothy and Owen in 3 years.

Choices:  A: get money B: pay money C: go shopping D: lose money E: save money<n><n>### Response:		<n>D(lose money)<n><n>### Rationale:<n>These stores trick you by telling you that the more products you get the more money you will lose. You only lose money if you pay for the products.<n>####<n><n>### Input:"If Jake cuts the grass twice as fast as Mary, how many times faster is he cut the grass from Mary? "<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Jake cuts the grass two time faster because he makes twice as much progress in half the time than Mary.<n><n>### Response:" JAKE IS TWICE AS FAST AS MARY"<n><n>### Rattianle:<n>The response is as long as Jake cuts the lawn, he could do so at least 2 times as fast as Mary does. If you were in Mary's shoes, you would be doing half as much as Jake is doing in half the time.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does god want people to do for money? Choices:  A: work in life B: speak to people C: everywhere D: sitting ideal E: care for people<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>#### Response<n>Answer:<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### A: work in life<n><n>### B: speak to people<n><n>### C: everywhere<n><n>### D: sitting ideal<n><n>### E: care for people.<n><n>Answer: C<n><n><n><n><n># 💡Hints<n>Write a line of code to answer the problem.<n><n>If you need hints to solve a problem, click on the star above!<n><n>### Hints:<n><n>#### #48847954630-hints
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is the result of instituting civil action? Choices:  A: bad feelings B: confusion C: going to court D: hurt feelings E: sandwiches<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer: A<n>#### B<n><n>Answer: B<n>#### C<n><n>Answer: C<n>#### D<n><n>Answer: D<n>#### E<n><n>Answer: E<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is something that you feel when you go to the opera? The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What will happen if you are successful when committing suicide? Choices:  A: scars B: being born C: sorrow D: misery E: kill yourself<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:Successful suicide means committing suicide successfully.<n>We are left the only choice is A<n><n><n>#### A<n><n>######A: scars<n><n>### Response<n>B<n><n>### Rationale: The other choices are either unsuccessful suicide or not committing suicide. Committing suicide is a type of unsuccessful suicide, and not a type of successful suicide because being successful means finishing the task.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Choice:  C: sorrow<n>The choice A: scars is more likely than C: sorrow because after attempting suicide, the people will suffer pain and feel very sad for the rest of their life.<n><n>### Choices:  D: misery and E: kill yourself are not true because committing suicide will have no misery, and it will not keep you alive, and after committing suicide, you will no longer exist so you can no longer do a second attempt.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>In order to kill yourself, you might first have to try to commit suicide.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>```golang<n>func main() {<n>    success := suicide()<n>    if success {<n>        fmt.Println("You're alive")<n>    } else {<n>        fmt.Fatal("You failed to kill yourself")<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n>And what happens if the attempted suicide doesn't work? It prints to stdout `"You failed to kill yourself"`. <n><n>### A: scars<n>The choice A:scars is more likely because of the fact that after attempting suicide, people will suffer pain and never be able to forget about it for the rest of their lives.<n><n>### Successful suicide means committng suicide successfully, and "killing yourself" is not a task. <n>So the other choices are not successful suicides. <n><n>### If you successfully commit suicide, you will die, otherwise you are still alive. <n>So the choice that leads you to die is more likely.<n><n>### You can't get scars after successful suicide.<n><n>######B: being born<n><n>### Response <n>B<n>The answer B is more likely than C because when people choose suicide, they are likely to
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A school is most likely to be located in what sort of zone?
