The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What should you do if your pens aren't work? Choices:  A: ink in B: caps C: ink cartridges D: take notes E: scribble<n><n>### Response:		Because pens are used for taking notes, the best way to deal with a situation in which a pencil is not working is to take notes.<n><n>### Input : A group of six friends plan to buy a car. One of the friends offers to split the cost of transportation home for everyone. However they do not have enough money. How is the rest of the group supposed to come to an agreement for dividing the cost of transportation if only one person offers to split the cost?<n><n>### Response : The rest of the group should split the cost for the transportation equally among themselves instead of getting a cost breakdown from one person, since in the cost breakdown the person may include costs that do not apply to other people.<n><n>###Input:You are an entrepreneur and you have to deliver some goods to a village near a river.  You need to transport the goods on a raft. The raft can hold 331kg of goods and is able to make 15 hours of round trip from and to the villages that are near the river. How long do you have to stay on the river each time to make the round trips?<n><n>###Response 1:<n>You have to make one trip in 5 hours<n>Rationales: The raft can hold  331kg, so round trip is 331kg x 2=662kg.   Each trip should be 15 hours, so there should 2 trips.<n>If one trip is (t1, t2), one trip will be half of that trip, so t2 = t1 / 2 (Reduce)<n>t1 = 10;<n>Half of that should be:<n>t2 = 10 / 2 = 5<n>Final:<n>t1 - t2 = 5 - 10 = -5;<n>Final<n>5 – 5 = 0<n>Final<n>Final<n>(t1, t2)<n><n>### Response 2:<n>You have to do two trips in 10 hours<n>Rationales; The raft can hold   331kg, one trip is 33km, and the raft will make a round trip, so each stop needs to be (33 - 33) / 2 hours = 13 (Eliminates -13)<n>One
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a movie theater along with other stores in one placE? When playing an arcade game, Seth won four tokens. Each of his wins made him one token happier. With four tokens, he is twice as happy as without any tokens and eight times as happy as if he had no tokens at all. When he played he earned a token. If his happiness is equal to the tokens he has, how many tokens did he earn when playing?<n>### Solution:<n>He was twice as happy with token, because he is a: <<4th number>>4 + <<1th number>>1 = <<5>>5<n>He was 8 times happier without tokens, because 5/1 = 5<n>Seth
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		Authoritarian

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where in Southern Europe would you find many canals? Choices:  A: michigan B: new york C: amsterdam D: venice E: bridge<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explanation:Amsterdam has canals<n><n>### Input.What is 1/5 + 8? Choices: A: 3 B: 15 C: 8 D: 4<n><n>### Response. C<n><n>### Input : What is the equation of a line that passes through (7,2), and has a slope of \(-2/5\)?<n><n>### Response : \(x - 5 = -2 (y - 2)\)<n><n>### Input  : At the bakery, one dozen cookies are equal to 22 ounces. There are 28 cookies for every 1 dozen. Which expression is in simplest form to show how many ounces it takes to get a dozen cookies?<n><n>### Response C<n><n>### Rationale The whole dozen, the dozen has 12 and its only whole dozen<n>`12/12 = 1`<n><n>## Input :<n>### What is three-fifths + 1/3?<n>### A) 2/5 B) 7/15 C) 1/4 D) -1<n>### Response : 1/4<n>### Rationale<n>### Start with three-fifths 3/5<n>`3/5 + 1/5 = 3`<n>### Then, get 1/3<n>`3/5+1/3=1`<n>### The answer is 1/4<n><n>### Input<n>#### What is -95 - 82<n><n>####A) 7<n>####B) -12<n>####C) -73<n>####D) -15<n><n>### RESPONSE<n>#### Answer: D) -15<n>#### Rationale<n>#### 82<n>#### -15<n>#### -95 - 15 = -<n>#### -95 + 82 = D) -15.<n><n>### Input A rectangle has an area of \(45 \frac{3}{4}\) square feet. The length of one side is \(5\frac{1}{2}\) feet. What is the width of the rectangle?<n><n>### Rationales<n>#### Length of one side is 5.5 feet<n>#### Area of rectangle is 45.75
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a great place to lay in the sun? Choices:  A: in the basement B: west C: solar system D: beach E: beans<n><n>### Response:		<n>This is a trick question.  Beans are actually legumes, not vegetables.<n><n>#### Choices:<n><n>-  A: in the [basement](https://www.dictionary.com/browse/-basement) (a lower part of a building) [B: beans](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/bean)(food)<n><n>-  B: [West](https://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780199316354.001.0001/acref-97801-63/west#acref-97-01-7340), [Solar](https://www.thoughtco.com/solar-system-names-2072049) [System](https://www.space.com/why-solar-system-earth-called-3b-3b.html) (space object consisting of the sun and all smaller objects that orbit around it)<n><n>-  C: Beach ([beach](https://www.britannica.com/place/beach))<n><n>-  D: [Beach](https://www.[beach](https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/beach))<n>E:<n><n>#### Answer:<n>B: West, Solar System<n><n>### Demostration:<n>![Demonstration](/assets/images/21713489_1616497826269538_87097227208545560_n.png)<n><n>### Input 2:What is a great way to keep pets cool on a hot summer day? The only transport available is boat. After they have reached their destination, a total of 58 kms of the journey was covered by walking, 21 kms of the journey is covered by canoe. The rest of the journey is covered in a long ferry trip.  How far away from their destination  had they been when they decided to board the ferry?<n><n>### Explenation <n>The journey began with 58km, and then 7km of distance is covered by canoe, and 8km by the ferry. They walk for 58+7+8 = <<58+7+1.8=68>>68km. This means they walk for 68km from the end of the canoe ride to the ferry. They travel 58+7 = <<58+1.8=35>>35km on the canoe. They walk 68 - 35 = <<68-35=33>>33 km, and thus begin to walk. The ferry takes them 8km to the destination. They start walking from where they stopped canoeing and continue to walk. This takes 33+8= <<33+8=41>>41<n><n>### Answer<n>41<n><n>## 6<n><n>### Input1<n>I need to find out the value of X.  x = 203 + X- 2X^3<n><n>### Explanation <n>In this equation, the value of X is found by finding the first derivative, 2X. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What do drugs do? Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n><n>### Response:		In order to make a response, you need to do all of the following to earn full credit:<n><n>1. Read carefully, answer what is asked for, follow the task<n><n>2. Write complete, correct answers<n><n>3. Provide a full justification for your answers<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Can you name a good reason for attending school? Choices:  A: get smart B: boredom C: colds and flu D: taking tests E: spend time<n><n>### Response:		(C)<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>

Choices:  A: hole B: television C: sporting goods store D: pool table E: sporting event<n><n>### Response:		If we take a closer look at the options for this question, they are not all equally possible. The two main kinds of players are 1. professionals and 2. amature players, and the two places they spend time playing are either public or private. Hole is the only private location, so we rule out B and D. A and C are the two public places we could see people in uniforms playing the ball.<n><n>### Input : What is a noun? Choices: 1)an action 2)a place 3) a person or thing 4)an error<n><n>### Response : Nouns are typically people or things, but they can  also be used as pronouns! So, they can be a person, place, or thing; an action is not a noun.<n><n>### A man is twice as old as his son. Five years from now, the man will be 4 years older than his son. How old is the son now?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Dad and son are 3 years apart. 5 years ago, son was 1 year younger to  dad,  so dad is 3 + 4 = <<3+3+4=10>>1 years older to dad now.<n>Son will be 6 years younger than dad in 5 years.  So son is 10 - 6 = <<10-6=3>>3 years old now.<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n># 4 The Math Word Problems<n>## 4.1<n>## 4.7<n>## 4.9<n>## 4.21<n>## 44.57<n>## 44<n>## 46

Choices: 30 days: A: 2 days B: 5 days C: 7 days D: 10 days E: 13 days<n><n>### Response 2:<n>Since he can run 62 miles in one day, if the race required 1,00 miles then he will need 16 days to complete the race.<n><n>### The task<n>- You will see many questions on the exam that involve making inferences and conclusions from the given information. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The teacher told all the students that listening was key, it was the main way they would gain what? Choices:  A: empathy B: anxiety C: knowlege D: falling down E: hear things<n><n>### Response:		D, the answer is D, hearing things.<n><n>### Input 1: A group of 3 children are sharing a box of jellybeans equally. One child takes 4 beans while the second child takes 6 beans. What did the third child receive?<n>### Input 2: There are 8 pennies, 10 nickels,and 12 dimes. If they are placed in an envelope so they are evenly distributed, how many ways can they be distributed evenly? (Use 0-index notation to separate counting techniques)<n>### Response 1: The third child receives 28 jellybeans.<n>### Response 2: There are no possible ways to evenly distribute a sum of money that have an uneven number of coins, regardless of how many coins in the sum. If counting starts at 1, we have 8 ways to distribute 8 pennies (since there’s 8 distinct ways to choose 8 from 8). We have 10 ways to distribute 10 nickels (since there’s only one way to choose 10 from 10, and 10-3 ways to choose 10-3 from 10). We only have 12 ways to distribute 20 dimes (since there’s no way to choose 12 dimes from 20). Therefore there are no possible ways to distribute the sum.<n><n>### Review 1: Input: A group of 4 children are sharing an apples equally. One child takes the first apple, another takes the 2nd, other takes the 3rd, and then the other takes the leftover apple. If there are a total of 11 apples, how many apples each child has left?<n>### Review 2: Input: If you split an apple into quarters, what is the largest volume of juice that each quarter will have?<n>### Review Final: One quarter of an apple will have 1/4th of the total apple juice, so half the juice. That means 11 apples have 4 apples. Since there are 11 apples and 4 juice quarters left, each child has 3 juice quarters.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a good result of losing weight? Choices:  A: increased energy B: healthier C: loose skin D: beauty E: death<n><n>### Response:		<n>If they all are true, then A is correct. If they are not true, then E is true. Either way, if death is false, then loss of weight can never kill a person.<n>### Demonstation:<n>1. A. increased energy<n>2.  B. healthier<n>3. C. loose skin<n>4.  D. beauty<n>5.  E. death<n><n>A. increased energy						B. healthier			C. loose skin		D. beauty					E. death<n>Yes<n>Yes<n>No<n>Yes<n>No<n><n>Loss of weight does not help. Loss of weight can help but not always, and can be a disadvantage.<n>Loss of weight helps the health, yes, but skin is a thing that can stretch back to its original position upon gaining weight. You cannot gain skin.<n><n>If you lose some weight, you can be healthier. But, it depends on the amount of weight you lose. In one case, you can die due to weight loss.<n><n>Loss of Weight can make you more Beautiful. But if your health is not good, you can get depressed which can be a disadvagante.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Demostration:<n>1. A					2. B		3. C			4. A			5. C<n><n>### Answer:<n>A, A, C, C<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer: A<n>

All annual maintenance fees are automatically charged to the customer on the day that the software is ordered by either phone or Internet. Each fee is charged to the customer in a dollar amount that is based on the software order. For example, if the software is ordered on Monday, then the fees might be: $99 for installation and setup, and $312 for maintenance for a total bill of $411.<n><n>#### Question<n><n>a.) How much will a customer be charged if they place a software order by phone on Saturday?<n><n>b.) The software maintenance fee doubles the installation and set-up cost. If the installation and set- up cost is $99, what will the maintenance fee be?<n><n>c.) Increase the installation and setup cost by 50%, so that the new cost is $200. What will the fee schedule be now?<n><n>d.) If the software purchase was placed via Internet on Thursday, what are totals for the customer's bill?<n><n>e.) A customer recently called to ask if there was any way that she could save money and possibly reduce the bill for the software service. What should be your advice?<n><n>#### Hint<n>A person can save money by installing the program himself or by setting up the software without using the support line.<n>---<n><n>**a.)**<n>$48 if it was placed by phone<n><n>---<n><n>**b.)**<n>$123<n><n>---<n><n>#### c.)<n>Fees will be<n>$270 for software maintenance<n>$300 for software installation and set- up<n><n>---<n><n><n><n>

If you are unsure in the answer of the first problem, you can skip ahead to the next part or move back to the previous part. The next part involves working with the solutions.<n><n>### 2.3<n>#### Input: A is two times the square of x.<n><n>#### Response: Since A = 2x² = <<3x 2x>>4x<n>#### Input:B is the square of c.<n><n>#### Response B = c² = <<8x^2>>4x^2<n>(x*1)*(x*2) = (x*1)^2/x<n><n># Section 2:  RD<n><n>### 3.5<n>#### 3.5:Input: How much does each of Sarah's toys cost?<n><n>```<n>	Toy 1	Toy 2 	Toy 3<n>Price	Price	Price<n>$36	$36	$75<n>$50	$64	$75<n>```<n><n>#### Response: Each toy cost $36 + $50 + $25 = $111, so 111/3 = $<<111/3=37>>37<n><n># Question 2<n>### Response:<n>#### Input: A 75-gallon pool pump was used to circulate the pool water for 30 minutes until the pump was completely submerged. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where is a tabby cat likely to be happiest? Choices:  A: box B: home C: alley D: lap E: barn<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Justification: There are plenty of cats with different personalities, but we can assume that the tabby cat in this question is happy. If not, then why would they be asking where the cat is likely to be happiest, not least happily alive. The cat’s home is his lap, so it’s natural to assume the cat thinks of his lap as a home. The alley is likely best avoided, because alien cats aren’t always so sociable. The tabby cat is probably used to spending a lot of time on his lap, so a barn would be pretty alien. Lastly, being a box cat is just weird, I think.<n><n><n>### Input :Write your response in the blank space ____ below.<n>The word “hypnos” means ______, or sleep.<n><n><n>## Additional Questions<n><n>### Input<n>For which of the following numbers will the absolute value of the number be less than its magnitude in exactly?<n>* 0<n>* 1<n>* 11<n>* ⌊e-2⌋<n><n>### Answer<n>⌊e-1⌋<n><n>#### Note:<n>⌊e−2⌋<⌊e−1⌋< 0<n><n>### Justify<n>We are only given the option of 0,1, which gives us e−1, which is less than 0, but more than 11<n><n>### Input The function f (x) = −1000 is increasing on. Which of the following values is a root of f (x)?<n><n>1. -6<n>2. -5<n>3. -3<n>4. -1<n><n>### Answer -3<n>* f(x) = b(x) if the function is increasing on [a,b] so ( f(b) - f(a) )/ ( b - a ) >0 -> -3 > -1 so b >= -1<n><n>## Additional questions<n><n>### Task<n>Which of the following statements are PRECEDENTS?<n>* "All planets are stars."<n>* "Pigs cannot fly."<n>* "A dog is not human."<n>* "Dogs don't speak."<n><n>### Answer <n>* "Not
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:There weren't potatoes but actually a snake in his what? Choices:  A: burlap sack B: hot country C: purse D: pet shops E: deep grass<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input<n><n>Choices:    A: 2<n>    B: 4<n>    C: 6<n>    D: 8<n>    E: 10<n>Answer Key<n>```python<n><n>A=math.pow(2,i)<n>B=math.pow(4,i)<n>C=math.pow(6,i)<n>D=math.pow(8,i)<n>E=math.pow(10,i)<n><n>for i in range(4) :<n>    if A < B < C < D < E:<n>        print("Correct Answer: ",(i+1),"is ",D)<n>        break<n><n>print("Final Answer is ",answer)<n>```<n><n>### Instructions<n>1. Write a response that does the following: A) Read the question and answer for the statement above.  B) Write the correct answer C) Include your answer using the mathematical formula<n><n>### Answer Key<n>```python<n>A=math.log10(A)<n>print("log10")<n>```<n>12<n><1/12=0.083333332<n><n>2<n><1/2=0.05<n><n>4<n><1/4=0.025<n><n>6<n><1/6=0.015<n><n>8<n><1/8=0.0125<n><n>```python<n>d=2*10000<n>print(d)<n>```<n>d=999<n><999*1000=1e-6<n><n>1<n><1.001e6<1e-6<n>```python<n>a='40+b'<n>b=3<n>d=eval(a)<n>print(d) <n>```<n>43<n>d=43+3=46<n>```python<n>d='4'<n>x=2<n><n>d<n>```<n>4<n>```python<n>d="5e3"<n><n>e=20<n><n>d = eval(d)<n><n><n>print(d) #50000<n>```<n><n><n><n><n><n>2.  In response to the following statement that was read in class:  <n><n> <n>A. What do you believe is the correct answer?
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The new play was the go to performance of the year, all the crowds would stand and what? Choices:  A: admiration B: applaud C: make reservations D: experience E: sleep<n><n>### Response:		<n>>The new play was the got to performance of the year<n>><n>><n><n>### Input<n>>The 3rd grade class took a field trip to the science center, each child brought $3.50. B:  If a child only had $3, that child would receive a refund of 50 cents.  C:  If one child paid exactly $4, that child received 50 cents change back. D: All children would receive 50 cents in change.<n><n>### Response<n>>Correct answer  D) - All children would receive <n>><n>>50 cents in Change<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do you put a new dining table? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Who is likely going in to a market? Choices:  A: stress B: food C: that you D: spending money E: walking<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  Stress because food<n><n>### Demostration:Start by deciding which choice was the correct response.<n><n>### Rationale : The rationale for the response is that “stress” and “food” are closely related. For instance, when dealing with stress you can eat something to relieve it. The sentence “stress is likely going into a market” is likely false, or inaccurate. When stress wants to go buy food it may stop into any one of the markets, but we can’t specify which particular market. So, the response that is most true is Stress because food. Stress and Food are closely associated to each other so both of them are going into markets which are close together.<n><n><n>#### Which response would make sense for the following given scenario?<n><n>Input: A new gym opened across the street from the YMCA. Choices:  A: michigan B: map C: american city D: rest stops E: country<n><n>### Response:		 <<A:map>>map<n>It is not specified, but the answer is A:map<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>If there are 760 square meters in a hectare, then this equation expresses the relationship between an area in square meters and its corresponding acre in acres:<n><n>0 square meters of area = <<.0 acres>>zero acres<n><n>1 square meter of area = <<.1 acres>>one acre<n>5.33 square meters of area = 4875.33 square feet of area = <<5.33 acres>>5.33 acres <n>4875.533 square feet of an area = <<.5 acres>>0.5 acres<n>4875 square meters in an area = <<3 acres>>3 acres<n>48715.5333333 square feet of a area = <<30 acres>>30 acres<n><n>How many square feet of area are in 810 acres?<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>810 acres = 32,358,000 square feet = 8,100,000 square meters of an area = <<32,353 acres>>32353 acres<n>```<n>It was the 22nd letter<n><n>### Input <n>```<n>In the set {5, 9, 21, …}, there is a pattern. What is that pattern?<n>```<n><n>#### Choice A: The set contains the first nonzero, positive, integer. Then the numbers are 5, 9, (3 x 9), and (9 x 9).<n>The answer: 21<n><n>#### Choice B: The smallest number in the set is used for the next unit: <<5, 9,  99, (99 x 99), 551, 2833, 335749>>33574.<n>The answer: 551<n><n>#### Choices C and D: Both of these are wrong because they do not contain a pattern<n><n>### Choice A: Choice B: <n><n>### C:<n>If n are two times more people in a country, then, the result of n^2 are<n>```<n>2 - 2 = <<
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What can someone feeling happiness fall into? Choices:  A: lead to laughter B: love C: laughter D: smiles E: tears<n><n>### Response:		<n>Laughter falls into A: happiness.<n>Love falls into C: happiness.<n>#### 1<n>1<n><n>### Input:-132.3 - -135.6 + 50.2<n><n>### Response:-3<n><n>### Input:(257 - 1)(-6)<n><n>### Response:(-550)<n><n>### Input:"The difference between $17 and 1/2 of 3 is?"<n><n>### Response:"4 3/4"<n><n>### Input"If $x = 5^3 + 35^7$ is true, what is $x = 4^2 + 4^2 + x = 28x - 4^4$ if $x = 43$?"<n><n>### Demostration:<n>$x = 5^2 + 35^4$<n>$x = 28x$<n>$x = -9x$<n>$x= 10x$<n><n>$x = 43^2 + 38^2 + 43 = -9x - -9x = 10x $<n><n>$x = (x/16)^1.8 + (5/12)^7 + (x/16)$if<n><n>$x =$<n><n>$x= 2^2 +9^7 + 20.0625 = 6541 =$

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. They used shake hands method to think :<n><n>### Response4 to answer4:<n><n>####<n>####<n>####<n>### Final answer4:<n><n>The method of controlling events, using shake hands and talking to each other :<n><n>### Input5: The group needed to think for their solution. If there are numbers in the question, substitute then for x and then solve. When you solve, you can see that some of the signs are different, for example, if (5x4 > 5x4) that would mean (5x4  ) and (5x (4) )) would mean the same thing meaning subtracting (

Choices:  A: cook dinner B: make bread C: eat in restaurant D: have lunch E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		Choice:A<n><n>### Instructions below:<n>When you finish your answer, double click the 'Complete Assessment.jpg' image to submit your solution.<n><n>### What I am looking for:<n>* What is the word problem?  <n>**What exactly is the student asked to do/find?**  <n>* How are you solving it?  <n>**Explain your thought process and the steps you took (include and explain how you are using the math concepts).**  <n><n>### How can you tell?  <n>**Revisit the description and look for evidence in the student's work that they have done this work.**<n><n>### Feedback is provided on a 5-point scale<n>-5 is unacceptable<n><n>---<n><n>### Instrument Details<n><n>**RUBRIC:**<n><n>* Instruction:Answer the question based on the information given to you.<n>* Demonstration:Answer the question correctly and appropriately.<n><n>---<n><n>**Grading Guidelines**<n><n>**RATING:**5 or 4 is outstanding; 3 above average with minor errors; 2 below average and 1 unacceptable **ACCURACY:** 3-5 is generally accurate; 2 is generally inaccurate; 1 is not generally accurate **CRITICAL THINKING:** **ORGANIZATION:** **EXECUTION:** 5-4 is effective; 3 is effective with minor errors; 1 is not effective<n><n>---<n><n>![](https://res.cloudinary.com/hopc/image/upload/c_scale,q_auto,w_700/v1/teachers/60447-thought_trackers_1.png)<n><n>### Instructor Information<n><n>---<n><n>#| Name on Roster (Hopkins)           | Title (Role)                       | Department (Counsel) |<n>|:---:|:-------|:-----------|<n>| Hopkins, Amanda                  | Math Teacher                        | D7                   |<n>| Hopkins, Amy                     | Teaching                            | G6                   |<n>| Miller, John                     | Principal                           |                      |<n>| Murphy,
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can peanut butter be stored? Choices:  A: container B: supermarket C: pantry D: sandwich E: jar<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A,B,and C - Peanut butter can be stored in jar, in a container or in the pantry. Supermarket can also mean a Pantry.<n><n>### Input 1:A and B - Why do birds fly south for the winter?<n><n>### Response Option A:Birds fly south for the winter for the same reason humans do, to escape harsh weather.<n>### Response Option B:Birds fly to the south for the winter to avoid harsh wintry weather.<n>### Answer: A<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response option A:If they were trying to keep the bears away from the picnic lunch, they had to find food more distant than 32  miles.<n><n>### Response B :If they had not taken in the bears that were within 32 miles of their picnic lunch, there would have been enough food remaining for them.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>A<n><n>### Input option A:Which does not need to be turned on?<n><n>Computer<n><n>Electric fan<n><n>Light<n><n>Light bulb<n><n>Appliance<n><n>### Response A:It only needs to be turned on when needed. It is a good idea to keep a light bulb from being turned off since it may be needed.<n><n>### Option B:It needs to be turned on during the night. It is a good item to have that does not need to be constantly operative.<n><n>### B for a good answer.<n><n>### D :<n><n>Answer that answer :<n><n>### Option D: It only needs to be turned off when it isn't needed but it should be periodically checked to be sure it is still working. It does need to be turned on but it is a good idea to have that light bulb because it's an appliance and will have to be used periodically in the future, so it will need to be turned on and checked for problems.<n><n>### G:<n><n>No. Only answer.<n><n>## Test 3<n><n>### Instructions: You need to use the sentence below to write your response.<n><n>### It took five years to build a space station. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Two friends wanted to spend a quiet evening together, what did they go see? Where did  he go to get more? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: cup C: pencil case D: shelf E: office depot<n><n>### Response:		If the answer is "D" he will go to E.  But the answer if not "D"  he will keep going until he reaches desk drawer, cup, shelf, pencil case,  and when he is at E, the answer will be "D".  So the output should be  E.<n><n>### Input1:16 – 17 =?<n><n>### Response1:-2<n><n>### Input2:The total weight of 10 boxes is 805lbs.  If each box weighs 20lbs more than its neighbor in a clockwise direction, will the weight of the two boxes on the corner be greater or less than the others? Choices: A. greater than B. less than C. equal<n>### Response: If each box  weighs 25lbs more than its other 8 neighbors, then the two boxes on the  corner will be 25 pounds more than their neighbors, which means 40 pounds more than  the weight of 20 lbs.  Therefore, the  two boxes on  the corner will be 60 lbs. more than the other boxes.  They will be greater than the other boxes.<n><n>### Solution<n>```<n>var solution = input<n>```<n>The program should loop through until the loop breaks.<n>```<n>var solution loop = true<n>while loop == true do<n>  result := answer question1<n>```<n>If the answer is correct, then the program should make the "loop" variable false.<n>

The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. A: flower B: Alive C: animal D: vegetable<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Harvesting is often done by hand, using simple tools like a fork, a spade, a hoe, and a shovel.<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>When your mother goes grocery shopping, you can find where in the store she should keep what.<n><n>### Answer 2:<n><n>You should find the bakery section in the store as this where you can find most things like buns, cakes, pizzas, pastries. It also contains other things like bread, frozen and prepared foods, desserts, and confections.<n><n>### Explanation<n><n>### Instructions<n>An explanation is a piece of writing that describes what to do, what to see, how to think about something, or why something is the way it is. This exercise involves writing an explanation to an incomplete question. Write an explanation that will help a child understand.<n><n>### Example:<n>The difference between two numbers is 10. If you add 21 to one of the numbers, the difference is 7. The other number is...<n><n>### Example<n>There are some items that we don't need anymore. What should we do with the items? Choices: A: throw away B: sell C: donate D: keep<n><n>### Example 2:<n>What should we look for when buying items? Choices: a b c d<n><n>### Example Answer<n>There are some items we don't need any more, and we need to know that we dispose of them. We can either sell them or donate them. It's more about helping others and reducing clutter!<n><n>### Example Instructions and Example Answer<n>There are things that we no longer need. We will dispose of them either by selling them or donating them. It's just about helping others and reducing waste, after all!<n><n>### Instructioin: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>What should we do when getting rid of items that we don' t need anymore? I don’t understand why they call it import.<n><n>### Inputs:A man with two children is 12 years older than his younger child and 8 years older than his older child. How old is the father?<n><n><n>### Response : A 44<n><n>#### Explanations : Since the father is 12 years younger than his younger child and he is 8 years older than that younger child, therefore both younger and older child equal to 12. Now 44 -12 + 8 = 12 = 44<n><n>### Input :  A bag contains two green and two red marbles. A person draws a green marble and then decides to leave it in the bag, or switch it with another. The same happens with a red marble. Repeat this process and you get three marbles in the bag. What color were they?<n><n>### Response - B<n><n>#### Explanation : There are two ways to find this, one is : if the first marble drawn is green, than in the next draw he will choose red, but if this was not the case, he would chose a green one. So the first marble drawn was green, so the two marbles the same color as the first one in the bag would be red and green both.<n><n>### Another way of finding:<n><n>#### Consider one draw, so we have one red marble in the bag, so the color of the next draw is the same color of the previous draw, so in this bag there is one green marble and two red ones; So if he keeps this way on and on, they are equal.<n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If done correctly grooming pet's nails generally does not cause this? Choices:  A: training B: satisfaction C: injury D: beauty E: late<n><n>### Response:		A: training<n>#### <n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input:If all the coins are equally weighted, then coin X will weigh how much more than coin A? Choices: 	A: 10 pounds B: 10 ounces C: 10 kilograms D: 10 grams E: 10 tons<n><n>## Answer: A: 5 pounds<n><n>### Demostration<n>In the given question, we have to determine how much more is the mass of coin X than the mass of coin A, which has the same mass for each value of coin.<n><n>Thus, we can say that mass is: $x-a=21$ (x mass − x = 21; where the extra x is extra mass of the coin that is more).<n><n>### Rationales<n>$21 \times 1 \text{ lb} = 21 pounds$<n>By the extra x mass is more. As all are equal. Thus, extra amount of mass is 10.<n>Hence, answer is A: 5 lbs.<n><n>To check the solution, we can replace A with a or vice-versa.<n>$x –(1+A) = –x+1= −1$, as the value does not remain the same.<n>Thus, it means the answer should be A.<n><n>### Answer: A: 10 lbs or 5 lbs.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast in bed can make you feel what, assuming that you don't spill anything? Choices:  A: vomiting B: pleasure C: happiness D: contentment E: mess<n><n>### Response:		Answer C because the other choices are incorrect<n><n>### Input-Demonstration<n>#### Input (Incorrect) A<n>#### Input (Insufficient) B<n>#### Input (Inappropriate) C<n>#### Input (Inaccurate) D<n>#### Input (Incompatible) E<n><n>### Input and Demonstration<n>#### Input A<n>Because "Vomiting" can feel the same as "Mess"<n>#### Demonstration<n>Rationales: Vomiting can feel the same way as mess because when you have vomited, you are always having a mess.<n>#### Answer C <n>Answer A (because vomiting = mess)<n><n>### Input (Inappropriately) D<n>#### Demonstratio- Incorrect answer <n><n>### Demostration<n>#### Input and Answer <n><n># Demonstrations(Response)<n><n>### Below is an instruction that states an incomplete idea.  Write a response that completes the request. <n><n>### Instructions: <n><n>#### Answer<n><n>A pizza is a food made from cheese and dough. After the pizza is cooked, a spoonful of pepperoni is poured onto  it. What has happened? <n>Rationales: Pepperoni is something that is put onto the pizza, so it is put on the pizza when it has already been cooked. It has already been cooked is an incomplete idea and so the answer is "been cooked"<n>#### Answer<n><n>What can a person say or write from memory?<n>Rationales:"Memorize" and write refers to the same thing-memorize because in the phrase "from memory you can say or write" write means say or write which is what you will remember and therefore when you memorize you will write from memory. <n>```Rationales:`Memorize is to read something you have memorized<n>Write is to type in what you have memorized<n>Read is what happens when you memorize what you have wrote<n>```<n>#### Answer B<n><n>How many pieces does one pizza have?<n>Rationales:-A pizza can have pizza-A pizza can have crust <n>```A pizza can have more than one pizza, and you will have to cut each pizza into different sizes```<n>```A pizza has more than

(The input will always contain 4. If the size is two or fewer, it produces a value of 1 as the output.) Ex: 1582 for 1582, 2588 for 1588.<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>sum(1*1582)+sum(2*1582):<n>>> 9<n><n>sum(3*1582) :<n>>> 5<n><n>return: 158<n><n>```<n><n>## Summary<n><n>Congrats on completing the exercises and completing the weekly assignment! Choices:  A: cash drawer B: piggy bank C: purse D: box E: pocket<n><n>### Response:		<n>* If the option says box, then put it in the piggy bank or the box.<n>* If it says pocket, then put it in cash drawer.<n>* Since it is a question, always put it in a box.<n>* Since it does not say how much, put it in box.<n><n>### Justification:<n>If you put it in a box, then you could not easily get it out without breaking it.<n>You can not put it in a piggy bank.  Because a piggy bank has no lock<n>Put it in the box, you cannot take it out without breaking it because you have to open the box.<n>#### A<n>Answer: box<n><n>### Next Time:<n>* A dollar is a dollar to you. Make it harder for yourself to get.<n>* Try a 25 cent or a 33 cent bill.<n><n>### Feedback:<n>* You did an amazing job on this challenge! Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.
