For one of the items, the total bill is 74. For the second item, the total bill is $105. The customer had $170 to spend. Was the customer able to buy both items?<n>Rationales:(5)I: The customer used all his money to pay for the item with $105, so he does not have enough money to buy the other item that costs $74.<n>(1)I: He did not buy both items because he could only afford to buy one of them<n>(4)I: He did buy both items<n>(3)I: He bought two items<n>(2)I: He did both items<n><n>I = (1), (2), (4), (5), (3)<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Instructure:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>Input: Sam is making a new recipe. Choices:  A: tennis elbow B: proffesional player C: exercise D: victory E: becoming tired<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Demostration:<n>A tennis elbow is a common injury caused by playing tennis <n><n>### Instuction:Write a response that 26 is divisible by 3 + 16?<n>### Solution:<n>\$26\$ can be represented as \[26\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)\], so the answer is \[26\left(3+\frac{16}{2}\right)\]. When we divide \$26\left(r_{3}+\frac{n}{2}\right)\$ with 3, we would get \$26\left(\left(r_{3}+16/2\right)\div 3\right)\$. We have \[26\cdot 16\]. However, the last one would not be correct because $\$16\$ is not divisible by 3. Thus, the answer should be $\$336\$.<n><n>### Solution<n>31 + 16

Sarah wants to buy 3 pairs of shoes for herself and 2 pairs for Nancy. The total cost for all shoes is $98.84. As payback for buying for Nancy, Sarah receives 50% of her shoes for free. <n><n>How much does Sarah’s total shopping cost?<n><n>## Response<n><n>#### 25<n>Answer: 25<n><n>### Input How do you find the total cost for all shopping?<n>## Response<n>Let n be the number of shoes bought for Nancy. <n>$\frac{n}{3}=m$, the  number of shoes bought by Sarah<n>$\implies n=3m$<n><n>$$\begin{matrix} <n>sarah_s_cost=\frac{3m}{2}\times\$98.84<n>=m\times\$9884-\$1973.54<n>\end{matrix}$$<n><n>m=12, so Sarah’s total shoes cost=$9884-1973.25=7910.75$<n><n><n>### Input What is the expression for Sarah’s cost?<n>## Response<n>The expression for sarah’s cost is-<n>$$\begin{align

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Many addicts turn to exercise to deal with their addictions, this is because it is a healthy way to do what? Choices:  A: condition heart B: expend energy C: laugh D: stretch E: weigh<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input :How much do you agree (or disagree) with the statement : “Ladies shouldn't play chess“?<n><n>### Response : (agree)<n><n>### Input<n>One evening, Kyle came to his room and found that his roommate, Ryan, had left his laptop open. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A shop will give you what for your purchases? Choices:  A: downtown area B: container C: ocean floor D: the lost city of atlantis E: high school<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is B. <n>The correct answer is B.<n><n>### Input<n>Their son, Troy, is in need of $200 for a school trip. Troy’s parents and he decide to split the cost between each other. The money for Troy’s trip is evenly split between each of the two and they each pay 200/2 = $<<20/2=100>>100 each.<n>However, Troy’s parents decided that they each would like to contribute an additional $50 because they want to fully support Troy. So, they each contribute an additional $5 = $<<5*2=10>>120 in total. The money now comes to $100 + 120 = <<100+120=220>>220.<n>Troy’s parents paid $200 to contribute the $200, but they are still going to need to contribute something to meet the increased cost. This is because they have spent $100, leaving $120 left to contribute. $120 / 2 = $<<125/2=62.5>>62.5 each. So, they need to contribute another $31.25 to cover all the costs.<n>This makes the contribution for each parent another $100.25 + $31.21 = $<<100.2+31.25=131.45>>131.40 each.<n>This equals $100 + $3 = <<100+$3=103>>103. Troy still needs to contribute $20 for his contribution to the trip.<n>Forty percent of the amount Troy contributed will be his contribution, or $103 / 40.5 = $<<103/40.5=2.5>>2.5<n>The final total is $103 - $2.5 = <<103-2.5=100.5>>100.5, which is equal to $100.00 + $2.5 = $<<$1000.5>>$100.0<n>#### 100.5<n>Answer: 1<n>

If You Spend 40 Cents, How Much Money Do You Have Left (Write a Proportional Equation)?`<n><n>**Challenge:Answer the following proportion equation.**<n>**1. I have $2.25 and I am left with $71.58***<n><n>### Concentration:Write the following proportion.<n><n>### Representation:Draw a table to complete. Write the table values under the column headings.<n><n>### Concrete solution:<n>Start by dividing the $2.25 by 71.58 = <<2.25/71.58=0.0313>>0.031<n><n>Since 0.031 is the unit rate, you need the cost of everything to be converted to the unit rate.<n><n>Cost of Everything / $0.031= Cost of Everything / Unit Rate<n><n>$2.25 / $0.01 = $2.25/0.031 = $<<2.25/31=72.73>>72 and the money left = 71.5<n><n>The money left = $71.5 – $2.25 = <<71.5-2.25=69.25>>69.25<n><n>### Conclusiom:The solution to this question is 0.073. This is the unit rate that relates to $69.22 divided by the given starting number, $2.25.<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Represent:<n>### Solution:0.073<n><n># Chapter 2.07<n>```<n>```<n><n>### Chapter 2.12<n><img src="https://assets.chegg.com/3e/73/912646cb-3ed5-474d

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where might I find unusual varieties of roses? Choices:  A: botanic garden B: flower garden C: backyard D: supermarket E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>Where might I find unusual variants of roses?<n><n>#### A:<n>Yes, because rose is botanic garden and it has so many species.<n>#### B:<n>No, because rose is not flower garden<n>#### C:<n>No, because in supermarket usually roses flower are normal and also in backyard.<n>#### D:<n>I might find unusual species  of roses,<n>in backyard because the climate is perfect weather for rose to grow in the garden<n><n>#### E:<n>Yes, because the rose flower will grow in outdoor weather<n>

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If I am suffering from boredom, and I want to do something with a dictionary, what would help? Choices:  A: do crossword puzzle B: see art C: give up D: grocery shop E: play chess<n><n>### Response:		D is the only option without a logical fallacy<n><n>---<n>#### Answer:Answer to the problem<n><n>### Response to response:<n>### Correct:<n><n>### Incorrect<n><n>### Your response(s) does(do) not follow the instructions of the task. Please re-read the instruction for a better understanding of why your responses are incorrect.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Whether it's popped, grilled, or canned people like to what? Choices:  A: expect to die B: believe in god C: stay in D: watch movies E: eat corn<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Choice D<n><n>### Rationale:<n>In a survey of 687 participants, it was found that:<n><n>-  80% expect to die.<n>-  74 % believe in god.<n>-  0.1% stay in.<n>-  25 %  eat corn.<n>-  80 % watch movies.<n><n>This would mean that 20% stay, 20% can't eat corn and 80% can't watch movies.<n>#### 20%<n><n>Answer1:<n><n>#### 80%<n><n>Answer3:<n><n>#### 25%<n><n>Answer5:<n><n>#### 100%<n><n>Answer7:<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: jail B: internet cafe C: blacksmith's shop D: building E: bar<n><n>### Response:		 C. Building B.The Internet Cafe<n>* Rationale for response: "The building, The internet cafe, because when the stool was being made someone would of seen a picture of the stool and went to the Internet Cafe to tell someone<n><n>### Input<n>Write a single-statement, simple program that answers this question.<n><n>Write a program that reverses the word that you enter. For example, you enter ‘hello’, the program should give you ‘olleh’. Your program should not give you something like ‘olle’ or ‘helo’. Enter your program as a single statement. (No indentations)<n><n>### Output<n><n>* Program answer:<n>```<n>hello<n>[1]   2  5  1<n>```<n>* Rationale: the program should start by creating a new line with the user input in reverse<n>* Explicit: new line then put the input in reverse with the first letter as the last, 5th letter the 4th until the end.<n><n><n>### Input Write a single-statement, compound program that answers this question..<n><n>Write a program to calculate 2 different angles using two values, a1 - an, inputted by the user.  It should give me a value of theta at the end, as this is what I entered into my program.  <n><n>### Output Write a single-statement program that answers this question...<n><n>Calculate the value of each theta for (2pi) and (theta + pi).  The angles must be in between 0 pi/2 and pi radians, inputted by the end-user.<n><n><n>## Output<n><n>* Program Answer:<n>```<n>Enter angles<n>60<n>Enter value for theta1<n>30<n>Enter value for an<n>sin(theta1) =  cos(theta1) =<n>```<n>* Rationales:<n>```<n>if(theta1 & theta2 & 2pi ) then find value of theta 1<n>if(theta1,the2 & 2pi & then find theta2<n>if ( θ-pi & then find value of thet1<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What are students trying to do? Choices:  A: study philosophy B: become adult C: ask questions D: further education E: study together<n><n>### Response:		The answer would be the letter which starts with the first letter of your last or home surname.<n>

Also, two dogs named Luna and Lily are laying around. How many more pages do I need to read? I plan to read about 1.5 more pages per dog I have here.<n>Constraints:  I have read 4 pages, so  <<4=4>>4 more pages do I need.<n>I have 2 dogs which multiply is 2 x.75 = <<2x.75=1.5>>3 dogs are laid.<n>I am also half way done, so half of the 3 = <<3/2=1.5>>2 dogs.<n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n>

Choices:  A  B  C  D  E<n><n>### Demand:Billy went because....<n>### Answer:  Because their parents were fighting <n><n>### Input Choices:  Choices:  A B C D E<n><n>### Response Choices:   Input: Billy went because his parents were arguing. Rationales: In a fight, they were arguing, which is the same thing.<n><n>### Your response: Billy went to his......<n><n>### Choices:  A team   Present   At Home   Come Back   Charming<n><n><n>### Democracy.<n>#### Write the correct response to the instruction.<n><n>### Response instructions: The store sells sturdy boxes at a marked-down price. If the marked-down price of the box is $50 and you buy 12 boxes, then your total cost is $<<600=60>>60.<n>### Your response instructions: Write a statement that correctly completes the request.

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do most people keep magazines? Choices:  A: bookstore B: library C: doctor D: home E: table<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n>### Instructions: Write the correct code for the following. The number in parenthesis with each solution will be the test cases. For example (A) = 1: one case, (B) = 2: two cases<n><n>### Instuctions: You are given a string representing a phone number and a dollar value. Print the following statement if the phone number is within $5 of the dollar amount.<n><n>### Input:[547223090534]$20.00 <n><n>### Rationales: If the difference is 5 or less, then the person is within 5 dollars of the requested amount<n>Difference = $10 - 5 = <<10.00-5.00=5>>5 and $20.00 - 5 = 15.00 - 100 = <<$20.00-100=0>>0<n>If there is a difference greater than 5, then the person is not within 5 dollars.<n>#### $20.01<n>Answer: True<n><n>### Input:-3 1 +.21<n><n>### Rationale: If the difference between -3 and.21 is 1, then the person is 1 dollar or less from the requested amount (within $5)<n>Difference = 1 - 1 < <<1-1>=0>>0 then True<n>#### -1.20<n>Answer: True<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:How can buildings like the Empire State building be described? Choices:  A: small B: underground C: high D: huge E: tall<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is E, tall. The Empire State building is known for its sheer size and height. It’s easy to forget sometimes that the Empire State building is underground with the amount of people in it. This building will be in the Empire State so it is not going to be small or high or small. It is only going to tall.<n><n>### Input<n>Harper’s husband, Jim, works at a call center and earns $10 per hour.  Jim receives a $50 bonus each month. What is Jim’s monthly salary and how much of his bonus is Jim saving for each month that he works?<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>Jim’s total hourly pay is his hourly pay + his bonus.<n>His hourly pay is $10/hr and his bonus is $50/month.<n>$10/hr + $50/month = Jim’s salary = $<<<10*12+50=120+50=170>>$170.<n><n>Jim’<n>s wife, Harper, has a job. She earns an $18 hourly salary. She is also paid an $100 bonus during the same month that Jim receives his bonus for calling in sick. What is she working and how much is she being paid for the hourly pay?<n><n>### Response<n>Harper is paid $18 an hour + $100 bonus.<n>To find Harper’s current hourly pay, multiply by 3:<n>$$28/hr = 180/h$$<n><n>Harper saves half of her bonus.<n>She saves $19.25 a month.<n><n><n><n>### Input <n>What do the words and phrases in bold all mean?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>* Slightly greater than 100<n><n>$$\frac{687*100}{100}=6.87>\frac{687}{100}=7$$<n>$$\frac{1528*100}{35000}=\frac{96356}{3500}=\frac{4\times3210}{350}\approx \frac{32400}{35}\\

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The gambler had been winning a lot, he wisely decided to what? Choices:  A: matchwinning B: cash in C: compete D: return E: celebrate<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is D. Winning does not always mean having fun. Some people have a natural talent for winning. When it's almost inevitable, winning becomes a stressful situation. At some point, winning becomes less fun and more of a responsibility and an opportunity to earn money.<n><n>### Question:The gambler felt an instant urge to? Choices:. A. leave B. bet C. continue D. ignore E. quit<n><n>### Response : The correct answer is B. When a gambler wins a lot and feels like they can do whatever they want - like bet on the same hand and go off on an adventure - this person is going to feel an instant urge to leave. This is because the gambler is already exhausted by trying hard enough to make enough wins or just trying too much.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### I'm feeling better today. My parents had a birthday party for me and I'm so excited to celebrate. Can you believe I made the entire cake from scratch?!<n>My parents were totally surprised to see me cook and now they are asking me to cook for them all the time. I think they're a little worried because they are looking for me to fill the void of our housekeeper who moved away.<n><n>They say they're proud of me and my brother who was with me as I cooked! So today, I'm going to be happy about the cake and happy that I'm making my parents proud. I'm also proud now that I'm taking more of a leadership role. There's a lot to be proud of.<n><n><n>### Question for a computer scientist: How many possible games can the player play with the computer? Use a recursion formula (i.e., a function that calls itself) to find the answer.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What treatment might an old time doctor have tried to accomplish with leeches? Choices:  A: heart transplant B: distance himself C: perform surgery D: study medicine E: let blood<n><n>### Response:		A heart transplant<n><n><n>

He gets $19 for the bus and he has $14. How much was bus?<n><n>###Response:<n>Answer: 14<n><n>###Rationales: He got $19 for the ride to school and also $14 after the ride. So he got $2 in total. So he spent $42 total. When he spends $42, he has $14 left (2-19=14), so it was $14.<n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is love when everyone keeps feeling it? Choices:  A: contagious B: wrong C: last forever D: painful E: blind<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>#### Answer: Contagious <n><n>#### Why: The definition of love as something that keeps feeling it is not true love because it means when ever someone gets hurt by someone they wont stop loving them. It would mean that the person is just blind to the harms they cause to the person.<n><n><n>### Your Response:<n>#### What is love when everyone keeps feelin' it?<n><n>#### A: contagious - The definition of love as an outward force that just keeps pushing you towards that same person that you're suppose to love is not true love. If it's contagious it means that everyone is blinded to the hurt they're causing to the other person.<n><n>#### B: wrong - Wrong meaning you know the other person really good, but you cant love them.<n><n>#### C: last forever - True love is not a choice.<n><n>#### D: painful - True love is not painful. If it hurts it's not real.<n><n>#### E: blind - Love is not blind because you never get to the point when u love something so much it's blinded. Love is always present in your heart and thoughts. It's real emotion not a feeling.<n><n>#### Which is the example of non-proportional relationship?<n><n>#### - A: 5-minute baths is 5 times as long as 1-minute baths<n><n>#### - B: 45/2<n><n>#### - C: 10/3 and 4 are not proportional<n><n>#### - D: if 8 is subtracted from 12,9 is obtained<n><n>#### - E: 5 times 7 and 38/7<n><n>#### <n><n>#### <n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Billy bounced the ball off the wall. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:what do you do before going to party? Choices:  A: call 911 B: enjoy yourself C: get drunk D: having sex E: meet new people<n><n>### Response:		B<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where will a native lemur be found? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Turkey is a nation in what part of the world? Choices:  A: middle east B: asia minor C: asia D: provide meat E: balkan peninsula<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### D<n><n>Turkey is a country in Asia.<n><n>#### E<n><n>Turkey provides meat.

I know I would be upset. So for the second paragraph you learn about New England where there's a lot of casserole. In the fourth paragraph the only important thing to know is that Idaho is the biggest potato producer. Choices:  A: tree tops B: rain forest C: zoological gardens D: great outdoors E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input-<n><n>##Rationales-<n><n>## #Rationale<n><n>##Answer-<n><n>##E<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does reckless driving lead to on a person? Choices:  A: injuries B: fatigue C: traffic jams D: tired E: accidents<n><n>### Response:		Accidents<n><n>### Rationale:Reckless driving leads to accidents as it involves fatigue. Thus, the correct answer is accidents. A and B are not correct as they are not directly connected to reckless driving while B and C are already mentioned in the question<n><n>### Input:"The length of 800 ft is equal to how many inches?"<n><n>### ResponseA: "The length if 800 ft. is equal to how many"<n><n>### Rationales:It is important to ask the question in a complete sentence as it is a form of writing and it is also important to capitalize the first word of a sentence.<n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Choices:  A: pass water B: bathe C: listen to each other D: feel pleasure E: reproduce asexually<n><n>### Response:		A. Pass water<n><n>### Rationale::If you were to describe animals, you might say that they live lives that are good for their environments - they eat what they have to in order for the ecosystem not to become out of balance. Some animals can't swim and so they drown, unless they are able to come up to the surface. Others might not eat much since they don't have teeth. Differentiated instructions: "You could have said 'bath.'"<n><n>#### <n>Answer: A. Pass water<n><n>Input: The children want to bake brownies. Each spoonful of brown sugar takes one teaspoon from the bowl of brown sugar. How many spoonfuls of brown sugar can the three children take if there are one-half cup of brown sugar in the bowl?<n>Rationales::Use half = <<.5=1/2>>1/2 to reduce from 1/2 down to 1/2 for later ratios.<n>The one cup has one-half as much as it originally had. The children can each take 1/2 so 1 - 1/2 = << 1-1/2=1/2>> 1/2<n><n>Let c + b + t = <<c+b+t=1>>1 The 1/2 in this expression is the first one-half,<n>The b, c, and t is the reduced amount you get by subtracting the half-cup.<n>There is the b, c, and d that the kids can eat once b and c are subtracted from the 1 cup the way d was<n>1/2 + 1/2 + 3/4 = <<1/2+1/2+3/4=3/2>> 3/2<n>b /3 + c/4 + t/3+2/6+4/12 = <<b/3+c/4+t/3+2/3+4/12=1/2+1=3/2>>  3/2<n>b =<<b=2>> 2<n>c =<<c=2>> 2,<n>t = t –<t-2> = 3<n>Now c = 2 and b = 2, the remainder is equal to the entire 1 cup – they divide it evenly<n>

Choices : A: 152 times B: 266 times C: 133 times D: 601 times<n><n>### Response :<n>Richard check the electrical connection twice in a week hence he checks it 26 times on monthly average<n>Richard fixes it once in each month hence, he fixes it 13 times per month<n><n>## Instruction:<n>How many times does he check it in a year?<n><n>## Response:<n>Richard check the electric connection twice a week and he fixes it once a month, so it is checked 26 times on weekly and 13 times on monthly basis which is 39 time per year (1 time/week * 52)<n>

If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Jan went to the auditorium and listened to the speech. Where might he be? Choices:  A: crowd B: high school C: city D: somewhere E: theater<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D. Theater<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Question:An adult sells a bagel to the store. What type of transaction is it? Choices: A: a business-to-consumer transaction B: a business-to -business transaction C: a business-to government transaction D: a business-to nonprofit transaction<n><n>### Response<n>Answer: B Business-To-business transaction<n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input.Mike needs to buy tickets for his team.The sports team is from Boston and the event is in Denver. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:We were having a canned food drive and I needed to pick up some contributions, where did I go? Choices:  A: shelf B: cellar C: refrigerator D: cupboard E: grocery store<n><n>### Response:		A is the correct answer.<n><n>### Answer: A<n><n>### Input2: What is this number divided by 3? Choices A: 1 B: 2 C: 3 D: 9 E: 12<n>### Rationales2: Answer has to be 2<n>### Answer2: 2<n><n>### Input3: Sam’s room has a TV, computer, desk, bed, dresser, and bedroom set. How many chairs does he have? Choices: 1 A: none B: 2, C: 3 D : 4 E: 5<n>### Rationalese: He has one more, not two more, not three more because every time  one, then there goes 1 more, then we are left 1 behind. <n><n>### Answer3: D<n><n>Input4: I want 3 limes, not the green kind that grow on trees and not the red kind.<n>Rationales4: red, trees, grow, so green limes<n>#### 3<n>Answer4: 3<n><n>Input: I like to put stickers in my planner. Last month, I put 3 stickers on the first page of my planner and I wrote things to do for every day of the month. I had 8 stickers left in the jar.<n>Rationales: Last month I wrote something to do for every day, so each day has 1 sticker.<n>I have 3 + 12 = <<3+12=15>>15 stickers.<n>I have 15 stickers left, so I still have 22 stickers to make.<n>#### 22<n>Answer: 22<n><n>Input: My cousin, Bradley, and his wife are new parents. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The wheel was loose, and threatened to fall off when they were what? Choices:  A: footloose B: sailing C: fast D: tighten E: bind<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E: The wheel was loose, and Threatened to fall off when they are "tighten"<n><n>### Input 1:<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Start by taking the first value and multiplying it by 10 to turn the fraction into an integer.<n><n>First fraction ==> 1/3 = <|0.333>>'0.333'<n><n>When adding fractions, the largest denominator should be kept. Since 15/5 is larger than 10/10, we multiply 15/5 by 10 to obtain a larger denominator of 150.<n><n>Second Fraction ==> 10/15 = <|10/15>>'10/15'<n><n>The result of 40/10 = <|0.4>>'0.4' / (of first fraction 0.333) = <|0.7>>'11.67'<n>

Choices:  A: envy B: resentment C: winning or losing D: one winner E: two winners<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>######<n>IMPORTANT NOTE: Always use capital letters except when writing numbers and use lower-case letters only to type code, abbreviations, or any type of code.<n><n>#### E: two winners or A: envy?<n><n>### Solution:<n>1. Choice A: Envy<n>2. Envy: The most likely cause is that no one wants to be the first team to lose.<n>3. When a person does something well and other people feel that what they did is better than, it is called “envy”. It can cause a person to act in an unpleasant fashion to another person.<n><n>### A: envy or E: two winners?<n><n>### A Solution:<n><n>1. Choice E: Two winners<n>2. Choice E: The teams were evenly matched in the playoffs between one another, meaning that they kept getting the same score and nothing could change it, so there can’t be one winner and one loser.<n>3. There isn’t any envy.<n><n>### Solution 2:<n>1. When a person does a good job and does better in what they did than another person, it is called “Envy”<n>2. When competition between two people isn’t equal, it can be considered as “Annoying”.<n><n><table><n>  <tr><n>    <td>1. </td><n>    <td><code>A: envy</code> </td><n>  </tr><n>  <tr style="display: none"><n>    <td><img src="/imgs/choice_2.jpg"></td><n>  </td><n> </tr> <n>  <tr>    <n>    <td>2. Choices:  A: apartment B: pantry C: table D: living room E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>**Response:** Choice A: apartment<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The word "place" means you are going to some sort of container. A "pantry" is "some sort of" container, and so is a "living room" or "shelf". However, none of the above refers specifically to dishes so option D refers to a house rather than an apartment. That then reduces the set to (A,B,E), but (E) still applies to books, so (A) is the answer.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>There is no explanation for why the rest of this example is correct, but there is nothing wrong with them. This is just the next example, so there should be no issue.<n><n>### Response 2:<n><n>**Response 2:** Choice A<n><n>### Rations:<n>There is no rational for why this is incorrect.<n><n>### Input:-3-:You and the following people want to play a 4-player board game that costs $12. $9. $6. and $5. respectively. Each person will have to pay this price to play. You want the game, but you only have $3.20. How do you split up the amount of money?<n><n>### Response:-3--:You have $3.25 so you pay the difference. $3.25 - $12 = $<<3.25-12=9>>9 and you also pay $9 because that is your share.<n><n>### Incorrect:<n>Each person is paying for themselves, so when they have 3.25, the person with.25 cannot pay the difference; they can only give the difference to the person with the lowest price. That is exactly what the 4th person has to do, giving.25 to the 3rd, and the 3rd giving.25 to 2nd, and 2nd taking the remaining $5. Since each person paid exactly, there is no way that the one with the lowest price is not the one who won.<n><n>### Correct:<n>Since you want to play the game, you can pay $11.25.<n><n>### The correct one is (D), because the only way to satisfy all the equations is if (D) is true.<n><n>##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Parents often yell in times of chaos, what are they trying to do? Choices:  A: guide children B: understand children C: control children D: care for children E: vent anger<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:Input the command below to start a calculation using Python: x = 12 - y<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### The answer was: Answer<n><n># Solution<n><n>### Input A: < 20 - 14 > + 39<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>Since Hurley is 15 and the difference in ages is 20-15, Richard is 25.<n>Forty years is 600, and 150×2 is 300, plus the 25, the answer is 325.<n>The answer is 326, with 6 = 14 × 4.<n><n>### Input B: < 150 - 0 > + 39 - 14<n><n>### Rationale<n>Pablo read 17 books.<n>The car costs $900, so Brad’s share is $900%4 = <$ 35> <$35>.<n>So Harper spent $35 on her son’s teacher, $40 on her daughter’s, and $480 on the remaining 3-4 = <3-4> <$24> <$20>.<n><n>### Code:<n><n>```python<n>10. a = 0<n>  14. b = 18<n>  40. c = 128<n>  34. answer = a + b + c<n>98. a = 1200<n>  200. b = 70<n>  40. answer = a * b<n>91. a = 5<n>  20. b = 4<n>  4. answer = a * (b + 1)<n>```<n>

Rather, it moves the masts on what? Choices:  A: sailing vessel B: paddleboat C: ship D: motorboat E: tugboat<n><n>### Response:		The answer is E: tugboats have the helm that moves the mast, not sailing vessels, paddleboats, ships, or motorboats.<n><n># Solution 1<n><n>### Rationale<n>The input in the task is "The helm" which is not something you would wear on your head. Instead, the "helm" is something that moves masts.<n><n>Since we do not know what kind of boat this belongs on, our intuition may lead us to pick D: motorboat. The helm moves the masts, which would make sense on a motorboat. But if we look at the answer choices, we know that it does not move the masts of a ship (that is B), a sailing boat(that is A), or a paddle boat(that is a C). Additionally, as the answer, picking E: tugboating is the correct answer for two reasons:<n><n>1. Tugboats are in the answer choices.<n>2. "The helm" is not what you would wear on your own head, but instead what moves the masts of a boat. It therefore does make sense that it would be on a tugboat which would need the steering mechanism(the helm).<n><n># Solution 2<n>**Instruction**<n>Input: The helm is not something that you wear on your head; rather, it moves the mast on what?<n>  <n>Choice (A) A: sailing vessel<n>Choice (B) B: paddle boat<n>Choice (C) C: ship<n>Choice (D) D: motor boat<n>Choice (E) E: tug boat<n><n># **Rather, it moves the  mast on  what**<n>We need to find where the helm moves the mast.<n>Since it is on the mast and the answer choice is "The helm moves the mats on what?", we can determine the answer to be E (tug boat)<n><n># **Solution 1 (More In Depth):**<n>```powershell<n>$input = "The helm is not "<n>$input2 = "something you "<n>$input3 = "wear on your head."<n>$Input4 = "Rather, it moves "<n>$Input4 = $Input4 + "the masts "<n>$Input4 += "on what?"

How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John hated mosquitoes.  It wasn't the bloodsucking that he disliked, it was that the insects made what? Choices:  A: fly B: buzz C: move D: honey E: help flowers pollenate<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Mosquitoes fly or buzz. And pollenate flowers.<n>F<n><n>### Input : There are 7 people in the audience.  The manager tells the usher to hand out 5 tickets for free.  How many tickets must be distributed to the remaining two people?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Tickets are distributed according to the number of people in your party.<n>For 6 people (in this case usher and 6 audience members) to get 5 tickets, you divide the 5 into 6, getting 1 round to divide it in half (2), and another to split it completely. You just have to distribute the 1 ticket that will have to be split between 2 people.<n>####<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>Sally has 5 pairs of identical socks, and 6 identical pairs of underwear. She gives a pair of socks and a pair of underwear to her brother, a pair of underwears to her mother, and a pair of socks to an orphan. Now neither her brother nor her mother has any underwear or socks left. How many underwear and socks does the orphan have?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Sally gives a sock and an underwear to the brother and a sock and an undershirt to her mother. And the orphan is left with one pair each.<n><n>####<n>Answer: Underwear:1 sock:1<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>Answer:<n>Eighty-two dollars and eighty-two cents.<n><n>### Input 1: Mr. Lyle owns a pizza place.  He makes $10 for every large pizza or $5 for every small pizza. The next day, he only sells small pizzas, so he doubles his price. How much does he make the day after? <n><n>### Rules: <n>1. No one buys a small pizza after the price increase.<n>2. Every one buys the same amount of pizza after the price increases (i.e. no one buys more or less than they bought the day before). <n>3. Mr. Lyle only sells pizzas, he does not buy any.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The family was playing cards, what would be a reason for this?
