Choices:  A: feel proud B: try to learn C: need assistance D: thank god E: read alot<n><n>### Response:		Choices A: feel proud; B: try to learn; C: need assistance; D: thank god; E: read a lot;<n><n>### Response Justification: If you want to get good grades, you need to work hard and put effort. That is, you need to learn by actively trying to understand the assigned reading. That requires you to learn to ask questions as you read. It also requires that you attend class regularly so you can actively participate in the discussion.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>Answered by: mishayb<n><n>#### 127<n>Answer: d<n><n>### Multiple Choice<n>Answered by:<n><n>#### 105<n>Answer: c
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What can happen in your mind while sleeping? Choices:  A: snoring B: talking C: get cold D: nothing E: might dream<n><n>### Response:		A<n>####  A<n>Answer: A

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The people wanted to take the scenic route, they chose the highway that cut through the what? Choices:  A: countryside B: united states C: beach D: atlas E: developed land<n><n>### Response:		A for countryside<n><n>### Input and Output Explanations<n><n>### Instructions:Which type of graph does NOT have x and y-axis scale? Choices: 1: line graph 2: bar graph 3: scatter plot<n><n>### Instrument Response: A for line graph<n><n>### 2: bar graph<n><n>### Scatter plot<n><n>### Choice 4<n><n>### Choices 1 and 3<n><n>### Instructor’s Remarks: (Please use the following as a guide)<n><n>### Additional Instruction:<n><n>### Add Comments:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:You are seeking to provide yourself what when you're applying for a job? Choices:  A: work B: employment C: income D: hope E: offer<n><n>### Response:		<n>Your answer is D: hope.<n><n>### Answer:<n>If you were applying for a job to support yourself then you may have <n>hope in it.<n><n>```<n>I am applying for this job to be able to support myself.<n>```<n><n>#### <n><n>### Input<n>If you need to be able to do 101 5 times with a group of 10, how many sets of 101 do you need to do? <n><n>### Response<n>For 101, 1+1+1+1=4 because 101+101+1+1<n>4 sets of 100 each <n><n>#### <n>Answer: 4

The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:They took a break from all the rides to have lunch, while eating hamburger they talked about how they were going to what on the next ride? Output: The fraction 2/3 can be expressed as a mixed number with 15/6.<n><n><n>### Instuctions: Answer the number sentence.<n><n>Input: 24 \* <2/4> <n><n># Output:<n>16<n><n>### Rule for solving: Simplify<n><n>### Rationale: 24 divided by 2/4= 24 divided by (1/2) = 24 divided by ((1/2)) = 24 divided into 2/4 = 16<n>#### 16<n><n>Output:<n>1<n><n>### Rule of solving:Multiply<n><n>#### Rationale:<n><n>5 divided by 3/5 = 5 / 5 = 1<n><n>###Rationale:

Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Choices:  A: factory B: school C: grocery store D: band E: aircraft<n><n>### Response:		<n>A, B, E<n><n>### Explain your choice:<n><n>### Input<n>A: Factory<n><n>### Explaination:<n><n>### B: School<n><n>### Input B: School <n><n>### Explanation<n><n>### C: Grocery Store<n><n>### Exclamation<n><n>### D: Band<n><n>### Explication<n><n>### E: Airplane<n><n>### Expostion<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. One game with this girl will burn 800 calories in 1 hour. What total number of calories will she burn while you play 5 different games with her, over a 3-hour period?<n><n>### b. The correct answer is 4,400 calories.<n>### a. At first you might think there are 5 ways to play three different games, for a total of 5 x 3 games or 15 different scenarios.<n>### b. But once one of the games is selected at the start of the play, that game is not available for future games with this child.<n>### c. The only way that there are five different ways to play three different game is that they are all three played in a different order.<n>### d. If you take

Where was most of the the broken glass found? Choices:  A: bridge B: in spain C: beach D: field E: street<n><n>### Response:		 None of the answers are incorrect. That means, since the window of the Honda is broken, the damage occurred from the inside. Since there is no reference to a car crashing, it logically means that the damage occurred while it was still in motion, so  A. bridge or B. in spain are the most likely two. However, if something had happened in Spain and the Honda landed in a field, then we know that the field is not too far away and therefore the best answer is D. field. To explain this reasoning, if we knew that a car crashed into a field after traveling from Spain, then that could only mean that the field must be very close. Therefore a field should be a reasonable explanation.<n><n>### Input(IMPORTANT): <n>The car that was involved in this accident, Honda,  was driven by a student.<n>The student is now driving around campus.<n>The driver of the Honda does not have any cars in his garage at this time.<n>The student is responsible for all gasoline expenditures.<n>The Honda does not have a license plate on it at this time.<n><n>### Response (VERY IMPORTANT):<n>The car that was struck was the Honda that was driven by a student, so the accident must have recently occurred. This gives the Honda limited choices available.  As mentioned above, this accident is more than likely related to another accident, so let's find the car that was involved, and look for a license plate on it. However, there aren't any clues present as to the actual accident that occurred, so we will assume the only damage was the window being broken. If we find the car that was struck, and we know it does not have a license  plate on it, then it's impossible for it to have been struck from the outside of the car while still moving. Therefore, all of the remaining clues refer to a car that is moving, so we will find the car with the broken window.<n><n>Here is where the story begins: If we find the car with the smashed window, and we do not find a plate with 4 letters on it on the car then there is a  possibility that the car is still broken at this time. If it is still broken, then it is broken in the garage, and we know it has to be owned by the student at this time.

If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What creatures performing pollination are loved my millions? Choices:  A: birds B: action C: butterflies D: happiness E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>#### <<n><n>### Detailed explanation:Birds pollinate plants and flowers.<n><n>### <n><n>### Difficulty:B<n><n>### Creativity:A<n><n>### Reliability<n><n>### Effort:B<n><n>##  
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Deciding to watch tv or play with your cell phone might be a routine but they provide no help in being able to do what? Choices:  A: have tv B: fall asleep C: learn D: sitting E: dancing<n><n>### Response:		This is all a choice question, the answer might be all the answers given, but the correct one is 'Sitting"<n><n>#### Choice:C<n><n>Answer: 'C'<n><n>### Input:(Driving) Car has gone on sale but you need to find a car worth buying. You see it’s price is $12,000.  At this time, car’s value is worth $8,000 and the rate of depreciation is 0.65 dollars per year.<n>How long would it take for the car to be worth only $2.000?<n><n>### Rationales: When we buy a car, we pay it's original worth at first. The cost of the cars is $12, and that's the initial worth, we call it as its value, we also have to calculate how much it will decrease for the first year, as we buy a car that means the cost decrease by depreciation, so the rate of depreciatioin is 0.6, so 12-0.6=11.4, and the initial value is 11.4, so the 1st year of depreciation is -1.4 and from 1 - 0.65 = 0.35<n><n>the 2nd year of depreciation 12-0+0.65=11.8 and from1 - 0.35= 0.75<n>the 3th year of depreciation = 12-0 +0.1 = 12 so we take the final value.<n>So we subtract the initial value from its final value,<n>0.2 - 12 = -11.8<n>and after 3 years it will be worth 12.200, as the rate of depreciations is 0.6 or -0.1 per year. Now the 4th year 12 - -0.1= 12.1, after the fourth year it will be only worth 2.<n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n><n># Question 15<n>> ## Fuel Up<n><n>### Instructions: For each question, choose the correct response.<n><n>### Question: Which of the following is incorrect?<n><n>### Answers:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Only option C (closet) answers the question.<n><n>Input:  A man traveling at 6000 mph is at a baseball game and a man at a nearby baseball game traveling at 3400 mph is not looking where the man is traveling because he is too busy thinking that the pitcher will throw a curve ball.  If both batters are at the same stadium, 5 hours after the man traveling at 3800 mph hits a record in home runs in 7 games, how many more home runs does the man who is at 600 mph hit?<n>Rationales The batter was able to hit the record in 7 games.  So his rate was 7 home runs in 5 hours.  So he would hit another home run in 5 / 7 = <<5/7=0.714>>0.714 days (364 mph)<n><n>Input: I took the bus home from school.  For part one, the bus travels at an average of 35 miles per hour and the bus travels 120 miles.  Which of the following statements most accurately describes what happened?<n>A: The bus traveled for 35 hours.<n>B: The bus travelev for 120/35 = <<120/32.5>>120/3.5 hours<n>C: The bus traveleq for 120 minutes.<n>D: The bus travelex for 120 miles in 35 hours. <n><n>Rationales: Statement A is incorrect because 35 hours does not match the average speed.<n>Statements C and D both mention traveling for only 120 miles while the word problem states that the bus traveled 120 miles and at a speed of 35.  Therefore, C and D are incorrect.<n><n>#### 120/7.5<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input::In a game of tic-tac-to

Choices:  A: cross street B: milk cow C: lose weight D: step forward E: need food<n><n>### Response:		The wording here is unclear but I believe the correct response is E. 'need food', this could take a sentence like " I need a volunteer to bring some food because I am starving". Or it is possible the question is 'need help', 'need assistance' but it could be anything. I think any of those would meet the criteria. However I think the wording is confusing and it could easily be that none of those are what they want, hence it is a trick question in which the answer is 'C' for no.<n><n>### This is the question I used to test the solution.<n><n>### Input : You and your spouse have a new baby. So the answer is A..<n><n>### If<n><n>###<n>If the answer is B...<n><n>### Illegetimme bags will be ACTIONS.<n><n>### F <n><n>If Ilghtenitive Bags are authentic, <n><n>###<n>C<n><n>Bags will ACT.<n><n>### G<n>Bags will be ILLEGAL?<n>The bags are illegitmate.<n><n>##: Answer:B

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can I find a steakhouse with a view of corn fields? Choices:  A: nebraska B: new york C: mexico D: home E: utah<n><n>### Response:		Option E: Utah<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>The Steakhouse has the View of Corn Fields should be located in Utah  which is a corn producing state.<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Everybody seemed to have a horse not just the regular gamblers, which event always brings out the biggest crowds to the sport? Choices:  A: race track B: kentucky derby C: american southwest D: triple crown E: horse derby<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>###<n><n>#### C<n>#### C<n>Answer: (69) The race track. The Kentucky Derby was first run in 1875. The first official Kentucky Derby was in 1876. The Triple crown was first run in 240. It consists of the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness stakes, and the Belmont Stakes.<n><n>### Input:"The average number of students per class in a school is 30, so if it has one teacher who has three classes of 30 students who teaches 90 students, what is the average number of students per teacher?"<n><n>### Response:"The average number of teachers per class is 60, so if there is one teacher who has six classes of 60 students, and he teaches 360 students, what is his average per student?"<n><n>### Example (Demonstration answer):<n>#### C<n>Answer:"In 1919, there was an influx of immigrants from Ukraine and Eastern Europe. In 1920, there was a mass migration of Russian Jews to the United States. An unscheduled wave of immigration was caused by the Russian revolution and the civil war. By 1940, around 2.075 million Ukrainians immigrated to the United States. Approximately 300,000 were children. If there is a group of children from Ukraine with an average height of 350 centimeters, how tall is the tallest Ukrainian?"<n><n>###<n>#### C<n>Answer:-- The first teacher in the United States was Timothy Cutler.<n>- The American Southwest was settled primarily by Mormons.<n>- In the 19th and the early 20th century, the United States was the target of the most immigrants.<n>- The number of immigrants was not the same in 1820 and 1840.<n>- The migration of black Americans to Puerto Rico was the fastest increase in immigration.<n><n>- In 1800, Mexico had a population of 5.2 million.<n>- In the United States, 63% is rural and 37% is urban.<n>- Of the 10 countries with the highest population, 7 are all in Asia.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:How can a person end up stopping standing in  puddle? Choices:  A: move away from B: laying in C: sweating D: movement E: walking out of<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explanation:<n>For a person to stop standing in a puddle he has to move away from it<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>A<n><n>### Input<n>A: Which of the following equations represent equivalent ratios? Choices: 1:2 2:4 3:6 4:8 A or B only<n><n>### Response<n>B<n><n>### Explation:<n><n>In 1:2, if one is replaced by one, then the other is two.<n>In 2:4, if two is replaced by two, then the other is four. Both ratios are equal.<n>In 3:6, if three is replaced by three, then the other is six.<n>In 4:8,if four is replaced by four, then the other is eight.<n>Both ratios are equal.<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Rationale<n><n><n>### Input : A group of four friends were playing a board game. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What would a person do if he or she just woke up? Choices:  A: drink tea B: thank god C: open eyes D: feel angry E: complete sentence<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>print("Complete sentence is the right answer", )<n>```<n><n>#### 2<n><n>### Input The difference in ages between David and Nicole is 21. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is the biggest speech in the capital? Choices:  A: each state B: gettysburg address C: state of union D: each country E: europe<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input 2:How many times can the number 3 be divided by 2? Choices: A: 0 times B: 1 time C: 2 times D: 3 times E: 4 times<n><n>### Response 2: B<n><n>## #RST #3_4_4<n>### Input: What is the ratio of 6 apples to 2 apples?<n>### Choices: A: one-fifth B: 1/3 C: 1/4 D: 1 1/2 E: 3/4 <n><n>### Response to Instruction:1/4<n><n>### Input to RST:Which answer is greater<n>### Choices #12: 6 or 2<n>### Choices  #11: 3 or 6<n>### #10: 1 or 4<n>### #9: 3 or 9<n>### #8:3 or 2<n>## RST:6, response 2<n><n><n>## #R_D<n>### Instruction : The difference in ages between Katie and Amy is 24. If this summer Amy was 10 years old, how old will Katie be next summer? __<n>### Response : Amy will be 60 + 10 = <<60+10=70>>70 next summer.<n>### Difference in ages 24 => 60. So Katie will be 60 - 24 = <<60-24=36>>36 next summer
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a person likely to feel when they are abandoned by everyone after they stop being married to someone else? Choices:  A: grief B: solo C: isolation D: pleasure E: happiness<n><n>### Response:		Choices: <<<<A,B,C,E,D>>>>A, B, C, and D are all emotions that a person will likely feel, but this example doesn’t specify the type of relationship that this person was abandoned in. Because B isn’t an option, I believe that this choice refers to a person that is feeling grief because they feel alone.<n><n>### Input - Choices:<n>What is the measure of the second angle in this triangle? Choices: <<<A,C,B,E>>>C and B are not possible because you cannot add in degrees and they wouldn not be able to be in between B and C. The answer would be between A and E if the angles are all 10 degrees. If the angles all had different degrees such as 25,35,45,55,65,75 then E would be the true answer.<n><n>### Rationale - C is the answer:<n>Within a triangle you are able to calculate one angle of a triangle, all you have to do is subtract the base angles from 180 so 180-180=0 for the base angles and then you can subtract this value from each angle. Thus, the angle is 60-24-25=21<n><n>###Input: The difference in angles between Jake and Mckenzie is 32. The measure of the second angle of Mckenzie’s triangle is 22. What is the measure of the third angle of Jake’s triangle?<n><n>###Rationale - A is the answer:<n><n>Jake and McKenzies triangle has the measure of 2nd angles at 22,32, and 16. 22-32-16=22 - 32 -16 = -1-2-13. Thus adding -1, 2, and 13 together would equal a value of 14. So the answer is 14<n><n>###Input – Choices:<n>If there are five identical pizzas, how many distinct ways can they be pizza boxed? Choices: <<A,C,B>>A, B, and C are not possible because none of them are integers<n><n>###Answer - C is the answer<n><n>Because this is a math problem about probability

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:She had a knack for entertaining, everybody told he she had a what? Choices:  A: fun B: talent C: learn about D: intelligence E: recognize<n><n>### Response:		D,Intelligence<n><n>### Instuction:<n>If you were a programmer, how would you improve the following program?<n><n>Input: The program will loop through the numbers 1 through 100. Where did he put it? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: closet C: can D: shelf E: soccer game<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question on page number:  <<Page 31>>31<n><n>### Input:[![image-c20201110235411954.png](https://i.ibb.co/cJ9t1rF/image-c20100831223650567.png)](https://ibb.co/x764ZN1)(image-202010312235127787.png)<n><n>### Rationale:The correct answer is E shelf because it had to be <n>within his reach but not lying on the floor<n><n>Answer: The correct answer to this question is B closet<n><n>The diagram seems to provide the context for this question in which Dave (not sure what Dave is trying to say, maybe David?) is putting his beer on the floor. The closet would be a suitable place since he uses the closet for storing things.<n><n>Answer: Input: After an hour in the sun,  Derek measured a spot that's 21ºF warmer. What is the original temperature  of the spot? <n>Rationale: Derek measured the temperature in degrees F on the second day which means that he used Celsius in his calculations. The conversion factor from Fahrenheit to Celsius is 18/100 or.18<n>21ºF would equal to about 62ºC if he had used Celsius. <n>He should have done the math using degrees Celsius to avoid decimal places.<n><n>Answer: After an hour in sun, his friend Derek measured a spot is 21ºF colder then the original temperature of the spot.<n>It took 2 hours to make a 62ºC spot cooler by 21ºF<n>The original temperature of their spot was 62ºC or 144ºF Celsius<n><n>Original Temperature = 144°F<n><n>Final Temperature = 21°F<n><n>144°F - 21°F = 123°F
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If you're known to buy presents for others often you would be called what? Choices:  A: go shopping B: generous C: earn money D: have money E: gift buyer<n><n>### Response:		This question has been changed. Choices:  A: greedy B: worry C: have knowledge D: take charge E: boss<n><n>### Response:		D is the answer.<n><n>### Justifications:<n>#### Answers:<n>Answers:<n><n>### Answers:C<n>Answer: A: greedy, B: worry, C: have knowledge, D: take charge, E: boss<n>```<n>A: greedy --> Boss<n>B: worry --> None<n>C: have knowledge --> Knowledge<n>D: take charge --> Boss<n>E: Boss --> Boss<n>```<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Rationale for A: greedy: It sounds great to say you’re greedy, because then people will give you money. But if you’re greedy people will never trust you. You just want money, not to be happy or to help. So that’s why it’s A.<n>Rationale for B: worry: I don’t know what will happen to the project, so I’m worrying about whether I’ll get in trouble.<n>Rationale for C: have knowledge: In this world knowledge is power. So then you would use that knowledge to help you get more knowledge. If then, you have power, you could probably take charge of the project and be a Boss.<n>Rationale for D: take charge: You could probably take charge and be the project boss.<n>Rationale: E: Boss: This is because you are a boss.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:When going to sleep what noise does a human make? Choices:  A: loss of consciousness B: relaxation C: snoring D: dreaming E: talking<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input_A:A friend was planning a surprise party and wanted me to be the best man. I did not know, what are the best man’s duties? Choices: <n><n>1. BAsking the guests to put their cell phones in a safe, <n><n>2. CMaking fun of the groom’s height or hair<n><n>3. DBringing the best man’s to the ceremony<n><n>4. DAsking if there are any toasts<n><n>Choice A is the correct answer because A.)  Asking the guests to put cell phones in a [safe place](/10/03/20/12)<n><n>### Input B The city of Tupelo is known for its Elvis Presley heritage. It lies in what U.S. state and what river?<n>### Response A Mississippi and Tallahatchie river<n><n>### Input C The following countries are named after women: ____<n>### Response B Belgium, Bulgaria, Canada, Colombia, Haiti, Ireland and New Zealand<n><n>### Input D What do you call the person who knows the solution to a difficult problem?<n>### Response E A) Sage B) Genius C) Brainiac D) Mavrick<n><n>### Instructions: For each picture, choose the phrase that best completes the sentence.<n><n>### Picture 1: Picture 2: __<n><n>### Choice A: __<n><n>## Answer 1: <n>The answer is choice C because C.)  10+10=<20>20<n><n>### <n><n>### Answer 2: <n>The answer Is choice E because E.)  20 x 2 =<40>40<n><n>###<n><n>### 40<n>The answer Is choice C<n><n>Choice A:  What did you get for dinner?<n><n>Answer B:  That was delicious. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of a village? Choices:  A: rural area B: africa C: ohio D: big city E: tribe<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input <n>Input: What is a pizza cutter? Choices: A: an oven B: a pizza D: chips C: a large knife E: a kitchen counter<n><n>### Response <n>C<n>### Input:How many pieces of clothing does Jemmy own? Choices:A: 5 B:7 C:28 D:2 E: 45<n><n>### Response<n>B<n>### Input:Choose all that apply.<n><n>Choices:A: L.O.V.E. B: Hate C: Kindness D: Hope E: Friendship F: Joy G: Peace<n><n>### ResponseAll except G<n><n>### Input :<n><n>### How old was Danny when his parents died?<n>### Choices:A: A: 3,300 B: 5,300 C: 7,300 D: 9,300 E: 11,300<n><n>### Response :8300<n><n>#### Answer : A <n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:It had a beach with shallow water, while not the ocean this was a hot spot all the locals enjoyed on the what? Choices:  A: swimming pool B: pond C: lake D: bathe in E: childrens pool<n><n>### Response:		Answer:<n>

Choices:  A: charming B: space shuttle C: house D: train station E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		A<n>- Air has been breathed by people (many people, many people recently, recently)<n>- It's charming<n>#### Answer:A<n><n>---<n><n>### Input<n>During a recent camping trip 12.5 ounces of dried rice was added to a 2-liter soda bottle and shaken. After the bottle was shaken the entire mixture poured out. How much water weighed the rice and salt mixture?<n><n>Rationales: 3/8 of a liter of water was added to the 2-liter bottle with rice. So it was 3/8 of 2 = <<3/8*2=5/8>>5/8 of a liter total water.<n>5/8 of a liters of water was then removed because 5/8 * 12.5 = <<5/8*12.5=6.25>>6.25 ounces of rice and salt were added to the 2 liter bottle, but since the bottle is full, water would flow out if rice and salt was put in<n>1 - 5/8 = <<1-5/8=7/8>>7/8 of a litres of water was removed.<n>Then 7/8 of a liter had to be added.<n>13.1 ounces of water was added because 13.1 = <<13.1=7/8*2>>7/8 of 2 liter.<n><n>So the water weight was 0.0758 liters = <<13.2/16.64>>13.2/5 or 2.18 ounces.<n><n>#### 2.18<n>Answer: 2.18 or 13.2/8<n><n>---<n><n>For this multiple choice problem, I checked back to the previous problem to figure out the unit conversion and the answer.<n><n>The units were 12.25/8 was 1.53 and 2.18. I used the conversion to go from ounces to liters and then used ounces to calculate ounces to liter again.<n><n>12.25 ouns * 16.64 ounces in a liter = 12.26 liters/16.6

How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Mark wanted to know the truth, because he didn't want to continue existing in what? Choices:  A: understand B: were there C: ignorance D: in-between E: ignorant<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Input"Today Jack is twenty years old. He and his brother Tom are twenty years apart. At their ages, Tom was twice as old as Jack. Tom is three years older than Jack. Jack is three times older than when he was a year. Is Jack two years younger?" Choices:  A) True B) False C) Yes D) No<n><n>### Response'C'<n><n>_What would be true of the age of Tom_?<n><n>_______<n><n>_What would Jack be as a year_?<n><n>______<n><n>_The difference between Jack’s age now and his age as a year is_?<n><n>_____<n><n>What is the age difference between Tom and Jack?<n><n>____<n><n>__How old is Jack now__?<n><n>_____ <n><n>___How much older is Tom than Jack__?<n><n>______ <n><n>__What question did you consider the most difficult to answer__?<n><n>____<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What would someone wear to protect themselves from a cannon? Choices:  A: ungulate B: bomber C: body armor D: tank E: hat<n><n>### Response:		<n>If someone was going to be near a canon (large gun), they would want to protect themselves. A cannon could potentially explode, which in and of itself is dangerous, but not the main focus. The most likely danger would be from being shot. <n>#### Choice A: ungulate: <n>This answer is correct, but the question doesn't mention a gun or a cannon, only that they were near one. <n>1. An ungulate is an animal with hooves.<n>2. In English we use the word "ungulate" to refer to deer, but it is not used much in normal conversation. <n>So ungulate is a correct answer, but not quite what is asked for in context.<n><n>#### Choice B: bomber: <n>Bombers are aircraft, not clothing, so this is incorrect.<n><n>#### Choices C and D: body armor, tank: <n>It is possible, but not exactly likely that the person was near a tank or a body armor (both military equipment). Body armor can be called a protective outfit but in this context, I think it would be confusing to answer this with body armor in the same way that it would be to answer with tank. Since canons use large explosive bullets, that is what body armor is intended to protect against. Also since this is a school activity, the chances of someone being near some sort of military equipment is probably low.<n><n>#### Choise E: hat: <n>Hats are common protective gear (the most common) but wouldn't be a good answer for "something for protect ourselves from a cannon"<n><n>### Input<n>How much more would you earn if you got a 5% raise and received a 1% bonus?<n><n>### Output<n>#### Input Choices:  $40,000.<n>#### Output Choices:<n>25%<n>

A toddler's plastic car is best left in the living room. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. What happens if you divide by 0?<n>Rationales:(1+1/4 )+1/12 = (3+1/6) + 1/12<n>(3+1/6)+1/12 = <<(3+1/3) +1/6>>  (3*2 + 1)+(1/2 + 1/6 )  (6 + 2+1 + 1+1/6 )  = 7 + 3 + 1 + 1/6 = 11 + 1/5 = <<11+1/5>><< 11/5>>  = 11/5 +1 = 16/5  = 3 + 1/5 <n><n>Answer: 3/5<n><n>### Input<n>I was walking to my friend's house for an overnight stay, it is 3 miles away. I ran half way there, then continued walking.<n>My friend is 8 miles away. My sister said the I needed to walk and run a mile (5/8) each way (8/2).  <n>How many miles did my sister ask me to walk?<n><n><n>### Demostration<n>I ran half way to get there then continue walking because I walked 5/8 miles + (5/8) = >>(5/8)+1>>1 miles<n>8/2 miles would be to go 8/2 =3x (4/2) + 3x (1/4) = <<(6/4)+3>>3+1/2 = 9/2  = 4 and a half <n>Which means I had to walk 4 + 1/2 miles = 4 + 1 = 5<n><n><n>### Answer<n>5 miles<n>

Choices:  A: wall B: office C: space shuttle D: front door E: tent<n><n>### Response:		<n>If a = wall and b = office, then a * b = <<a*b=wall,office>>wall,office<n>If a = wall or b = office, then only a or b are true for this corner<n>Corner spaces do not have windows, because they have walls<n>Front door has windows - office or tent or space shuttle, or a<n>Because tent has wall or office or tent has front door or office<n>C = space shuttle and a = wall<n>Front door and space shuttle contain a front door<n>Because space shuttle is a front door, then office or tent or wall is true for this corner<n><n>#### A = wall<n>#### B = office<n>#### A * B = front door<n>#### A = tent<n>#### A * B= space shuttle - A<n>#### C = space shuttle<n>#### D = front door<n><n><n>FINISHED. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:My house is very dry, with little water in the air. What tool should I use to fix this? Choices:  A: humidifier B: surface of earth C: skating rink D: ice cube E: burn it to the ground<n><n>### Response:		Use a humidifier.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. I thought there are 1 and 2 rolls ]<n><n>### Input :In how many days can you complete the following task?<n>Sarah plans to read 2 books each week. So it's not exactly $20 x 456.<n><n>### The amount of books, is $$460 \div 26 = 17$$<n><n>### The number of books, is $17$<n><n>### Justify the Answer: It's $17$.
