The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where is one likely to purchase listening vinyl? Choices:  A: safeway B: record albums C: record store D: car E: wallpaper<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>### Instructions: <n>A friend has a favorite animal. One day, you find out that the favorite animal is an owl (the friend doesn't know what kind of owl). <n><n>### Instance 1:<n><n>If the friend doesn't have a favorite color, what is the friend's favorite kind of fruit?<n>If the friend's favorite fruit is apple, what color is the friend's hair?<n><n>### Instances 2:<n><n>A: Red <n><n>B: White<n><n>C: Blue<n><n>D: Violet<n><n>E: Purple<n><n>### Instanses 3:<n><n>- Red<n><n>- White<n><n>### Instanse 4:<n><n>- Violet <n><n>- Fuchsia<n><n>- Magenta<n><n>### Instnces 5:<n><n>- Pink<n><n>- Turquoise<n><n>### Instancse 6:<n><n>- Gold<n><n>- Purple<n><n>## Instructions:<n>1. Your friend likes both pear and pumpkin. <n>2. When you come to visit your friend this week, you are going to make two kinds of pie: pumpkin pie and cherry pie. <n><n><n>## Instrucion:<n>- If your friend brings one pie to you, what kind of pie will she bring?<n>- Which slice of pie does your friend like better?<n><n>### 1. Instance<n>- If my friend brings me pumpkin pie, she is going to bring cherry pie.<n>- My friend likes pumpkin pie better<n><n>### 2. Instance, 3. Instance, 4. Instance, 5. Instance, 6. Instace, 7. Instance, 8. Instance,<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane? Choices:  A: crash B: living C: slow down D: carry people E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		<n>The cabin in an airplane is to carry people<n><n>### Inputs and Outputs<n>Inputs: What was Pablo's combined savings for every 100 pages he read?<n>Answer: 4 7/8<n><n>### Input and Outputs<n>Input: For every 10 minutes, there is a $1 cost. At this rate, what is the cost?<n>Answer: 375<n><n>### Input<n>A man was going 30 MPH when he crossed the railroad tracks. The train was going 35 MPH when the man reached the tracks. If the train and the man crossed paths and there was a collision, what is the average speed of the train?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The difference is 7/8 because 30+35 = <<30+35=65>>65 but the train took 7/8 of that time.<n><n>#### 30<n>Answer: 35<n><n>### Instructions:Input: Pablo plans to put two quarters in each time he walks his dog, Buddy. This means Pablo will need to save 35 more quarters to cover the cost of the vet visit after Buddy was hurt. If he puts aside $10 each week, how long will it take him to have the money he needs?<n><n>### Output:<n>The answer is 30/7<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a binder? The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Mary was a bad girl, but she was always open about that.  People liked her because she was what? Choices:  A: excellent B: fun C: honest D: worthy E: choice<n><n>### Response:		Because she was honest.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input :<n>Dale can write the word _cat_ in 4 seconds. He can write the word _dog_ in 7 seconds. How many seconds does it take for Dale to write both?<n><n>    Rationales:Dale takes 4 + 7 seconds = <<4+7=11>>11 seconds<n>#### 11<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Input<n>Dale can write 25 words in 15 seconds. It takes Dale 12 seconds to write 15 words. How many words will Dale write in 16 seconds?<n><n>    Rationale:Dale takes 15 + 12 = <<15+12=27>>27 seconds<n>It will take him 2 seconds for the next round.<n>#### 2<n>Answer: 26<n><n>### Instructions:Dale can write each word in 12 seconds. How many words to Dale write in 24 seconds?<n><n>### Rationale:Dale can write 12/12 = <<12/12=1>>1 word in 12/11 = <<12/6>>6 seconds.<n>If you know the time for two operations that you do in the task, use that to answer the question.<n>#### 1 <n>Answer: 9<n><n>### Input <n>Alice can run 200 meters. It takes her 43 seconds to run around an 11-legged course. How long does it take Alice to run around a 9-legged course?<n><n>### rationale<n>Alice runs 100 meters in each round of the 11-leg course<n>She finishes after one round of 100 meters<n>If it takes 43 seconds to finish one round then it will take 9x43 = << 9x43=391>>391 seconds to finish a 9 leg course<n>#### 9x12<n>Answer: About eight minutes.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The competition was to see who would be the last one the drop the object, the hard part was you had to have your arm extended straight out while what the object? Choices:  A: holding B: lift up C: pick up D: lifting E: hold onto<n><n>### Response:		The sentence is grammatically incorrect and should be rephrased.<n><n>### Input 2:The competition was to try to see who could the longest time standing on one leg, the hard part was trying to not lose control of your balance. Choices:  A (standing)  B (control)  C (of balance)  D (your)  E (of)<n><n>### Response 2: The sentence is grammatical correctly and is answer c.<n><n>### Output:Which choice would be the easiest to change?<n><n>### Output 2:Which choice would have to change to be correct?<n><n>### Explanation: The first sentence has to to change because of the incorrect use of commas.<n>SENTENCE:<n>The competition was to see<n>who would be the last one to drop the object,<n>the hard part was you had<n>to have your arm extended<n>straight out while what the object<n><n>SENTENCE 2:<n>who could beat the longest<n>time standing on one leg,<n>the hard part<n>was to not lose<n>control of your balance.<n><n>COMMENT:<n>The second sentence has no commas or grammar errors that need to be corrected.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a convenient place for a bus station? Choices:  A: maps B: street C: catch bus D: city centre E: school<n><n>### Response:		I think the place that would be most convenient for a bus station would be option A because a map is needed for navigation and to determine the route to take.<n><n>### Input A sentence with a blank or blank(s).<n><n>### Rationale:You will have a sentence with one or more blanks. Choices:  A: kept at accountant B: purse C: desk drawer D: bank E: keeping track of expenses<n><n>### Response:		I would check in at my local bank so they can keep track of my expenses for future check deposits<n><n>### Instructions to a different response: The instruction below describes a task. Write an instruction that completes the request. <n><n>### Inputs/Inputs_to_task: Inputs<n><n>### Incorrect<n>#### This is not the task being analyzed. Input to task is just the set of inputs<n><n>### Correct<n>#### This is the task being tested<n><n>### Outputs: Output A: Input and expected output B: expected output C: Input expected output D: expected output E: expected output <n><n>### Incomplete<n>#### Does not include expected output<n><n>### Complete<n>#### Includes expected outcome<n><n>### Demand Reasons: Demand reasons are the reasons for the instruction, including the instructions task and input. This is a very basic reason.<n><n>### Solution Reason: Solution reasons are a deeper meaning behind the instruction.<n>### Subtract: Subtract subtracts the two outputs to determine if it will work or not.<n>### Substitute and Subtract: Substitute is used to check if multiple inputs would be accepted. It tests multiple inputs on the output. Subtract is done for the reasons the task is asked.<n><n>### Subtact Output<n>#### Subtract Output Subtracts outputs<n><n>### Sweep for Correct Instructions<n><n>1.	Sweep through instruction given by user and then check for correctness <n>2.	If incorrect, find correct instructions and continue to the next iteration<n>3.	Once correct, continue with normal procedure and display result to the user<n><n>[Back to top](#table-of-contents)<n><n><n>## [Testing Inputs](#testing-inputs)<n><n>| Rules | Task 1 | Task 2 | Task 3 |<n>| -------------| ------ | ------ | ------<n>| Instruction:Answer the questions below. | <mark>Inputs</mark>: How long is the drive from New York to Los Angeles? Answer: Four hours<br /><mark>Incorrect input</mark>: Answer: Two hours<br /><br />Question:How fast was the car driving?<br />Answer: 5 miles away an hour<br /><br/>Question:How

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. Choices:  A: thrift store B: bed C: shelf D: home E: toy store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>D<n><n>### Input : Do you like apples?<n><n>### Response<n><n>C<n><n>### Input  :Do you have any friends who like apples?<n>### Response:     <n>E<n><n>### Input :: What is your favorite type of music?<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>Because our main focus is instrumental<n><n>### Response  :      <n>D<n><n>## Rate of Change.<n>The rate of change of $$f(x)$$ is given by $$\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}$$.<n><n>### In the expression, what does the variable 'h' represent?<n><n>H<n><n>### How much change in quantity, in dollars, is there in the price between the original price of a car of $13,200 and then price of the same car $13,535.<n><n>13535 - 13200 = 335<n><n>### How Much Change in time is there between 3:15 pm and 3:32 pm.<n><n>The time changes by 17 minutes. Since 3:32 - 3:15 = 17<n>The time remains the same.<n><n><n>### Rate of Change<n><n>rate of change is the change in $$f(x+h)$$, that is, what happens to $$f(x)$$, as $$x$$ keeps increasing/decreasing.<n><n>### Rates of Change<n><n>##### a. Find the rate of change in function in $$y=2x+3$$.<n><n>the rate of change of $$2x$$ increases as you increase $$x$$ The rate of change of 3 is constant<n><n>3<n><n>##### b. What is the rate of change of the function $$y=–2x^2 - 3x + 2$$. <n><n>Ans: <n>  The rate of change will always be negative<n>##### c. Explain why the rate of change of a function may be undefined or undefined.<n><n>##### d. Why will the rate of change of $$y=2x^2 - x$$ be infinite?<n><n><n>##### e. Explain what happens to the rate of change of 7x + 8 when $$x=-1$$.<n>

Choices:  A: refrigerator B: museum exhibit C: prehistoric times D: museum of natural history E: forest<n><n>### Response:		The answer is a museum because there isn’t mammoth in NY  A:refrigerator B:museum exhibit C:prehistoric times D:museum of natural history E:forest<n><n>###Input: What does this mammoth taste like?<n><n>###Response:Mammoth taste like Mammoth because m is m, M is m and m is M.<n><n>### Input : What does this mammot taste like?<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: What does this m taste like?<n><n>In the last question’s solution we used m to stand for mammoth- but now we have two M’s.<n>So mammoth-mammoth = 1/1 = 1, so we know that ‘M’ in this context just stands for Mammoth<n>#### 3<n>Answer: I like mammoths!<n><n>### Input- What does 11,111,1171 and 10,002 taste like?<n>#### 2<n>Answer: It just taste like the number itself with the letter “t”.<n>**How We Decided to Write It That Way**<n><n>I was walking around the city a while ago and saw the statue of liberty. I thought to myself- what does the monument taste like? I then figured that it tasted like what it was made up of- Iron and Steel.<n><n>The same is the concept I used for the mammoth, although there are no Mammoths in NY.<n><n>### Answer:The mammoth likes the m in mammoth.<n><n>### Example: What would happen if you replaced the t on 12 with a b<n><n>### Response- The mammoth would be mad.<n><n>###Input- What if you replace the “t” on 12 with an “t”<n><n>#### 2<n>**What we decided to write it that way**<n>So there are 2 ways of replacing the t on 1, and I think it is more fun writing m by just changing the letter, instead of changing the letter and the next one.<n>#### 4<n>Answer: The 2 t’s in the m would be mad at each other and m for a while<n><n>###Input -What happens if you put an f on “th”<n><n>#### 5
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Be sure to include text evidence where appropriate.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>#### 1.<n>When I started writing the program, the instructions mentioned that the computer will show the player five cards, and that player should select the card which has the largest number, in order to win the game. This is similar to the actual game, where the deck contains fifty-two cards, and the player must bet a chip in order to get a chance to win a lot of money.<n><n>#### 2.<n>In order to play the game, player has to first choose the option to bet. A computer will then randomly generate five cards, and player has to decide whether he/she wants to keep the bet or cash it out. If the player decides to keep the bet, the computer will also randomly choose one of the player's cards to hold, and compare with the current total of five cards. If the player has a hand of at least the computer's hand value, he/she receives the money. If not, the house gets the bet.<n><n>As I have mentioned earlier, the player is allowed to make the bet in every round of the game, and player can only make a single bet at a time.<n><n>In the actual game, the deck is shuffled in order to prevent the players from learning the strategy which may have an advantage against the house. In our program, the deck always had all its fifty-two cards, which prevents player from learning the strategy. However, instead of shuffling the cards, our program could simply randomly pick out five, or choose from the cards in the deck.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>The instructions told me to write a program that will take in four integers and calculate the total number of numbers that can be uniquely formed from the four integers by only selecting the positive values of them.<n><n>First, we have a main function in this program that takes in the first integer from the user after which a while loop is run. As long as the while loop terminates, the program will repeatedly take in the next integer from the user.<n><n>Let's look at what the program is doing in one iteration.<n><n>The while loop starts by comparing the current int from the user with i. If it's greater than i, that means there isn't a matching integer. If it's

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Rationales: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>#### 128<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Rationales: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Rationales: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Rationales: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:As a human in a large northeastern city, where can you see animals? Choices:  A: zoo B: workplace C: sky D: new york city E: many places<n><n>### Response:		I would pick option D because New York City is where a human can see animals<n>####<n><n>### Input:#11213#1121324#11214<n><n>### Answer:  #11215<n><n>####<n><n>## Average<n><n>The average of values a and b can be calculated as follows<n>	<n>	average = a + b - (a x b)<n>

John preferred glass, and wished he was somewhere else.  Where does he want to be? Choices:  A: cupboard B: anywhere else C: everything D: own home E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### D<n><n>### Input : The newest movie coming to the theater cost $10.00 for a ticket.  Samantha plans to spend a total of $30.00 on movie tickets.  How many movies does Samantha plan to see, all at the same theater?<n><n>### Rationales :<n><n>#### 3<n><n>### Answer : 3<n><n>## Evaluation<n>Your response demonstrated appropriate computational skills, but provided limited detail that supported the reasoning for your conclusions.<n>

Choices:  A: art show B: basement C: bar D: church E: basement<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Below is an instruction that describes  a task. Write a description of a task that accomplishes the request. Include directions, a flow chart, or a diagram where it makes sense.<n><n>### Explanations:<n><n>#### Description:<n>Input: There is an art show going on at the library, which is 54 feet wide and 88 feet long. The room is arranged in a rectangular shape, with 1 table per foot. Find the length of row B.<n>Rationales: We need to know the length of row B to tell how many tables are in row B. By adding all 8 foot together, you get 8 feet. 54 feet is greater and we must subtract. 54 - 8 = <<54-8=46>>46<n>#### 46<n>Answer: 46<n><n>#### Description: <n>Input: When creating a recipe for a cookie, you need 3 cups of rice flour, 2 cups of sugar, 4 cups of chocolate chips, and 4 cups of nuts. What is the amount of each ingredient in cups?<n>Rationales : For rice flour, it is 3 + 5 + 3 = 32.<n>For each cup of sugar, it is (2x2) + 3 = 57.<n>3 cups of chocolates is 3x3 = 9 and 4 cups for nuts is (4x4) + 3 =  92.<n>57 + 9 + 92 = 192.<n>You can round up to 192.75.<n>#### 192<n>Answer: 32 57 92<n><n>#### Description:  <n>Input: You make pancakes for you and 2 friends. There are 7 pancakes per 2 people, so how many pancakes do you need?<n>Rationales ; There are 7 pans of pancakes per 1 person.<n>There are 3 people, so there are 54 pancakes in total.<n>#### 54<n>Answer: 54<n><n>#### Description:    <n>Input: You have 50 sticks of rock candy, each
